abstract: The GBA gene encodes the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase (GCase), which maintains glycosphingolipid homeostasis. Approximately 5-15% of PD patients have mutations in the GBA gene, making it numerically the most important genetic risk factor for Parkinson's disease (PD). Clinically, GBA-associated PD is identical to sporadic PD except for earlier onset (AAO), more frequent cognitive impairment, and more rapid progression. Mutations in GBA can be associated with loss- and gain-of-function mechanisms. The main hallmark of PD is the presence of intraneuronal protein inclusions called Lewy bodies, which are mainly composed of alpha-synuclein. Mutation of the GBA gene can lead to loss of GCase activity and lysosomal dysfunction, which can disrupt alpha-synuclein metabolism. GCase deficiency models show dysfunction of the autophagic-lysosomal pathway and subsequent accumulation of alpha-synuclein. This dysfunction can also lead to disturbances in lipid metabolism, including the accumulation of glycosphingolipids, glucosylceramide, and glucosylsphingosine. Certain mutations cause GCase to misfold and be retained in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), activating stress responses, including the unfolded protein response (UPR), that can contribute to neurodegeneration. In addition to these mechanisms, GCase deficiency has also been associated with mitochondrial dysfunction and neuroinflammation, which have been implicated in the pathogenesis of PD. This review discusses the pathways involved in GBA-PD and highlights potential treatments that may work to target GCase and prevent neurodegeneration.

abstract: Psoriasis is a common chronic skin disease. Pathologically, it is characterized by abnormal epidermal proliferation, inflammatory cell infiltration, and increased angiogenesis in the dermis. Misexpression of E3 ubiquitin ligase and deregulated protein ubiquitination system have been implicated in the pathogenesis of psoriasis. To explore the potential role of S-phase kinase-associated protein 2 (Skp2), an E3 ligase and oncogene, in psoriasis. Gene expression and protein levels were assessed by quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction, western blotting, immunohistochemistry, and immunofluorescence staining of skin samples from patients with psoriasis vulgaris and an imiquimod (IMQ)-induced mouse model, as well as cultured endothelial cells. ). Protein interactions, substrate ubiquitination, and degradation were investigated using co-immunoprecipitation, Western blotting, and cycloheximide chase assays in human umbilical vein ECs. Angiogenesis was measured in vitro using human dermal microvascular ECs (HDMECs) for BrdU incorporation, migration, and tube formation. In vivo angiogenesis assays included chick embryonic chorioallantoic membrane, Matrigel plug assay, and quantification of blood vessels in mouse lesions. Skp2 gene global knockout (KO) mice and endothelial-specific conditional KO mice were used. Skp2 was increased in skin samples from psoriasis and IMQ-induced mouse lesions. Immunofluorescent double staining indicates a close association of Skp2 expression with excess vasculature in damaged skin papillae. In HDMECs, Skp2 overexpression enhanced, and Skp2 knockdown inhibited EC proliferation, migration, and tube-like structure formation. Mechanistically, phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN), which inhibits the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt pathway, was identified as a novel substrate for Skp2-mediated ubiquitination. A selective inhibitor of Skp2 (C1) or Skp2 small interfering RNA significantly reduces vascular endothelial growth factor-induced PTEN ubiquitination and degradation. In addition, Skp2-mediated ubiquitination was dependent on PTEN phosphorylation by glycogen synthase kinase 3β. Skp2 gene deficiency alleviated IMQ-induced psoriasis in a mouse model. Importantly, tamoxifen-induced endothelial-specific Skp2 KO mice developed significantly improved psoriasis with reduced papillary angiogenesis. Furthermore, topical application of the Skp2 inhibitor C1 effectively prevented experimental psoriasis. The Skp2/PTEN axis may play an important role in psoriasis-associated angiogenesis. Thus, Skp2-mediated targeting of angiogenesis may be a potential approach for the treatment of psoriasis.

abstract: Some studies have shown that gut microbiota may be associated with dementia. However, the causal effects between the gut microbiota and different types of dementia, and whether cytokines play a mediating role, are unclear. Gut microbiota, cytokines, and five types of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease (AD), frontotemporal dementia (FTD), Lewy body dementia (DLB), vascular dementia (VD), and Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) were identified from large-scale. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) summary data. We used Mendelian randomization (MR) to investigate the causal relationship between gut microbiota, cytokines, and five types of dementia. Inverse variance weighting (IVW) was used as the main statistical method. Furthermore, we investigated whether cytokines act as mediating factors in the gut microbiota-to-dementia pathway. There were 20 positive and 16 negative causal effects between genetic susceptibility in gut microbiota and dementia. Also, there were five positive and four negative causal effects between cytokines and dementia. Cytokines did not act as mediators. Gut microbiota and cytokines were causally associated with five types of dementia, and cytokines did not appear to mediate the pathway from gut microbiota to dementia.

IVW is a method used in Mendelian randomization (MR) studies to estimate the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome across multiple genetic instruments. It is not a gene, but rather a statistical technique.  Focus of the Study: The primary focus of the study is on the causal relationships between gut microbiota, cytokines, and various types of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, vascular dementia, and Parkinson’s disease dementia. Thus, the text cannot be used to evaluate genetic interactions involving a gene with that name in relation to dementia.

abstract: An open-label study showed that selective depletion of B cells using rituximab led to sustained clinical improvement in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. To confirm these observations, we conducted a randomized, double-blind, controlled trial. We randomly assigned 161 patients who had active rheumatoid arthritis regardless of methotrexate treatment to receive one of four treatments: oral methotrexate (> or =10 mg weekly) (control); Rituximab (1000 mg on days 1 and 15); rituximab plus cyclophosphamide (750 mg on days 3 and 17); or rituximab plus methotrexate. Responses defined by American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) criteria were assessed at 24 weeks (primary analysis) and 48 weeks (exploratory analyses). At 24 weeks, the proportion of patients with a 50 percent improvement in disease symptoms according to ACR criteria, the primary endpoint, was significantly higher with the rituximab-methotrexate combination (43 percent, P=0.005) and with the rituximab-cyclophosphamide combination (41 percent, P=0.005). than with methotrexate alone (13 percent). In all groups treated with rituximab, significantly more patients had a 20 percent improvement in disease symptoms according to ACR criteria (65 to 76 percent vs. 38 percent, P< or =0.025) or had EULAR responses (83 to 85). percent versus 50 percent, P< or =0.004). All ACR responses were maintained at 48 weeks in the rituximab-methotrexate group. The majority of adverse events occurred with the first infusion of rituximab: at 24 weeks, serious infections occurred in one patient (2.5 percent) in the control group and four patients (3.3 percent) in the rituximab group. The concentration of immunoglobulin in the peripheral blood remained within the normal range. In patients with active rheumatoid arthritis regardless of methotrexate treatment, a single course of two infusions of rituximab alone or in combination with cyclophosphamide or methotrexate provided significant improvement in disease symptoms at 24 and 48 weeks.

abstract: Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by persistent synovitis, systemic inflammation, and autoantibodies (especially to rheumatoid factor and citrullinated peptide). 50% of the risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis is attributed to genetic factors. Smoking is a major environmental risk. In industrialized countries, rheumatoid arthritis affects 0.5–1.0% of adults, with 5–50 per 100 000 new cases annually. The disorder is most common in women and the elderly. Uncontrolled active rheumatoid arthritis causes joint damage, disability, reduced quality of life, and cardiovascular and other comorbidities. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs), the main therapeutic agents, reduce synovitis and systemic inflammation and improve function. The leading DMARD is methotrexate, which can be combined with other drugs of this type. Biologic agents are used when arthritis is uncontrolled or toxic effects occur with DMARDs. Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors were the first biologic agents, followed by abatacept, rituximab, and tocilizumab. Infections and high costs limit the prescription of biological agents. Long-term remission induced by intensive, short-term treatment selected by biomarker profiles is the ultimate goal.

abstract: Recent insights into rheumatoid arthritis (RA) have prompted an update of the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) RA management recommendations. A large international task force based its decisions on evidence from 3 systematic literature reviews, developed 4 guiding principles and 12 recommendations (vs. 3 and 14, respectively, in 2013). Recommendations apply to conventional synthetic (cs) disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) (methotrexate (MTX), leflunomide, sulfasalazine); Glucocorticoids (GC); Biologic (b) DMARDs (tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegoli, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab), abatacept, rituximab, tocilizumab, sarilumab and sirukumab (targeted DM) ) DMARDs (Janus k Naza ( Jak) inhibitors tofacitinib, baricitinib). Monotherapy, combination therapy, treatment strategies (treatment-to-target), and targets of sustained clinical remission (as defined by American College of Rheumatology (ACR)-EULAR logical or index criteria) or low disease activity are discussed. Cost aspects were considered. As a first strategy, the task force recommends MTX (rapid escalation to 25 mg/week) plus short-term GC, with a goal of >50% improvement at 3 and goal at 6 months. If this fails, stratification is recommended. Without unfavorable prognostic markers, switching to or adding another csDMARD (plus short-term GC) is recommended. In the presence of unfavorable prognostic markers (autoantibodies, high disease activity, early erosion, failure of 2 csDMARDs), any bDMARD (current practice) or Jak-inhibitor should be added to the csDMARD. If this fails, any other bDMARD or tsDMARD is recommended. If the patient is in sustained remission, bDMARDs may be tapered. For each recommendation, the level of evidence and agreement of the working group are provided, both of which are generally very high. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national rheumatology societies, hospital officials, social care agencies, and regulators about the latest EULAR consensus on the management of RA aimed at achieving the best outcomes with current therapies.

abstract: This article updates the 2010 European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) recommendations for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with synthetic and biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (sDMARDs and bDMARDs, respectively). The 2013 update was developed by an international working group that based its decisions primarily on evidence from three systematic literature reviews (one each on sDMARDs, including glucocorticoids, bDMARDs, and safety aspects of DMARD therapy); Treatment strategies also included searches. Evidence presented was reviewed and summarized by experts in a consensus-building and voting process. Levels of evidence and grades of recommendations were obtained, and levels of agreement (strengths of recommendations) were determined. Fourteen recommendations were developed (instead of 15 in 2010). Some of the 2010 recommendations were deleted, and others were amended or split. Recommendations include general aspects such as achieving remission or low disease activity using a targeted approach and the need for shared decision-making between rheumatologists and patients. More specific points refer to the initiation of DMARD therapy using a conventional sDMARD (csDMARD) strategy with glucocorticoids, followed by the addition of a bDMARD or another csDMARD strategy (after stratification by the presence or absence of adverse risk factors) if the treatment goal is not reached within 6 months (or no improvement is observed in 3 months). Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab, biosimilars), abatacept, tocilizumab, and, in certain conditions, rituximab are considered to have essentially similar efficacy and safety. If the first bDMARD strategy fails, any other bDMARD can be used. The recommendations also refer to tofacitinib as a targeted sDMARD (tsDMARD), which is recommended, where licensed, after the use of at least one bDMARD. Biosimilars are also being considered. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national rheumatology societies, and other stakeholders about the latest EULAR consensus on the management of RA with sDMARDs, glucocorticoids, and bDMARDs. They are based on evidence and expert opinion and aim to improve outcomes in patients with RA.

abstract: Conventional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are associated with a spectrum of toxic effects, particularly gastrointestinal (GI) effects, due to cyclooxygenase (COX)-1 inhibition. Whether COX-2-specific inhibitors are associated with fewer clinical gastrointestinal toxicities is unknown. To determine whether celecoxib, a COX-2-specific inhibitor, is associated with a lower incidence of significant upper gastrointestinal toxicities and other adverse effects compared with conventional NSAIDs. The Celecoxib Long-term Arthritis Safety Study (CLASS), a double-blind, randomized controlled trial conducted from September 1998 to March 2000. Three hundred eighty-six clinical sites in the United States and Canada. A total of 8059 patients (>/=18 years) with osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA) were enrolled in the study, and 7968 received at least 1 dose of study drug. A total of 4573 patients (57%) received treatment within 6 months. Patients were randomized to celecoxib, 400 mg twice daily (2 and 4 times the maximum RA and OA doses, respectively; n = 3987); ibuprofen, 800 mg 3 times daily (n = 1985); or diclofenac, 75 mg twice daily (n = 1996). Aspirin was allowed to be used for cardiovascular prevention (</=325 mg/day). Prospectively determined incidence of symptomatic upper gastrointestinal ulcers and ulcer complications (bleeding, perforation and obstruction) and other adverse effects during a 6-month treatment period. For all patients, the annual rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and symptomatic ulcers with celecoxib and NSAIDs were 0.76% versus 1.45% (P =.09) and 2.08% versus 3.54% (P =.02). respectively. For patients not taking aspirin, the annual rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and combined symptomatic ulcers for celecoxib versus NSAIDs were 0.44% versus 1.27% ( P =.04) and 1.40% versus 2.91% ( P =.02) . For patients taking aspirin alone, the annual rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications and symptomatic ulcers with celecoxib and NSAIDs were 2.01% versus 2.12% ( P =.92) and 4.70% versus 6.00% ( P =.49). Fewer celecoxib-treated patients than NSAIDs-treated patients developed chronic gastrointestinal blood loss, gastrointestinal intolerance, hepatotoxicity, or renal toxicity. There was no difference in the rate of cardiovascular events between celecoxib and NSAIDs, regardless of aspirin use. In this study, celecoxib, at doses higher than clinically indicated, was associated with a lower incidence of symptomatic ulcers and ulcer complications combined, as well as other clinically important toxic effects, compared with standard-dose NSAIDs. The reduction in upper GI toxicity was strongest in patients not receiving concomitant aspirin. JAMA. 2000; 284: 1247-1255

abstract: Prostaglandin (PG)E2 is a potent mediator of pain and inflammation, and high levels of this lipid mediator are observed in many diseases. Inhibition of PGE2 production to control pain and treat diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis has so far relied on non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents such as aspirin. However, these agents inhibit the synthesis of all prostanoids. To produce biologically active PGE2, PGE synthases catalyze the isomerization of PGH2 to PGE2. Recently, several PGE synthases have been identified and cloned, but their role in inflammation is not clear. To investigate the physiological role of individual PGE synthases, we generated by targeted homologous recombination a mouse line deficient in microsomal PGE synthase 1 (mPGES1) in an inbred DBA/1lacJ background. mPGES1-deficient (mPGES1-/-) mice are viable and fertile and develop normally compared to wild-type controls. However, mPGES1-/- mice showed a marked reduction in inflammatory responses compared to mPGES1+/+ mice in multiple assays. Here, we identify mPGES1 as a PGE synthase that contributes to the pathogenesis of collagen-induced arthritis, a human rheumatoid arthritis disease model. We also show that mPGES1 is responsible for the production of PGE2, which mediates acute pain during the inflammatory response. These findings suggest that mPGES1 represents a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases and pain associated with inflammatory conditions.

abstract: To study the efficacy and safety of SC-58635 (celecoxib), an anti-inflammatory and analgesic agent that acts by selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) and is not expected to cause typical gastrointestinal (GI), renal, and platelet-related Associated side effects associated with COX-1 enzyme inhibition. Four phase II trials were conducted: a 2-week osteoarthritis efficacy trial, a 4-week rheumatoid arthritis efficacy trial, a 1-week endoscopic gastrointestinal study, and a 1-week platelet function study. 2 arthritis studies identified SC-58635 dosage levels that were consistently effective in treating the signs and symptoms of arthritis and differentiated from placebo on standard arthritis scales. In an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy study, 19% of subjects receiving naproxen (6 of 32) developed gastric ulcers, whereas no ulcers occurred in subjects receiving SC-58635 or placebo. A study of platelet effects revealed no significant effect of SC-58635 on platelet aggregation or thromboxane B2 levels, whereas aspirin produced a significant reduction in 2 of 3 platelet aggregation and thromboxane B2 levels. In all four studies, SC-58635 was well tolerated, with a safety profile similar to placebo. SC-58635 achieves analgesic and anti-inflammatory efficacy in arthritis through selective COX-2 inhibition without exhibiting the toxic effects of COX-1 inhibition 2 associated with NSAIDs.

abstract: Acid suppression with famotidine, a histamine H2-receptor antagonist, protects against gastric damage in normal subjects receiving short courses of aspirin or naproxen. The effectiveness of famotidine in the prevention of peptic ulcers in patients receiving long-term therapy with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is not known. We studied the efficacy of two doses of famotidine (20 mg and 40 mg, each orally twice daily) compared with placebo in the prevention of peptic ulcers in 285 patients not receiving long-term NSAIDs for rheumatoid arthritis. 82 percent) or osteoarthritis (18 percent). Patients were evaluated clinically and endoscopically at baseline and after 4, 12, and 24 weeks of treatment. Raters were unaware of treatment assignment. The primary endpoint was the cumulative incidence of gastric or duodenal ulcer at 24 weeks. The cumulative incidence of gastric ulcers was 20 percent in the placebo group, 13 percent in the group of patients receiving 20 mg of famotidine twice daily (P = 0.24 compared with placebo), and 8 percent in the group receiving 40 mg of famotidine. twice daily (P = 0.03 compared with placebo). The proportion of patients who developed a duodenal ulcer was significantly lower with both doses of famotidine than with placebo (13 percent in the placebo group, 4 percent in the low-dose famotidine group [P = 0.04], and 2 percent in the high-dose famotidine group [P = 0.01]). Both doses of famotidine were well tolerated. Treatment with high-dose famotidine significantly reduces the cumulative incidence of both gastric and duodenal ulcers in patients with arthritis receiving long-term nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory therapy.

abstract: Vitamin K antagonists are highly effective in preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, but have several limitations. Apixaban is a new oral direct factor Xa inhibitor that has been shown to reduce the risk of stroke compared to aspirin in a similar population. In this randomized, double-blind study, we compared apixaban (5 mg twice daily) with warfarin (target international normalized ratio, 2.0 to 3.0) in 18,201 patients with atrial fibrillation and at least one additional risk factor for stroke. The primary outcome was ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke or systemic embolism. The study was designed to test for non-inferiority, with key secondary endpoints testing superiority in relation to the primary outcome and rates of major bleeding and death from any cause. The mean duration of follow-up was 1.8 years. The primary outcome rate was 1.27% per year in the apixaban group compared with 1.60% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio with apixaban, 0.79; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.66 to 0.95; P<0.001 for noninferiority, P=0.01 for superiority). The incidence of major bleeding was 2.13% per year in the apixaban group compared with 3.09% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.60 to 0.80; P<0.001), and mortality rates for any cause was 3.52% and 3.94%, respectively (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.80 to 0.99; P=0.047). The incidence of hemorrhagic stroke was 0.24% per year in the apixaban group compared with 0.47% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.51; 95% CI, 0.35 to 0.75; P<0.001) and ischemic incidence. or unspecified type of stroke was 0.97% per year in the apixaban group and 1.05% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.74 to 1.13; P=0.42). In patients with atrial fibrillation, apixaban was superior to warfarin in preventing stroke or systemic embolism, caused less bleeding, and resulted in lower mortality. (Sponsored by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer; ARISTOTLE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00412984.).

abstract: Despite current treatment, patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes have a high rate of major vascular events. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of the antiplatelet agent clopidogrel when coadministered with aspirin in such patients. We randomized 12,562 patients who presented within 24 hours of symptom onset to clopidogrel (300 mg immediately, then 75 mg once daily) (6259 patients) or placebo (6303 patients) in addition to aspirin for 3 to 12 months. The first primary outcome—a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or stroke—occurred in 9.3 percent of patients in the clopidogrel group and 11.4 percent of patients in the placebo group (relative risk for clopidogrel versus placebo, 0.80; second primary outcome—first primary outcome or refractory ischemia occurred in 16.5 percent of patients in the clopidogrel group and 18.8 percent of patients in the placebo group (relative risk, 0.86; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.79-0.94 P<0.001). The percentage of patients with refractory or severe ischemia, heart failure, and revascularization procedures was significantly lower in the clopidogrel group than in the placebo group (3.7 percent vs. 2.7 percent; relative risk, 1.38; P= 0.001), but there were not significantly more patients with life-threatening bleeding episodes (2.2 percent [corrected] vs. 1.8 percent, P=0.13) or hemorrhagic stroke (0.1 percent vs. 0.1 percent). The antiplatelet agent clopidogrel has beneficial effects in patients with non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndromes. However, the risk of major bleeding is increased in patients treated with clopidogrel.

abstract: To determine the effect of antiplatelet therapy in patients at high risk of occlusive vascular events. Collaborative meta-analyses (systematic reviews). Randomized trials of antiplatelet regimens versus controls or one antiplatelet regimen versus another in patients at higher risk (with severe or previous vascular disease or other predisposing conditions) with results available up to September 1997. Studies had to use a randomisation method, excluded prior knowledge of the following treatment and comparisons had to be unblinded – that is, have study groups that differed only by antiplatelet regimen. 287 studies involving 135,000 patients comparing antiplatelet therapy versus controls and 77,000 comparing different antiplatelet regimens. "Serious vascular event": non-fatal myocardial infarction, non-fatal stroke or vascular death. Overall, allocation to antiplatelet therapy among these high-risk patients reduced the pooled outcome of any serious vascular event by approximately one-quarter; Non-fatal myocardial infarctions were reduced by one-third, non-fatal strokes by one-fourth, and vascular deaths by one-sixth (with no apparent adverse effect on other deaths). The absolute risk reduction of a major vascular event was 36 (SE 5) per 1000 treatments over two years in patients with previous myocardial infarction; 38 (5) per 1000 patients treated for one month in patients with acute myocardial infarction; 36 (6) per 1,000 treated within two years among those with a previous stroke or transient ischemic attack; 9 (3) per 1,000 treated within three weeks among persons with acute stroke; and 22 (3) per 1,000 treated over two years in other high-risk patients (separately significant results for stable angina pectoris (P=0.0005), peripheral arterial disease (P=0.004), and atrial fibrillation (P=0.01)). In each of these high-risk categories, the absolute benefit substantially outweighed the absolute risk of major extracranial hemorrhage. Aspirin has been the most widely studied antiplatelet drug, with doses of 75–150 mg daily at least as effective as higher daily doses. The effect of doses below 75 mg per day was less certain. Clopidogrel reduced serious vascular events by 10% (4%) compared with aspirin, which was similar to the 12% (7%) reduction seen with its analogue ticlopidine. The addition of dipyridamole to aspirin did not result in a significant further reduction in vascular events compared with aspirin alone. Among patients at high risk of immediate coronary occlusion, the short-term addition of a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa antagonist to aspirin prevented 20 (4) further vascular events per 1,000 (P<0.0001) but resulted in 23 major (but rarely fatal) extracranial hemorrhages. at 1000. Aspirin (or another oral antiplatelet drug) is protective in most patients at risk for occlusive vascular events, including those with acute myocardial infarction or ischemic stroke, unstable or stable angina pectoris, previous myocardial infarction, stroke, or cerebral ischemia. Peripheral arterial disease or atrial fibrillation. Low-dose aspirin (75-150 mg daily) is an effective antiplatelet regimen for long-term use, but in acute settings an initial loading dose of at least 150 mg aspirin may be required. Adding a second antiplatelet agent to aspirin may provide additional benefit in some clinical circumstances, but more research is needed on this strategy.

abstract: Many clinical trials have evaluated the benefit of long-term use of antiplatelet drugs to reduce the risk of clinical thrombotic events. Aspirin and ticlopidine are effective, but both have potentially serious side effects. Clopidogrel, a new thienopyridine derivative similar to ticlopidine, is an inhibitor of platelet aggregation induced by adenosine diphosphate. CAPRIE was a randomized, blinded, international trial designed to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of clopidogrel (75 mg once daily) and aspirin (325 mg once daily) in reducing the risk of the composite outcome of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. ; Their relative safety was also evaluated. The study population consisted of subgroups of patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease, manifested as recent ischemic stroke, recent myocardial infarction, or symptomatic peripheral arterial disease. Patients were observed from 1 to 3 years. 19,185 patients, over 6300 in each clinical subgroup, were recruited over 3 years, with a mean follow-up of 1.91 years. There were the first events from 1960 included in the outcome cluster, in which an intention-to-treat analysis showed that patients treated with clopidogrel had an annual risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death of 5.83% compared with aspirin. These figures reflect a statistically significant (p = 0.043) relative risk reduction of 8.7% in favor of clopidogrel (95% Cl 0.3-16.5). An on-treatment matched analysis yielded a relative risk reduction of 9.4%. There were no significant differences in terms of safety. Adverse events reported in the clopidogrel and aspirin groups that were graded as severe included rash (0.26% vs 0.10%), diarrhea (0.23% vs 0.11%), upper gastrointestinal discomfort (0.97% vs 1.22%), intracranial 3% vs . %) and gastrointestinal bleeding (0.52% vs 0.72%), respectively. There were ten (0.10%) patients with significant neutrophil reduction (< 1.2 x 10(9)/L) in the clopidogrel group and 16 (0.17%) in the aspirin group. In patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease, long-term administration of clopidogrel is more effective than aspirin in reducing the combined risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. The overall safety profile of clopidogrel is as good as that of medium-dose aspirin.

abstract: In the Western population, within the normal range of LDL cholesterol, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Thus, lowering LDL cholesterol in such populations may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely regardless of baseline cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40–80 years) with coronary artery disease, other occlusive arterial disease, or diabetes mellitus were randomized to simvastatin 40 mg daily (mean compliance: 85%) or matching placebo (mean off-study statin use: 17%. ). The analyzes are event-specific first-come, first-served and compare all simvastatin-allocated versus all placebo participants. This "intention-to-treat" comparison estimated the effect of approximately two-thirds (85% minus 17%) of taking statins during the planned 5-year treatment period resulting in a mean difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L. about two-thirds of the effect of actual use of simvastatin 40 mg per day). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subcategory analyses), with additional assessments of cancer and other major morbidities. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin-allocated vs 1,507 [14.7%] 10,267 placebo-allocated deaths; p=0.0003), with a highly significant 18% (SE 5) proportional reduction in coronary events. mortality (587 [5.7%] vs 707 [6.9%]; p=0.0005), marginally significant reduction in other vascular mortality (194 [1.9%] vs 230 [2.2%]; p=0.07) and non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality ( 547 [5.3%] vs 570 [5.6%]; p=0.4). There was a highly significant reduction of approximately one-quarter in the first event rate for non-fatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] vs 1212 [11.8%]; p<0.0001), non-fatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%] vs 585 [5.7%] ; p<0.0001) and for coronary or noncoronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a definite 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19–28) reduction in the event rate (2033 [19.8%] vs 2585 [25.2%] affected individuals; p < 0.0001). The reduction in major vascular events during the first year was not significant, but thereafter it was highly significant in each individual year. The proportional reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in each participant subcategory studied, including: those without a diagnosis of coronary artery disease, those with cerebrovascular disease, or those with peripheral artery disease, or those with diabetes; men and separate women; is less than 70 years old at the time of entry; And—most notably—even those who had LDL cholesterol below 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL) or total cholesterol below 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefit of simvastatin was additive to that of cardioprotective treatment. The annual excess risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or hospitalization for any other nonvascular cause. The addition of simvastatin to existing treatment safely provides significant additional benefit for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their baseline cholesterol concentration. Taking simvastatin 40 mg per day reduced the incidence of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for the discrepancy, the actual use of this regimen is likely to reduce these figures by about one-third. Therefore, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, 5 years of simvastatin would prevent approximately 70-100 of 1,000 people from experiencing at least one of these major vascular events (and longer-term treatment should provide further benefit). The size of the 5-year benefit mainly depends on such individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not just their blood lipid concentrations.

abstract: Statin therapy reduces low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels and the risk of cardiovascular events, but adding ezetimibe, a non-statin drug that reduces intestinal cholesterol absorption, may further reduce the incidence of cardiovascular events. We conducted a double-blind, randomized trial of 18,144 patients who had been hospitalized for an acute coronary syndrome within the previous 10 days and had an LDL cholesterol level of 50 to 100 mg per deciliter (1.3 to 2.6 mmol/liter). , if they were receiving. Lipid-lowering therapy or 50 to 125 mg per deciliter (1.3 to 3.2 mmol per liter) if they were not receiving lipid-lowering therapy. The combination of simvastatin (40 mg) and ezetimibe (10 mg) (simvastatin-ezetimibe) was compared with simvastatin (40 mg) and placebo (simvastatin monotherapy). The primary endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, unstable angina requiring rehospitalization, coronary revascularization (≥30 days after randomization), or nonfatal stroke. The median follow-up period was 6 years. The time-weighted mean LDL cholesterol level during the study was 53.7 mg/dL (1.4 mmol/L) in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group, compared with 69.5 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L) in the simvastatin-monotherapy group. P<0.001). The Kaplan-Meier event rate for the primary endpoint at 7 years was 32.7% in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group compared with 34.7% in the simvastatin-monotherapy group (absolute risk difference, 2.0 percentage points; hazard ratio, 0.936; 95% confidence interval, 0.89 to 0.99 to P=0.016). The rates of prespecified muscle, gallbladder, and liver side effects and cancer were similar in the two groups. When added to statin therapy, ezetimibe resulted in gradual reductions in LDL cholesterol levels and improved cardiovascular outcomes. Moreover, lowering LDL cholesterol to levels below previous targets provided additional benefit. (Sponsored by Merck; IMPROVE-IT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00202878.).

abstract: Individuals with diabetes have an increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, although their plasma LDL cholesterol concentrations are generally similar to those of the general population. Previous evidence for cholesterol-lowering effects in people with diabetes has been limited, and most people with diabetes currently do not receive cholesterol-lowering therapy despite their increased risk. 5,963 UK adults (aged 40–80 years) with known diabetes and an additional 14,573 with occlusive arterial disease (but no diagnosed diabetes) were randomly assigned to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily or matching placebo. Prespecified analyzes in these prior disease subcategories and other relevant subcategories were first major coronary event (ie, nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death) and first major vascular event (ie, major coronary event, stroke, or revascularization). Analyzes of subsequent vascular events during the planned treatment period were also performed. Comparisons are made with all participants allocated to simvastatin (ie, intention-to-treat) who showed a mean difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL) over the 5-year treatment period. Among both participants who had diabetes and those who did not, there was a highly significant reduction of about a quarter in first event rates for major coronary events, stroke, and revascularization. For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events among participants with diabetes, there was a 22% (95% CI 13–30) reduction in event rates (601 [20.2%] simvastatin-allocated vs 748 [25.1%] placebo-allocated, p<0.0001), which was similar to was among other high-risk individuals studied. There was also a highly significant reduction of 33% (95% CI 17-46, p=0.0003) among the 2912 diabetic participants not diagnosed with occlusive arterial disease at entry and 27% (95% CI 13-40, p=0.0007 ) among 2,426 diabetic participants with pretreatment LDL cholesterol concentrations below 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL). The proportional reduction in risk was also about one-fourth among other subcategories of diabetes studied, including: those with different durations, types, or controls of diabetes; persons older than 65 years at the entrance or with hypertension; and those with total cholesterol below 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). In addition, among participants who had a first major vascular event after randomization, simvastatin allocation reduced the rate of subsequent events during the planned treatment period. The present study provides direct evidence that cholesterol-lowering therapy is beneficial for people with diabetes, even if they do not already have overt coronary disease or high cholesterol. Taking simvastatin 40 mg daily reduced the frequency of first major vascular events by about a quarter in a wide range of diabetic patients studied. After allowing for noncompliance, actual use of this statin regimen would likely reduce these rates by approximately one-third. For example, among patients with diabetes without occlusive arterial disease studied, 5 years of treatment would be expected to prevent at least one major vascular event in about 45 per 1,000 people (and, among those 45 people, prevent about 70 or more events after that treatment period). Statin therapy should now be routinely considered for all diabetic patients at sufficiently high risk of major vascular events, regardless of their baseline cholesterol concentration.

abstract: In patients with established cardiovascular disease, residual cardiovascular risk persists despite achieving target low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels with statin therapy. It is unclear whether extended-release niacin added to simvastatin is more effective in lowering high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol than simvastatin alone in reducing this residual risk. We randomly assigned eligible patients to receive extended-release niacin, 1500 to 2000 mg daily, or a matching placebo. All patients received simvastatin, 40 to 80 mg daily, plus ezetimibe, 10 mg daily, as needed, to maintain LDL cholesterol levels between 40 and 80 mg per deciliter (1.03 to 2.07 mmol per liter). . The primary endpoint was the first event of coronary heart disease, nonfatal myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, hospitalization for acute coronary syndrome, or death from symptomatic coronary or cerebral revascularization. A total of 3414 patients were assigned to receive niacin (1718) or placebo (1696). The study was discontinued after a median follow-up of 3 years due to lack of efficacy. Over 2 years, niacin therapy significantly increased median HDL cholesterol from 35 mg/dL (0.91 mmol/L) to 42 mg/dL (1.08 mmol/L), reduced triglyceride levels to 164 mg/dL (1.85 mmol/L /l). liter) to 122 mg per deciliter (1.38 mmol per liter) and reduced LDL cholesterol levels from 74 mg/deciliter (1.91 mmol per liter) to 62 mg/deciliter (1.60 mmol per liter). The primary endpoint occurred in 282 patients in the niacin group (16.4%) and in 274 patients in the placebo group (16.2%) (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval, 0.87 to 1.21; P=0.79 log-rank test). Among patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and LDL cholesterol levels of less than 70 mg per deciliter (1.81 mmol per liter), there was no additional clinical benefit of statin supplementation with niacin over a 36-month follow-up period, although significant. Improving HDL cholesterol and triglyceride levels. (Sponsored by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and Abbott Laboratories; AIM-HIGH ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00120289.).

abstract: Lower blood cholesterol concentrations are consistently associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease, but not a lower risk of stroke. Despite this observation, previous randomized trials showed that cholesterol-lowering statin therapy reduced the risk of stroke, but large-scale prospective confirmation was needed. 3,280 adults with cerebrovascular disease and an additional 17,256 with other occlusive arterial disease or diabetes were randomly assigned to simvastatin 40 mg daily or matching placebo. Subgroup analyzes were prespecified within subcategories of the first “major vascular event” (ie, nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death, any type of stroke, or any revascularization procedure). Secondary outcomes included any stroke and stroke subtypes. Comparisons are made with all simvastatin-allocated participants (ie, “intention-to-treat”) who showed a mean difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL) over 5 years of treatment. period. Overall, there was a highly significant 25% (95% CI 15–34) proportional reduction in the incidence of a first stroke event (444 [4.3%] simvastatin versus 585 [5.7%] placebo; p<0.0001), reflecting a certain 28 . % (19-37) reduction in probable ischemic strokes (p<0.0001) and no apparent difference in strokes attributable to bleeding (51 [0.5%] vs 53 [0.5%]; incidence ratio 0.95 [0.65-1.40]; p=0.8 ). In addition, simvastatin reduced the numbers with only transient ischemic attacks (2.0% vs 2.4%; p=0.02) or requiring carotid endarterectomy or angioplasty (0.4% vs 0.8%; p=0.0003). The reduction in stroke was not significant during the first year, but was significant (p=0.0004) at the end of the second year. Among patients with pre-existing cerebrovascular disease, there was no clear reduction in the incidence of stroke, but there was a highly significant 20% (8-29) reduction in the incidence of any major vascular event (406 [24.7%] vs 488 [29.8%]; p=0.001) . The proportional reduction in stroke was about one-quarter in each of the other subcategories of participants studied, including: those with coronary heart disease or diabetes; Persons over 70 years of age at entry; and those with varying levels of blood pressure or lipids (even when pretreatment LDL cholesterol was below 3.0 mmol/L [116 mg/dL]). A much larger number of people had a stroke in the present study than in any previous cholesterol-lowering study. The results show that statin therapy rapidly reduces the incidence of not only coronary events but also ischemic stroke, without any apparent effect on cerebral hemorrhage, even in individuals without high cholesterol concentrations. The distribution of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the incidence of ischemic strokes by approximately one-quarter, and so, after accounting for study inconsistencies, the actual use of this regimen is likely to reduce the incidence of stroke by approximately one-third. The HPS also provides definitive evidence that statin therapy is beneficial in people with pre-existing cerebrovascular disease, even if they do not already have overt coronary disease.

abstract: Previous studies have shown that experimental hypercholesterolemia induces neovascularization in the vasa vasorum (VV) of the coronary artery. Recent evidence suggests that HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins) have beneficial effects independent of lipid lowering. We aimed to determine the effect of simvastatin on coronary VV neovascularization in the absence of cholesterol lowering. Pigs were randomized into 3 groups fed a normal (N), high cholesterol (HC) or HC+simvastatin (HC+S) diet for 12 weeks. The proximal left anterior descending artery was isolated, micro-CT scanned, and reconstructed. Quantification of VV density in serial sections along the vessel was then performed. LDL cholesterol was similarly increased in HC and HC+S compared to N. There was an increase in both VV density (4.7+/-0.3 vs. 2.7+/-0.2 n/mm(2); P<0.05) and vessel wall area. (3.1+/-0.2 vs. 1.8+/-0.1 mm(2); P<0.05) in HC compared to N. VV density was maintained in HC+S compared to HC (3.0+/-0.2 n/mm(2 P<0.05), despite a similar increase in vessel wall area compared to N (2.5+/-0.1 mm(2); P<0.05) Coronary artery tissue expression of VEGF was increased in HC but not in HC+S compared with N. In parallel, immunoreactivity of HIF-1alpha, VEGF, and MMP-9 was highlighted in the external media. , but not compared to HC+S N. This study demonstrates that simvastatin attenuates coronary artery wall hypoxia and VV neovascularization in experimental hypercholesterolemia. These data are consistent with an additional mechanism of vascular effects of statins independent of cholesterol lowering.

abstract: Simvastatin attenuates ischemia and reperfusion in normocholesterolemic animals by stabilizing endothelial nitric oxide synthase activity and inhibiting neutrophil-mediated injury. Because endothelial dysfunction is a detrimental effect of hypercholesterolemia, we investigated whether short-term simvastatin treatment could inhibit leukocyte-endothelial interactions and attenuate myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury in apoE-deficient (apoE(-/-)) mice fed a high-cholesterol diet. diet. We studied leukocyte-endothelial interactions in apoE(-/-) mice fed either a normal or high-cholesterol diet after short-term (ie, 18 hours) treatment with simvastatin. We also studied simvastatin treatment of myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury in apoE(-/-) mice by impairing 30 min ischemia and 24 h reperfusion. ApoE(-/-) mice fed a high-cholesterol diet showed higher blood cholesterol levels that were not affected by short-term simvastatin treatment. However, the increased leukocyte rolling and adhesion observed in cholesterol-fed apoE(-/-) mice (P<0.001 vs. control diet) was significantly attenuated by simvastatin treatment (P<0.01 vs. vehicle). Cholesterol-fed apoE(-/-) mice subjected to myocardial ischemia-reperfusion also showed increased myocardial necrosis (P<0.01 vs. control diet), which was significantly reduced by simvastatin (P<0.01 vs. vehicle). Simvastatin therapy also significantly increased vascular nitric oxide production in apoE(-/-) mice. Simvastatin attenuates leukocyte-endothelial cell interactions and ameliorates ischemic injury in hypercholesterolemic mice independent of lipid-lowering effects.

abstract: From a physiological point of view, physical activity is expected to reduce the risk of stroke. However, epidemiological studies of physical activity and stroke risk have produced mixed findings. We therefore sought to examine the relationship between exercise and stroke risk. This was a prospective cohort study of 21,823 men followed for an average of 11.1 years. Participants were from the Physicians' Health Study, a randomized trial of low-dose aspirin and beta-carotene. At baseline, men aged 40 to 84 years were free of self-reported myocardial infarction, stroke, transient ischemic attack, and cancer. At baseline, they reported a frequency of vigorous enough exercise to produce a sweat. The occurrence of stroke was self-reported by participants and verified after medical record review (n=533). We used Cox proportional hazards regression to analyze the data. Adjusted for age, treatment prescription, smoking, alcohol intake, history of angina pectoris, and parental history of myocardial infarction, relative risk of total stroke associated with vigorous exercise <1 time, 1 time, 2 to 4 times, and >/= 5 times per week Times at baseline were 1.00 (referent), 0.79 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.61 to 1.03), 0.80 (95% CI, 0.65 to 0.99), and 0.79 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.03). ), respectively; P for trend=0.04. In subgroup analysis, the inverse association was stronger with hemorrhagic than with ischemic stroke. In additional adjustment for history of body mass index, hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes mellitus, the corresponding relative risk for total stroke was 1.00 (referent), 0.81 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.07), 0.88 (95% CI, 0.70). 1.10) and 0.86 (95% CI, 0.65 to 1.13), respectively; P for trend=0.25. Exercising vigorously enough to produce sweat is associated with a lower risk of stroke in men. In the present study, the inverse association with physical activity was mediated by beneficial effects on body weight, blood pressure, serum cholesterol, and glucose tolerance. Apart from its beneficial effect on these variables, physical activity had no significant residual association with stroke incidence.

abstract: The beneficial effects of statins in preventing cardiovascular events may depend, at least in part, on their anti-inflammatory effects. The aim of the study was to evaluate the effect of simvastatin and aspirin on serum C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels in hypercholesterolemic subjects. 33 asymptomatic men with total cholesterol (TC) >6.5 mmol L(-1) and 25 men with coronary heart disease and borderline high cholesterol (between 5.2 and 6.5 mmol L(-1)) were chronically treated with a low dose. Serum levels of aspirin (75 mg/day), CRP, TNF-alpha, IL-6, and IL-8 were determined before and after 3 months of simvastatin therapy (20-40 mg daily). In the former group, these markers of inflammation were also measured before and after 2 weeks of aspirin treatment (300 mg/day) administered before and in combination with simvastatin. A clear decrease in CRP and TNF-alpha was observed in both groups; IL-6 levels were reduced only in subjects with marked hypercholesterolemia. Aspirin had no effect on the anti-inflammatory effect of simvastatin. Treatment with simvastatin reduces serum CRP and proinflammatory cytokines in men with hypercholesterolemia. Low-dose aspirin does not enhance the anti-inflammatory effects of simvastatin.

abstract: Previous studies of diet and coronary heart disease (CHD) have focused on nutrient intake rather than whole foods. Because dietary fiber, folate, and antioxidants may be protective against CHD, increasing vegetables is recommended. However, due to the chemical and physical complexity of vegetables, the effects of individual nutrients may differ when eaten whole. Moreover, little is known about the direct association between vegetable intake and CHD risk. We prospectively evaluated the association between vegetable intake and risk of CHD in the Physicians' Health Study, a randomized trial of aspirin and beta-carotene among 22,071 US male physicians aged 40–84 years in 1982. without heart disease, stroke or cancer at baseline who reported vegetable intake at baseline and at years 2, 4 and 6 using a simple semi-quantitative food frequency questionnaire including eight vegetables. We confirmed 1148 incident cases of CHD (387 cases of myocardial infarction and 761 cases of coronary artery bypass grafting or percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty) during 12 years of follow-up. After adjusting for age, randomized treatment, body mass index (BMI), smoking, alcohol intake, physical activity, history of diabetes, history of hypertension, history of high cholesterol, and multivitamin use, men who consumed at least 2.5 servings of vegetables per day had a relative risk ( RR) 0.77 (95% CI: 0.60–0.98) for CHD compared with men in the low category (<1 serving/day). In an overall trend analysis adjusting for the same covariates that considered vegetable intake as a continuous variable, we found a RR of 0.83 (95% CI: 0.71–0.98) for CHD risk for each additional serving/day of vegetables. The inverse association between vegetable intake and CHD risk was more pronounced in men with a BMI > or =25 (RR = 0.71, 95% CI: 0.51–0.99) or current smokers (RR = 0.40, 95% CI: 0.18–0.86) compared with higher and lower category acceptance. Our results suggest an inverse association between vegetable intake and CHD risk. These prospective data support current dietary guidelines to increase vegetable intake for CHD prevention.

abstract: The homeless are an extremely vulnerable group in North America. Among older homeless men, cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death. The purpose of this study was to examine cardiovascular risk factors in a representative sample of homeless adults and to identify opportunities for improved risk factor modification. Homeless individuals were randomly selected from shelters for single adults in Toronto. The response rate was 79%. Participants (n=202) underwent an interview, physical measurements, and blood sampling. The average age of the participants was 42 years, and 89% were male. The prevalence of smoking among homeless subjects (78%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 72% to 84%) was significantly higher than that in the general population (standardized incidence ratio [SMR], 254; 95% CI, 216 to 297 . ). Hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes were no more common than in the general population, but were often poorly controlled. Homeless men were significantly less likely to be overweight or obese than men in the general population (SMR, 79; 95% CI, 63 to 98). Cocaine use in the past year was reported by 29% of subjects (95% CI, 23% - 36%). CVD occurred in 15% of subjects, less than one-third of whom reported taking aspirin or cholesterol-lowering medications. Based on multiple risk factor equations, the estimated mean 10-year absolute risk of myocardial infarction or coronary death among homeless men aged 30 to 74 years was 5% (interquartile range, 3% to 9%). Modification of cardiovascular risk factors is suboptimal among homeless adults in Toronto despite universal health insurance. Many risk factor equations may underestimate the true risk in this population due to inadequate accounting for factors such as cocaine use and heavy smoking.

abstract: Rivaroxaban, an oral factor Xa inhibitor, can provide a simple, fixed-dose regimen for the treatment and continuation of treatment of acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) without the need for laboratory monitoring. We conducted an open-label, randomized, event-driven, noninferiority trial comparing oral rivaroxaban alone (15 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 20 mg once daily) with subcutaneous enoxaparin followed by a vitamin K antagonist (warfarin or acenocoumarol) 3, 6 or 12 months in patients with acute, symptomatic DVT. In parallel, we conducted a double-blind, randomized, event-driven superiority trial comparing rivaroxaban alone (20 mg once daily) with placebo for an additional 6 or 12 months in patients who had completed 6 to 12 months of treatment for venous insufficiency. Thromboembolism. The primary efficacy outcome in both studies was recurrent venous thromboembolism. The primary safety outcome was major bleeding or clinically important nonserious bleeding in the initial treatment study and major bleeding in the extension study. A study of rivaroxaban for acute DVT included 3,449 patients: 1,731 were given rivaroxaban and 1,718 received enoxaparin plus a vitamin K antagonist. Rivaroxaban was noninferior to the primary outcome (36 events [2.1%], 51 events with enoxaparin-vitamin K antagonist [3.0%]; hazard ratio, 0.68; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.44; up to 1. P<0.001) . The primary safety outcome was observed in 8.1% of patients in each group. In a continuous treatment study that included 602 patients in the rivaroxaban group and 594 in the placebo group, rivaroxaban had superior efficacy (8 events [1.3%], compared with 42 with placebo [7.1%]; hazard ratio, 0.18; 95% CI, 0.09 to 0.39 to P<0.001). Four patients in the rivaroxaban group had nonfatal major bleeding (0.7%), compared to none in the placebo group (P=0.11). Rivaroxaban offers a simple, single-drug approach to the short-term and continuous treatment of venous thrombosis that may improve the benefit-risk profile of anticoagulation. (Sponsored by Bayer Schering Pharma and Ortho-McNeil; ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00440193 and NCT00439725.).

abstract: Whether the oral factor Xa inhibitor edoxaban can be an alternative to warfarin in patients with venous thromboembolism is unclear. In a randomized, double-blind, noninferiority study, we randomized patients with acute venous thromboembolism initially on heparin to receive edoxaban 60 mg once daily or 30 mg once daily (eg, in patients with a creatinine clearance of 30 to 50 mL per minute or a body weighing less than 60 kg), or taking warfarin. Patients received the study drug for 3 to 12 months. The primary efficacy outcome was recurrent symptomatic venous thromboembolism. The primary safety outcome was major or clinically important non-major bleeding. A total of 4,921 patients had deep vein thrombosis, and 3,319 had pulmonary embolism. Among patients receiving warfarin, time in the therapeutic range was 63.5%. Edoxaban was noninferior to warfarin for the primary efficacy outcome, which occurred in 130 patients in the edoxaban group (3.2%) and 146 patients in the warfarin group (3.5%) (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.70 to 1.13 to; the safety outcome was observed in 349 patients (8.5%) in the edoxaban group and in 423 patients (10.3%) in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.71 to 0.94); other adverse event rates were similar A total of 938 patients with pulmonary embolism had right ventricular dysfunction as assessed by N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide levels; the rate of recurrent venous thromboembolism in this subgroup was 3.3% in the edoxaban group and 6.2% in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.52; 95 (% CI, 0.28 to 0.98).After initial heparin treatment, edoxaban administered once daily was noninferior to standard therapy and resulted in significantly less bleeding in a wide range of patients with venous thromboembolism, including those with severe pulmonary embolism. (Funded by Daiichi-Sankyo; Hokusai-VTE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00986154.).

abstract: Patients with acute proximal deep vein thrombosis are usually first treated in the hospital with intravenous standard (unfractionated) heparin. However, the longer plasma half-life, better bioavailability after subcutaneous administration, and more predictable anticoagulant response of low-molecular-weight heparins make them attractive for possible home use. We compared these two approaches. Patients with acute proximal deep vein thrombosis were randomized to receive either intravenous standard heparin in the hospital (253 patients) or low-molecular-weight heparin (1 mg enoxaparin per 1 kg body weight subcutaneously twice daily) mostly at home. 247 patients). The study design allowed outpatients receiving low molecular weight heparin to go home immediately and hospitalized patients receiving low molecular weight heparin to be discharged early. All patients received warfarin from the second day. Thirteen of 247 patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin (5.3 percent) had recurrent thromboembolism, compared with 17 of 253 patients receiving standard heparin (6.7 percent; P=0.57; absolute difference, 1.4 percent point; 95 percent confidence interval , -3.0 to 5.7). Five patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin had major bleeding, compared with three patients receiving standard heparin. After randomization, patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin spent an average of 1.1 days in the hospital, compared with 6.5 days in the standard heparin group; 120 patients in the low molecular weight heparin group did not require hospitalization at all. Low molecular weight heparin can be used safely and effectively at home in patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis.

abstract: Prevention of deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients remains underutilized. We hypothesized that the use of a computerized alert program to encourage prevention might reduce the incidence of deep vein thrombosis in high-risk hospitalized patients. We developed a computer program linked to a patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk of deep vein thrombosis in the absence of prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1,255 eligible patients to an intervention group in which the attending physician was warned about the patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis, and 1,251 patients to a control group in which no warning was given. The physician was required to acknowledge the warning and then could stop or order prophylaxis, including graduated compression stockings, pneumatic compression boots, unfractionated heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively proven deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism within 90 days. More patients in the intervention group received mechanical prophylaxis (10.0 percent vs. 1.5 percent, P<0.001) or pharmacologic prophylaxis (23.6 percent vs. 13.0 percent, P<0.001). The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9 percent) in the intervention group compared with 103 (8.2 percent) in the control group; Kaplan-Meier estimates of the probability of being free from deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days were 94.1 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 92.5 to 95.4 percent) and 90.6 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 88.7 to 92.2 percent), respectively (P< 0.001). Computer alerts reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism within 90 days by 41 percent (hazard ratio, 0.59; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81; P=0.001). The institution of a computerized alerting program increased the use of prophylaxis by physicians and markedly reduced the incidence of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in at-risk hospitalized patients.

abstract: Whether closure of the foramen ovale reduces the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke in patients who have had cryptogenic ischemic stroke is unknown. In a multicenter, randomized, open-label trial, blinded to endpoint events, we randomized patients aged 18 to 60 years with a patent foramen ovale (PFO) and cryptogenic ischemic stroke. PFO (PFO closure group) or receiving only medical therapy (aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, or aspirin with extended-release dipyridamole; medical-therapy group). The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of recurrent nonfatal ischemic stroke, fatal ischemic stroke, or early death after randomization. The results of the primary outcome analysis of the primary trial have been previously reported; The current analysis of data from an extended follow-up period was considered exploratory. We enrolled 980 patients (mean age, 45.9 years) at 69 sites. Patients were observed for an average of 5.9 years. Treatment exposure was unequal in the two groups (3141 patient-years in the PFO closure group vs. 2669 patient-years in the medical-therapy group), due to a higher dropout rate in the medical-therapy group. In the treatment-intent population, recurrent ischemic stroke occurred in 18 patients in the PFO closure group and 28 patients in the medical-therapy group, resulting in an incidence of 0.58 events per 100 patient-years and 1.07 events per 100 patient-years. years, respectively (hazard ratio with PFO closure versus medical therapy, 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.31 to 0.999; P=0.046 by log-rank test). Recurrent ischemic stroke of unknown cause occurred in 10 patients in the PFO closure group and 23 patients in the medical-therapy group (hazard ratio, 0.38; 95% CI, 0.18 to 0.79; P=0.007). Venous thromboembolism (which included pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis events) was more common in the PFO closure group than in the medical-therapy group. In adults with cryptogenic ischemic stroke, PFO closure was associated with a lower rate of recurrent ischemic stroke than medical therapy alone during long-term follow-up. (Sponsored by St. Jude Medical; RESPECT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00465270 .).

abstract: Individuals with transient ischemic attack and ischemic stroke have a high risk of recurrent stroke and death. Although acetylsalicylic acid (ASA, aspirin) has been proven and accepted as standard therapy in these patients, recent studies have shown that the combination of ASA and dipyridamole (DP) or clopidogrel may be superior to ASA. Blocking the renin-angiotensin system with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers may also reduce recurrent stroke. The ongoing PROFESS (Prevention Regimen for Effective Prevention of Second Stroke) trial was designed to assess whether ASA + extended-release DP compared with clopidogrel, and whether telmisartan reduces the risk of further stroke in individuals post-stroke in addition to usual care. PROFESS is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind trial involving 695 sites from 35 countries or regions. Patients > or = > 50 years with ischemic stroke < 120 days who were stable were randomized. The primary outcome of the study is recurrent stroke, using a pre-event analysis. The most important secondary outcome is a composite of stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. Other secondary outcomes include this composite + congestive heart failure, new-onset diabetes, other designated occlusive vascular events (pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, peripheral artery occlusion, transient ischemic attack, cerebral venous thrombosis, or retinal vascular accident not classified as stroke ). , any death, stroke subtype by TOAST criteria, and Mini Mental State Examination score. Safety is assessed by assessing the risk of major hemorrhagic events. The comparison between ASA + DP and clopidogrel is based on an initial assessment of non-inferiority followed by an assessment of superiority, while for telmisartan we will assess its superiority over placebo. Randomized with more than 20,000 patients and using a 2 x 2 factorial design, PROFESS is the largest stroke study to examine the prevention of recurrent stroke. The mean age was 66.1 +/- 8.6 years and 36.0% of patients were female. The median time from qualifying event to randomization was 15 days, with 39.9% of patients randomized within 10 days. According to TOAST criteria, 28.5% of strokes were caused by large vessel disease, 52.1% by small vessel disease, 1.8% by cardioembolism, and 2.0% by other defined etiology, and 15.5% were of unknown etiology. PROFESS is the largest secondary stroke prevention trial to date and will directly compare the two antiplatelet regimens as well as the benefit of telmisartan versus placebo.

abstract: The risk of bleeding complications during and after early hip fracture surgery in patients receiving clopidogrel and other anticoagulants has not been determined. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the risks of perioperative bleeding and clinical outcome after early hip fracture surgery in patients receiving clopidogrel (Plavix) and other oral anticoagulants. The study design is a retrospective cohort analysis using data extracted from hospital records and state death records. Regional Medical Center (level II trauma). Data for 1,118 patients aged ≥60 years who underwent surgical treatment for hip fracture between 2004 and 2008 were reviewed. Ninety-two patients undergoing late surgery (>3 days after admission) were excluded. Patients taking clopidogrel were compared with patients not taking clopidogrel. In addition, patients receiving clopidogrel alone were compared with cohorts of patients receiving both clopidogrel and aspirin, aspirin alone, warfarin alone, or no anticoagulant. Of the 1036 patients, 74 (7%) were receiving clopidogrel, although the control group included 253 patients on aspirin alone, 90 patients on warfarin, and 619 on no anticoagulants. No significant differences were noted between patients receiving clopidogrel and those not receiving clopidogrel in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirement, final blood count, hematoma evacuation, length of hospital stay (LOS), or in-hospital or 1-year mortality. A higher American Society of Anesthesiologists score was observed in the clopidogrel and warfarin groups (P = 0.05 each), increased LOS in the clopidogrel group (P = 0.05), and a higher incidence of deep vein thrombosis in patients receiving warfarin (P = 0.05). Clopidogrel versus aspirin alone versus aspirin and clopidogrel without anticoagulant versus warfarin showed no significant differences in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirement, final blood count, bleeding, or perioperative complications or mortality. Patients undergoing early hip fracture surgery receiving clopidogrel, aspirin, or warfarin (adjusted by international normalized ratio) are not at substantially increased risk of bleeding, bleeding complications, or mortality. Comorbidities and American Society of Anesthesiologists scores were significantly higher in the clopidogrel group, which may have resulted in increased postoperative LOS in this group.

abstract: Several new anticoagulants are in clinical development. Recently two of them, Dabigatran etexilate/Pradaxa. and Rivaroxaban/Xarelto have received marketing authorization in Europe and Canada for the prevention of thromboembolic events after major orthopedic surgery such as total hip and knee replacement. The results of phase III clinical trials in thromboprophylaxis in major orthopedic surgery are highlighted and discussed in detail. Ongoing phase II and III clinical trials are evaluating their efficacy in the secondary prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and in the long-term prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation and in combination with aspirin and clopidogrel. with acute coronary syndromes. Many other small antithrombotic molecules, including new generation low molecular weight heparins, are currently in various stages of clinical development. Except for oral administration, newer anticoagulants have a more balanced benefit/risk ratio and a wider therapeutic window. They have a rapid onset of action, a predictable anticoagulant effect that does not require routine laboratory monitoring. They have few food and drug interactions, including cytochrome P450 and P.gp. They are highly specific and target a single coagulation factor and may have similar or lower bleeding risks compared to older anticoagulants. Finally, they can be used in a wider range of patients, especially cancer patients and the elderly without dose adjustment, regardless of patient age, sex, body weight or mild renal impairment. Their use in the general world will hopefully confirm the promising results of clinical trials.

abstract: Allopurinol, a commonly prescribed drug for gout and hyperuricemia, is a common cause of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCAR), including drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis. Adverse events are unpredictable and cause significant morbidity and mortality. We performed a case-control association study to identify genetic markers for allopurinol-SCAR. We enrolled 51 patients with allopurinol-SCAR and 228 control individuals (135 allopurinol-tolerant subjects and 93 healthy subjects from the general population) and genotyped 823 SNPs in genes associated with drug metabolism and immune response. Initial screening revealed a strong association between allopurinol-SCAR and SNPs in the MHC region, including BAT3 (encoding HLA-B associated transcript 3), MSH5 (mutS homologue 5), and MICB (MHC class I polypeptide-related B sequence) (P < 10(-7)). We then determined the HLA loci A, B, C and DRB1 alleles. The HLA-B*5801 allele was present in all (100%) of the 51 patients with allopurinol-SCAR, but only in 20 (15%) of the 135 tolerant patients [odds ratio 580.3 (95% confidence interval, 34.4-9780.9); adjusted P value = 4.7 x 10(-24)] and 19 (20%) of 93 healthy subjects [393.51 (23.23-6665.26); Adjusted P value = 8.1 x 10(-18)]. HLA alleles A*3303, Cw*0302 and DRB1*0301 were in linkage disequilibrium and formed an extended haplotype with HLA-B*5801. Our results showed that allopurinol-SCAR is strongly associated with genetic susceptibility in Han Chinese. In particular, the HLA-B*5801 allele is an important genetic risk factor for this life-threatening condition.

abstract: Developing evidence-based recommendations for the management of gout. The multidisciplinary guideline development group consisted of 19 rheumatologists and one evidence-based medicine expert representing 13 European countries. Key management propositions were developed using a Delphi consensus approach. Research evidence was systematically sought for each proposal. When possible, effect size (ES), number needed to treat, relative risk, odds ratio, and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio were calculated. The quality of evidence was divided into levels of evidence. Strength of recommendation (SOR) was assessed using the EULAR visual analog and ordinal scale. After three rounds of Delphi, 12 main propositions were generated. Suggestions included both nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments and focused on symptomatic control of acute gout, urate-lowering therapy (ULT), and prevention of acute attacks. The importance of patient education, adverse lifestyle modification (weight loss if obese; reduced alcohol consumption; low animal purine diet) and treatment of associated comorbidities and risk factors were emphasized. The recommended medications for acute attacks were oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral colchicine (ES = 0.87 (95% confidence interval, 0.25 to 1.50)), or combined aspiration and corticosteroid injection. ULT is indicated in patients with recurrent acute attacks, arthropathy, tophi, or radiographic changes in gout. Allopurinol proved to be an effective long-term ULT (ES = 1.39 (0.78 to 2.01)). If allopurinol toxicity occurs, options include other xanthine oxidase inhibitors, allopurinol desensitization, or uricosamine. Uricose benzbromarone is more effective than allopurinol (ES = 1.50 (0.76 to 2.24)) and can be used in patients with mild to moderate renal impairment, but may be hepatotoxic. When gout is associated with the use of diuretics, diuretics should be discontinued if possible. For the prevention of acute attacks, either colchicine 0.5-1 mg per day or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (with gastroprotection if indicated) are recommended. 12 key recommendations for the management of gout have been developed using a combination of research-based evidence and expert consensus. The evidence was evaluated and an SOR was provided for each proposal.

abstract: Febuxostat, a novel non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is a potential alternative to allopurinol for patients with hyperuricemia and gout. We randomized 762 patients with gout and a serum urate concentration of at least 8.0 mg per deciliter (480 micromol per liter) to receive febuxostat (80 mg or 120 mg) or allopurinol (300 mg) once daily for 52 weeks; 760 received study drug. Gout flare prophylaxis with naproxen or colchicine was provided for 1 to 8 weeks. The primary endpoint was a serum urate concentration of less than 6.0 mg per deciliter (360 micromoles per liter) when measured in the last three months. Secondary endpoints included reduction in the incidence of gout flares and site tophus. The primary endpoint was met in 53 percent of patients receiving 80 mg of febuxostat, 62 percent of those receiving 120 mg of febuxostat, and 21 percent of those receiving allopurinol (P<0.001 for each febuxostat versus allopurinol group). . Although the incidence of gout flares decreased with continued treatment, the overall incidence at weeks 9 to 52 was similar in all groups: 64 percent of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 70 percent of those receiving 120 mg febuxostat, and 64 percent of those receiving febuxostat 120 mg. Allopurinol administration (P=0.99 for febuxostat 80 mg vs. allopurinol; P=0.23 for febuxostat 120 mg vs. allopurinol). Median reduction in tophi area was 83 percent in patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat and 66 percent in patients receiving 120 mg febuxostat, compared with 50 percent in patients receiving allopurinol (P=0.08 for 80 mg febuxostat vs. allopurinol; P =0.16 120 mg for febuxostat versus allopurinol). More patients in the high-dose febuxostat group than in the allopurinol group (P=0.003) or the low-dose febuxostat group discontinued the study. Four of 507 patients in the two febuxostat groups (0.8 percent) and none of 253 patients in the allopurinol group died; All deaths were from causes judged by the investigators (while still unblinded to treatment) to be unrelated to the study drugs (P=0.31 for the comparison between the combined febuxostat groups and the allopurinol group). Febuxostat, at 80 mg or 120 mg daily, was more effective than allopurinol at the commonly used fixed daily dose of 300 mg in reducing serum urate. Similar reductions in gout flares and tophus areas were observed in all treatment groups.
