abstract: The prototypic xanthine oxidase (XO) inhibitor allopurinol has been the cornerstone of clinical management of gout and hyperuricemic conditions for several decades. Recent data indicate that XO also plays an important role in ischemic and other types of tissue and blood vessel damage, inflammatory diseases, and various forms of chronic heart failure. Allopurinol and its active metabolite oxypurinol have shown considerable promise in the treatment of these conditions in both experimental animals and small-scale human clinical trials. Although some of the beneficial effects of these compounds may not be related to XO inhibition, the encouraging findings have sparked considerable interest in the development of additional, novel series of XO inhibitors for different therapeutic indications. Here, we present a critical review of the effects of XO inhibitors in various pathophysiological conditions and also discuss the various emerging therapeutic strategies offered by this approach.

abstract: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in subjects with primary fibromyalgia with or without current major depressive disorder. This study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted at 18 outpatient research centers in the United States. A total of 207 subjects meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for primary fibromyalgia were enrolled (89% female, 87% white, mean age 49 years, 38% with current major depressive disorder). After a single-blind placebo treatment for 1 week, subjects were randomized to duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (n = 104) or placebo (n = 103) for 12 weeks. Composite outcome measures were the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score (score range 0–80, 0 indicating no impact) and the FIQ pain score (score range 0–10). Secondary outcome measures included mean pain score, pain threshold, number of tender points, FIQ fatigue, awakening fatigue and stiffness scores, Clinical Global Impression Severity (CGI-Severity) scale, Patient Global Impression (PGI-Improvement) scale, Brief Pain Inventory ( Short Form), the Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36, the Quality of Life Depression Scale, and the Sheehan Disability Scale. Compared with placebo-treated subjects, duloxetine-treated subjects improved significantly (P = 0.027) on FIQ total score, with a treatment difference of −5.53 (95% confidence interval −10.43, −0.63), but not significantly higher FIQ pain score (P = 0.130). Compared with placebo-treated subjects, duloxetine-treated subjects had significantly greater reductions in the mean pain severity score of the Brief Pain Inventory (P = 0.008), the mean pain severity score of the Brief Pain Inventory (P = 0.004), the number of painful points (P = 0.002), and FIQ stiffness. score (P = 0.048) and had significantly greater improvements in midpoint pain threshold (P = 0.002), CGI-severity (P = 0.048), PGI-improvement (P = 0.033), and several quality-of-life measures. Duloxetine treatment improved fibromyalgia symptoms and pain severity, regardless of baseline major depressive disorder status. Compared with placebo-treated female subjects (n = 92), duloxetine-treated female subjects (n = 92) showed significantly greater improvements in most performance measures, whereas duloxetine-treated male subjects (n = 12) failed to improve any performance. measure. The treatment effect on significant pain reduction in female subjects was independent of mood or anxiety effects. Duloxetine has been safely administered and is well tolerated. In this randomized, controlled, 12-week trial (with a 1-week placebo run-in phase), duloxetine was an effective and safe treatment for many symptoms associated with fibromyalgia in subjects with and without major depressive disorder, particularly women. , which had significant improvements in most outcome measures.

abstract: This was a 12-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in 354 female patients with primary fibromyalgia with or without current major depressive disorder. Patients (90% Caucasian; mean age, 49.6 years; 26% with current major depressive disorder) received duloxetine 60 mg once daily (QD) (N=118), duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (BID) (N=116), or placebo (N=120). The primary outcome was the mean pain severity score of the Brief Pain Inventory. Response to treatment was defined as >or=30% reduction in this score. Compared with placebo, both duloxetine-treated groups improved significantly (P<0.001) on the mean pain severity score of the Brief Pain Inventory. A significantly higher percentage of duloxetine-treated patients had a >or=30% reduction in this score (duloxetine 60 mg QD (55%; P<0.001); duloxetine 60 mg bid (54%; P=0.002); placebo (33%) ). The treatment effect of duloxetine on pain reduction was independent of mood and the presence of major depressive disorder. Compared with placebo patients, patients treated with duloxetine 60 mg QD or duloxetine 60 mg bid had significantly greater improvements in pain severity and interference scores, Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire, Clinical Global Impression of Severity, Patient Global Impression, and Improvisations. Several measures of quality of life. Both doses of duloxetine were safely administered and well tolerated. In conclusion, both duloxetine 60 mg QD and duloxetine 60 mg BID were effective and safe for the treatment of fibromyalgia in female patients with and without major depressive disorder.

abstract: The primary objectives of this study were to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine in reducing pain severity in fibromyalgia patients with and without current major depressive disorder. This was a 6-month, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. A total of 520 patients meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for fibromyalgia were randomly assigned to duloxetine (20 mg/day, 60 mg/day, or 120 mg/day) or placebo once daily for 6 months (3 months after duloxetine 20 mg/day group titrated to 60 mg/day). Composite outcome measures were the mean pain severity score of the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) and the Patient Global Impressions of Improvement (PGI-I) score. Safety was assessed through on-treatment adverse events and changes in vital signs, laboratory and ECG measures. Compared with placebo-treated patients, patients treated with duloxetine 120 mg/day had significant improvements over 3 months in the composite outcome measures (change in BPI score [-2.31 vs -1.39, P<0.001] and PGI-I [ 2.89 vs 3.39, P= 0.004]) and at 6 months (change in BPI [-2.26 vs -1.43, P=0.003] and PGI-I [2.93 vs 3.37, P=0.012]). Compared with placebo, treatment with duloxetine 60 mg/day also significantly improved primary joint measures at 3 months and BPI at 6 months. Duloxetine was effective in patients with and without major depressive disorder. There were no clinically significant differences between treatment groups in changes in vital signs, laboratory measures, or ECG measures. The study results showed that duloxetine at doses of 60 mg/day and 120 mg/day appeared to be safe and effective in patients with fibromyalgia.

abstract: Duloxetine is a balanced serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor licensed for the treatment of major depressive disorder, stress urinary incontinence, and neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A number of studies have been conducted to investigate the use of duloxetine in neuropathic and nociceptive pain conditions. This is the first update of a review published in 2010. To evaluate the benefits and harms of duloxetine in the treatment of painful neuropathy and various types of chronic pain. We searched the Cochrane Neuromuscular Group Specialized Register, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHSEED, MEDLINE and EMBASE on 19 November 2013. We searched ClinicalTrials.gov for ongoing trials in April 2013. We also searched reference lists of identified publications for trials of duloxetine in the treatment of painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain. We selected all randomized or quasi-randomized trials for any formulation of duloxetine used in adults for painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain. We used standard methodological procedures expected by the Cochrane Collaboration. We identified 18 trials involving 6407 participants. We found 12 of these studies in the literature search for this update. Eight studies included a total of 2,728 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy, and six studies included 2,249 participants with fibromyalgia. Three studies included participants with depression and painful physical symptoms, and one included participants with central neuropathic pain. The studies were generally at low risk of bias, although important omissions, imputation methods and almost all studies conducted or funded by a drug manufacturer increase the risk of bias in some domains. Duloxetine 60 mg daily is effective in the treatment of painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy in the short term, with a risk ratio (RR) ≥ 50% pain reduction at 12 weeks of 1.73 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.08). The associated NNTB is 5 (95% CI 4 to 7). Duloxetine 60 mg daily was also effective for fibromyalgia over 12 weeks (RR ≥ 50% pain reduction 1.57, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.06; NNTB 8, 95% CI 4 to 21) and over 28 weeks (RR 1.58, % CI 1.10 to 2.27), as well as for painful physical symptoms in depression (RR 1.37, 95% CI 1.19 to 1.59; NNTB 8, 95% CI 5 to 14). There was no effect on central neuropathic pain in one small, high-quality study. In all conditions, adverse events were common in both the treatment and placebo groups, but were more common in the treatment group, with a dose-dependent effect. Most side effects were minor, but 16% of participants discontinued the drug due to side effects. Serious side effects were rare. There is sufficient moderate-quality evidence from eight studies conducted by the manufacturers of duloxetine that doses of 60 mg and 120 mg daily are effective in treating pain in diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but lower daily doses are not. No further tests are required. In fibromyalgia, there is lower-quality evidence that duloxetine is effective at doses similar to those used in diabetic peripheral neuropathy and with a similar magnitude of effect. In fibromyalgia, the effect may be achieved by a greater improvement in mental symptoms than in somatic physical pain. There is low- to moderate-quality evidence that pain relief is also achieved in pain associated with depressive symptoms, but there is no evidence of significant efficacy for NNTB 8 in fibromyalgia and depression. More trials (preferably independent investigator-led trials) in these indications are needed to achieve the optimal data size to make a robust determination of efficacy. Minor side effects are common and more common with duloxetine 60 mg and especially 120 mg daily than with 20 mg daily. , but serious side effects are rare. Improved direct comparison of duloxetine with other antidepressants and other drugs, such as pregabalin, already shown to be effective in neuropathic pain would be appropriate. Unbiased economic comparisons can further aid decision-making, but no high-quality study contains economic data.

abstract: Peripheral artery disease is considered a manifestation of systemic atherosclerosis, associated with cardiovascular and extremity adverse events. Data from previous studies suggested that patients receiving clopidogrel monotherapy had a lower risk of cardiovascular events than those receiving aspirin. We wanted to compare clopidogrel with ticagrelor, a potent antiplatelet agent, in patients with peripheral artery disease. In this double-blind, event-driven study, we randomized 13,885 patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease to receive monotherapy with ticagrelor (90 mg twice daily) or clopidogrel (75 mg once daily). Patients were eligible if they had an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80 or less or had undergone forelimb revascularization. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or ischemic stroke. The primary safety endpoint was major bleeding. Median follow-up was 30 months. The mean age of the patients was 66 years, and 72% were men; 43% were enrolled based on ABI and 57% based on prior revascularization. The mean baseline ABI in all patients was 0.71, 76.6% of patients had claudication, and 4.6% had critical limb ischemia. The primary efficacy endpoint occurred in 751 of 6,930 (10.8%) patients receiving ticagrelor and 740 of 6,955 (10.6%) receiving clopidogrel (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval [ CI], 0.92 to 1.13 = P); . In each group, acute limb ischemia occurred in 1.7% of patients (hazard ratio, 1.03; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85) and major bleeding in 1.6% of patients. (hazard ratio, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85). 1.43; P=0.49). In patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease, ticagrelor was not shown to be superior to clopidogrel in reducing cardiovascular events. Major bleeding occurred at similar rates in patients in the two study groups. (Sponsored by AstraZeneca; EUCLID ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01732822 .).

abstract: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affects approximately 20% of adults over the age of 55 and is a strong predictor of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death from vascular causes. The goal of treatment is to prevent future major coronary and cerebrovascular events and improve leg symptoms. A review of the best evidence for the medical treatment of PAD. MEDLINE and the Cochrane database were searched from 1990 to November 2005 for randomized trials and meta-analyses of medical treatments for PAD. References from these articles were also searched. Search terms included, individually and in combination: peripheral arterial disease, peripheral artery disease, PAD, randomized controlled trial, controlled trial, randomized and meta-analysis. Particular attention was paid to randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses of clinically relevant medical treatments for PAD. Outcome measures included leg symptoms (intermittent claudication and walking), death, and major coronary and cerebrovascular events. Claudication symptoms, walking, and quality of life can be improved with smoking cessation (physician advice, nicotine replacement therapy, and bupropion), a structured exercise program, statins, cilostazol, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The risk of major coronary and cerebrovascular events can be reduced by lowering blood pressure with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs, using statin drugs, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel, and possibly smoking cessation. The significant and increasing burden of PAD and its local and systemic complications can be reduced by lifestyle modification (smoking cessation, exercise) and medical therapies (nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, antihypertensives, statins, and antiplatelet drugs).

abstract: Incomplete inhibition of platelet thromboxane formation, as measured by an increase in urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentration, is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events. We aimed to determine the external validity of this association in aspirin-treated patients enrolled in the Clopidogrel High Atherothrombotic Risk and Ischemic Stabilization, Management, and Prevention (CHARISMA) trial and to determine whether there are any modifiable factors or interventions that reduce urinary 11 . Dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations that may reduce cardiovascular risk. Urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations were measured in 3,261 patients treated with aspirin at least 1 month after they were randomized to placebo or clopidogrel. Baseline urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations in the highest quartile were associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death compared with the lowest quartile (adjusted hazard ratio 1.66, 95% CI 1.06 to 2.61, 0.03). Increasing age, female sex, history of peripheral artery disease, current smoking, and oral hypoglycemic or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy were independently associated with higher urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, and aspirin dose > or =150 mg. /d, history of NSAID treatment, history of hypercholesterolemia, and statin treatment were associated with lower concentrations. Randomization to clopidogrel (versus placebo) did not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients in the highest quartile of urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) levels. In aspirin-treated patients, urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) are a surrogate and potentially modifiable predictor of atherothrombotic events such as stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death.

abstract: This guideline focuses on antithrombotic drug therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease as well as palliation of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in persons with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The methods in this guideline follow those described in Methodology for the Development of Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th Edition: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Chest Physicians in this supplement. The most important of our 20 recommendations are the following. In patients ≥ 50 years of age with asymptomatic PAD or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we recommend aspirin (75–100 mg/day) without therapy (Grade 2B) for primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic PAD (including patients before and after peripheral arterial bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) is recommended. Class 1A). We recommend not using warfarin plus aspirin in patients with symptomatic PAD (Grade 1B). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of the peripheral artery with stenting, we recommend single rather than dual antiplatelet therapy (Grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we recommend adding cilostazol (100 mg/day) to aspirin (75–100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Grade 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and rest pain who cannot be revascularized, we recommend the use of prostanoids (Grade 2C). In patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgical intervention with peripheral arterial thrombolysis (Grade 1B). Recommendations continue to support single antiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Adjunctive therapy for relief of extremity symptoms should be considered only after evaluation of exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and peripheral arterial revascularization.

abstract: This guideline focuses on antithrombotic drug therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease as well as palliation of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in persons with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The methods in this guideline follow those described in Methodology for the Development of Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th Edition: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Chest Physicians in this supplement. The most important of our 20 recommendations are the following. In patients ≥ 50 years of age with asymptomatic PAD or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we recommend aspirin (75–100 mg/day) without therapy (Grade 2B) for primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic PAD (including patients before and after peripheral arterial bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) is recommended. Class 1A). We recommend not using warfarin plus aspirin in patients with symptomatic PAD (Grade 1B). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal angioplasty of the peripheral artery with stenting, we recommend single rather than dual antiplatelet therapy (Grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we recommend adding cilostazol (100 mg/day) to aspirin (75–100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Grade 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and rest pain who cannot be revascularized, we recommend the use of prostanoids (Grade 2C). In patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgical intervention with peripheral arterial thrombolysis (Grade 1B). Recommendations continue to support single antiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Adjunctive therapy for relief of extremity symptoms should be considered only after evaluation of exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and peripheral arterial revascularization.

abstract: Bleeding, a common complication of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) treatment, is associated with worse outcomes. A modern model of major bleeding associated with AMI treatment can stratify patients at high risk of bleeding and is needed for risk adjustment of AMI practice and outcomes. Using the Acute Coronary Treatment and Intervention Outcomes Network Registry-Get With Guidelines (ACTION Registry-GWTG) database, a hospital-based model of bleeding risk was developed in patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and non-ST. Segment elevation myocardial infarction. The model used only baseline variables and was developed (n = 72,313) and validated (n = 17,960) in patients with AMI (at 251 US centers between January 2007 and December 2008). The 12 most statistically and clinically significant variables were included in the final regression model. Calibration plots are shown and model discrimination is demonstrated in derivation and validation cohorts, as well as in key subgroups. In the general population, the rate of major bleeding was 10.8%. The 12 factors associated with major bleeding in the model were heart rate, baseline hemoglobin, female gender, baseline serum creatinine, age, electrocardiographic changes, heart failure or shock, diabetes, peripheral artery disease, body weight, systolic blood pressure, and home warfarin. use. The risk model discriminated well in the derivation (C-statistic = 0.73) and validation (C-statistic = 0.71) cohorts. The major bleeding risk score corresponded well to the observed bleeding: very low risk (3.9%), low risk (7.3%), medium risk (16.1%), high risk (29.0%), and very high risk (39.8%). In conclusion, the ACTION Registry-GWTG Hospital Major Bleeding Model stratifies the risk of major bleeding using time-of-presentation variables and provides risk-adjusted bleeding outcomes for quality improvement initiatives and clinical decision making.

abstract: The combination of anticoagulants and antiplatelet therapy is more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone for the initial and long-term management of acute coronary syndromes, but increases the risk of bleeding. Antiplatelet therapy is often combined with oral anticoagulants in patients with an indication for warfarin (eg, atrial fibrillation) who also have an indication for antiplatelet therapy (eg, coronary artery disease), but the appropriateness of such an approach is unclear. Anticoagulation appears to be as effective as antiplatelet therapy for the long-term management of acute coronary syndromes and stroke, and possibly peripheral artery disease, but results in more bleeding. Therefore, in such patients who develop atrial fibrillation, switching from antiplatelet therapy to anticoagulants may be all that is needed. The combination of anticoagulants and antiplatelet therapy has only been shown to provide additional benefit over anticoagulants alone in patients with prosthetic heart valves. The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is not as effective as oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation, whereas the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is more effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with coronary stents. Whether the benefits of triple therapy outweigh the risks in patients with atrial fibrillation and coronary stents needs to be evaluated in randomized trials.

abstract: Vascular disease is included in a risk assessment system for predicting stroke in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF). This post-hoc analysis of ROCKET AF aimed to determine the absolute incidence of stroke and bleeding and the relative efficacy and safety of rivaroxaban versus warfarin in patients with and without peripheral artery disease (PAD). Peripheral artery disease was defined on the case report form as the presence of intermittent claudication, amputation for arterial insufficiency, vascular reconstruction, bypass surgery, or percutaneous intervention on the extremities, or previously documented abdominal aortic aneurysm. ROCKET AF was a double-blind, double-blind, randomized controlled trial comparing rivaroxaban and warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism. A total of 839 (5.9%) patients in ROCKET AF had PAD. Patients with and without PAD had similar rates of stroke or systemic embolism [HR: 1.04, 95% CI (0.72, 1.50), P = 0.84] and major or minor clinically significant (NMCR) bleeding [HR: 1.11, 95% CI (0.96, 1.28), P = 0.17], respectively. The efficacy of rivaroxaban compared with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism was similar in patients with PAD (HR: 1.19, 95% CI: 0.63–2.22) and without PAD (HR: 0.86, 95% CI: 0.73–1.02 interaction P = 0.34). There was a significant interaction for major or NMCR bleeding in patients with PAD treated with rivaroxaban versus warfarin (HR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06–1.86) compared with those without PAD (HR: 1.03, 95% CI: 0.95–1.11). interaction P = 0.037). Patients with PAD in ROCKET AF did not have a statistically significant higher risk of stroke or systemic embolism than patients without PAD, and there were similar efficacy results in patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin. In PAD patients, there was a higher risk of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (interaction P = 0.037). Further investigation is warranted to confirm this subgroup analysis and to determine the optimal treatment in these high-risk AF patients with PAD.

abstract: Management of warfarin therapy is complicated by wide variability in drug response among patients. Variants in the gene encoding vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1) may influence response to warfarin. We conducted a retrospective study of European-American patients receiving long-term warfarin maintenance therapy. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of VKORC1 haplotypes on warfarin dose. We determined VKORC1 haplotype frequencies in African-American, European-American, and Asian-American populations and VKORC1 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression in human liver samples. We identified 10 common noncoding VKORC1 single-nucleotide polymorphisms and inferred five major haplotypes. We identified a low-dose haplotype group (A) and a high-dose haplotype group (B). The mean (+/-SE) maintenance dose of warfarin differed significantly among the three haplotype group combinations, 2.7+/-0.2 mg per day for A/A, 4.9+/-0.2 mg per day for A/B, and 6.2. +/-0.3 mg/day for B/B (P<0.001). VKORC1 haplotype groups A and B explained about 25 percent of the dose variation. Asian Americans had a higher proportion of group A haplotypes, and African Americans had a higher proportion of group B haplotypes. VKORC1 mRNA levels varied by haplotype combination. VKORC1 haplotypes can be used to stratify patients into low-, medium-, and high-dose warfarin groups and may explain differences in dose requirements between patients of different ancestries. The molecular mechanism of this warfarin dose response appears to be regulated at the transcriptional level.

abstract: Coumarin derivatives such as warfarin are the therapy of choice for the long-term treatment and prevention of thromboembolic events. Coumarins target blood coagulation by inhibiting the vitamin K epoxide reductase multiprotein complex (VKOR). This complex recycles vitamin K 2,3-epoxide to vitamin K hydroquinone, a cofactor necessary for the post-translational gamma-carboxylation of several blood coagulation factors. Despite great efforts, the components of the VKOR complex have not been identified. The complex has been proposed to be involved in two inherited human diseases: vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor combined deficiency type 2 (VKCFD2; Online Mendelian Inheritance in Male (OMIM) 607473) and resistance to coumarin-type anticoagulants (warfarin). Resistance, WR; Here, we identify, using three species linkage information, the gene vitamin K epoxide reductase complex subunit 1 (VKORC1), which encodes a small transmembrane protein of the endoplasmic reticulum. VKORC1 harbors missense mutations in both human disease and warfarin-resistant rat strains. Overexpression of wild-type VKORC1, but not VKORC1 carrying the VKCFD2 mutation, results in a marked increase in VKOR activity that is sensitive to warfarin inhibition.

abstract: Current dosing algorithms do not take into account genetic and environmental factors to determine the dose of warfarin. This study investigated the contribution of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and body size to warfarin dose requirements. 297 patients with stable anticoagulation with a target international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0 were studied. Genetic analyzes of CYP2C9 (*2 and *3 alleles) and VKORC1 (-1639 polymorphism) were performed, and venous INR and plasma R- and S-warfarin concentrations were determined. Mean daily warfarin dose requirement was highest in CYP2C9 homozygous wild-type patients compared with those with variant *2 and *3 alleles (P < .001) and highest in patients with VKORC1 (position -1639) GG genotype compared with GA genotype and AA individuals with genotype (P < .001). The average daily dose of warfarin decreases by 0.5 to 0.7 mg per decade between the ages of 20 and 90. Age, height, and CYP2C9 genotype significantly contributed to S-warfarin and total warfarin clearance, whereas only age and body size contributed significantly to R-warfarin clearance. A multivariate regression model including the variables of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and height was the best model for predicting warfarin dose (R2 = 55%). Based on the data, a new warfarin dosing regimen was developed. The validity of the dosing regimen was confirmed in a second cohort of patients on warfarin therapy.

abstract: Initiating warfarin therapy using trial-and-error dosing is problematic. Our goal was to develop and validate a pharmacogenetic algorithm. In a derivation cohort of 1015 participants, independent predictors of therapeutic dose were: VKORC1 polymorphism -1639/3673 G>A (-28% per allele), body surface area (BSA) (+11% at 0.25 m(2)), CYP2C9(*) 3 (-33% per allele), CYP2C9(*)2 (-19% per allele), age (-7% per decade), target international normalized ratio (INR) (+11% per 0.5 unit increase), amiodarone use (- 22%), smoking status (+10%), race (-9%) and current thrombosis (+7%). This pharmacogenetic equation explained 53-54% of the variation in warfarin dose in the derivation and validation (N= 292) cohorts. In comparison, the clinical equation explained only 17–22% of the variation in dose ( P < 0.001). In a validation cohort, we prospectively applied a pharmacogenetic dosing algorithm to patients starting warfarin therapy, two of whom had major bleeding. To facilitate the use of these pharmacogenetic and clinical algorithms, we have created a non-commercial website, http://www.WarfarinDosing.org.

Given the direct evidence and detailed quantification of the effect of VKORC1 on Warfarin dosing, along with clinical implementation, the abstract strongly supports the hypothesis that an interaction exists between Warfarin and the VKORC1 gene, justifying a relevance score of 1.

abstract: Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals who are at greater risk with certain medications. Routine adoption of pharmacogenetic tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at preventing or reducing the incidence of ADRs. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms related to pharmacogenetic testing, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were scored independently by two reviewers. Articles deemed to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstracts and reviewed for full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met the inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58: 01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before clopidogrel treatment). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before 6-mercaptoputine, azathioprine and cisplatin therapy), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (to inform genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before methotrexate treatment) and factor Vpri Leiden testing. oral contraception). Testing for A1555G before prescribing aminoglycosides is ineffective. Our systematic review found strong evidence for the efficacy of genotyping before treatment with a number of conventional drugs. However, further analyzes and/or the availability of strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations for others.

abstract: Serious adverse drug reactions are the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, are the leading cause of postmarketing drug withdrawals, and represent billions of US dollars in costs annually in all developed countries. Some of these serious adverse drug reactions can be prevented by systematic screening for pharmacogenomic risk factors. In the past few years, regulatory agencies have introduced pharmacogenomic labels for several medications, but although a priori genetic testing is still recommended or recommended, it is rarely mandatory due to poor knowledge of evidence-based medicine. Recently published pharmacogenomic randomised, controlled and ongoing trials will gradually make genotyping tests mandatory for HLA-B*5701 (abacavir), TPMT (6-mercaptopurine), CYP2C9 plus VKORC1 (warfarin) and CYP3A5 (tacrolimus). The parallel development of pharmacogenomic bedside tests will certainly establish genetically based prescriptions in routine medical practice.

abstract: Pharmacogenomics attempts to explain individual variation in response to medications due to genetic variation. Although technological advances have provided us with relatively simple and inexpensive genotyping methods, the promise of personalized medicine has not yet lived up to our high expectations. Successful results that have been achieved in the field of pharmacogenomy is to name several, hla-b*5701 screening to prevent hypersensitivity to the abutter, thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) to prevent thiopurine and vkorc1. Agulant for better dosing of warfarin . However, few pharmacogenetic examples have been found in clinical practice for the treatment of complex diseases. Unfortunately, the absence of results from observational studies involving many genes and diseases appears to be a common pattern in pharmacogenomic studies. In this article, we discuss some of the methodological and statistical issues in study design, gene and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) selection, and data analysis that should be considered in future pharmacogenomic research. First, we discuss some issues related to the design of epidemiologic studies specific to pharmacogenomic research. Second, we describe some pros and cons of the candidate gene approach (including gene and SNP selection) and the genome-wide scan approach. Finally, both conventional and several innovative approaches to the analysis of large pharmacogenomic data sets are proposed, addressing multiple testing and systems biology issues in different ways.

These are cited to illustrate how pharmacogenomics can be applied in clinical settings to tailor drug treatments based on genetic testing. abstract: Cytochrome P450 2C19 (CYP2C19) is a major (or partial) cause of large differences in the pharmacokinetics of many clinically important drugs. Based on their ability to metabolize (S)-mephenytoin or other CYP2C19 substrates, individuals can be classified as extensive metabolizers (EMs) or poor metabolizers (PMs). Eight variant alleles (CYP2C19*2 to CYP2C19*8) have been identified that predict PMs. The prevalence of EM and PM genotypes and phenotypes shows wide ethnic differences. Non-genetic factors such as enzyme inhibition and induction, aging and liver cirrhosis can also modulate CYP2C19 activity. In EMs, approximately 80% of doses of the proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) omeprazole, lansoprazole, and pantoprazole appear to be cleared by CYP2C19, whereas CYP3A is more important in PMs. Exposure to these drugs is fivefold higher in PMs than in EMs of CYP2C19, and further increases occur in PMs upon inhibition of alternative metabolic pathways catalyzed by CYP3A. As a result, CYP2C19 PMs experience more effective acid suppression and better healing of duodenal and gastric ulcers when treated with omeprazole and lansoprazole compared to EMs. The pharmacoeconomic value of CYP2C19 genotyping remains unclear. Our calculations suggest that CYP2C19 genotyping could save approximately $5,000 for every 100 Asians tested, but none for Caucasian patients. Nevertheless, genotyping for common alleles of CYP2C19 before starting PPIs for the treatment of reflux disease and H. pylori infection is an effective way to determine the duration of treatment and dosage regimen. Altered CYP2C19 activity does not increase the risk of adverse drug reactions/PPI interactions. Phenytoin plasma concentrations and toxicity have been shown to be increased in patients receiving CYP2C19 inhibitors or having different alleles and, due to its narrow therapeutic range, genotyping of CYP2C19 along with CYP2C9 may be necessary to optimize phenytoin dosing. An increased risk of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity is likely in patients with reduced CYP2C19 and/or CYP2D6 activity. CYP2C19 is the key enzyme for the activation of proguanil to cycloguanil, but there are no clinical data to suggest that CYP2C19 PMs are at high risk of malaria prophylaxis or treatment failure. Clearance of diazepam is clearly reduced in PMs or with simultaneous administration of CYP2C19 inhibitors, but clinical consequences are generally minimal. Finally, many studies have attempted to determine the relationship between CYP2C19 genotype and phenotype and susceptibility to xenobiotic-induced disease, but none of them are conclusive.

abstract: Voriconazole is the therapy of choice for aspergillosis and a new treatment option for candidiasis. Liver disease, age, cytochrome CYP2C19 genetic polymorphisms, and comorbidities affect voriconazole metabolism. Wide variability in voriconazole pharmacokinetics may be associated with reduced efficacy or toxicity. This study was conducted to evaluate the utility of measuring voriconazole blood levels with individualized dose adjustments. A total of 181 high pressure liquid chromatography measurements were performed during 2388 treatment days in 52 patients. Wide variability in voriconazole blood levels was observed, ranging from < or = 1 mg/L (minimum inhibitory concentration at which 90% of isolates are susceptible for most fungal pathogens) to >5.5 mg/L in 25% of cases. L (level possibly associated with toxicity) in 31% of cases. Lack of response to therapy was more common in patients with voriconazole levels <or=1 mg/L (6 [46%] of 13 patients, including 5 patients with aspergillosis, 4 of whom were treated orally at a mean dose of 6 mg/L. kg/day) than with voriconazole >1 mg/L (15 [12%] of 39 patients; P=.02). Blood levels >1 mg/L were achieved after increasing the dose of voriconazole, with complete resolution of the infection in all 6 cases. Among the 16 patients with low blood voriconazole doses >5.5 mg/L, 5 patients (31%) had encephalopathy, including 4 patients treated with intravenous voriconazole at a mean dose of 8 mg/kg per day, whereas none of the patients Levels <or=5.5 mg/L presented with neurologic toxicity (P=.002). Coadministration with omeprazole may have contributed to voriconazole accumulation in 4 patients. In all cases, discontinuation of therapy resulted in rapid and complete neurological recovery. Therapeutic drug monitoring of voriconazole improves the efficacy and safety of therapy in critically ill patients with invasive mycoses.

abstract: Many drugs, including proton pump inhibitors and certain antidepressants, are metabolized by the polymorphic cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2C19 enzyme. A significant proportion of extensive metabolizers fail to reach relevant drug levels, and our aim was to investigate any genetic background. The 5'-flanking region of the CYP2C19 gene from subjects with rapid metabolism of omeprazole was sequenced and CYP2C19 phenotype-genotype associations were analyzed in Swedish (n = 107) and Ethiopian (n = 126) extensive metabolizers. The relationship of the metabolic ratio of omeprazole (omeprazole/5-hydroxyomeprazole in plasma 3 hours after drug administration) under the plasma concentration-time curve was used for prediction studies. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed using human nuclear protein extracts. Liver reporter vector transfection was performed in CD1 mice. We identified a novel allele (CYP2C19*17) carrying -806C>T and -3402C>T with a frequency of 18% in both Swedish and Ethiopian subjects and 4% in Chinese subjects. In Swedes, the metabolic ratio of omeprazole was higher in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.50 [interquartile range, 0.37-0.73]) than in homozygotes for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.25- [interquartile range] ]). (P = .010). In Ethiopians, a similar difference in S/R-mephenytoin ratio was observed between individuals homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.20 [interquartile range, 0.12-0.37]) and homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, range, 0 00). 0.03-0.06]) (P = .013). Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific binding of human liver nuclear proteins to the element carrying -806T but not -806C. Reporter vector experiments demonstrated increased transcriptional activity of the CYP2C19*17 allele in vivo in mice. Predictions revealed that CYP2C19*17 homozygotes would receive 35% to 40% lower plasma concentration-time curve values ​​of omeprazole than subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 receiving standard doses of omeprazole. CYP2C19*17 may cause therapeutic failure in drug treatment, for example, with proton pump inhibitors and antidepressants.

abstract: Human CYP2Cs are an important subfamily of P450 enzymes that metabolize approximately 20% of clinically used drugs. There are four subfamily members, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP2C18. Of these, CYP2C8, CYP2C9 and CYP2C19 are of clinical importance. CYP2C also metabolizes some endogenous compounds such as arachidonic acid. Each member of this subfamily was found to be genetically polymorphic. The best known of these polymorphisms is CYP2C19. CYP2C19 poor metabolizers (PMs) represent approximately 3–5% of Caucasians, a similar percentage of African Americans, and 12–100% of Asian groups. The polymorphism affects the metabolism of the anticonvulsant agent mephenytoin, proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole, the anxiolytic agent diazepam, certain antidepressants, and the antimalarial drug proguanil. Toxic effects may occur in diazepam-exposed PMs, and the efficacy of some proton pump inhibitors may be greater in PMs than in EMs with lower doses of these drugs. There are many mutant alleles that can be detected by genetic testing. CYP2C9 metabolizes a wide variety of drugs, including the anticoagulant warfarin, antidiabetic agents such as tolbutamide, anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, and NSAIDs. The frequency of functional polymorphisms is much lower, estimated at 1/250 in Caucasians and less in Asians. However, the clinical consequences of this rare polymorphism can be severe. Severe and life-threatening bleeding episodes have been reported in CYP2C9 PMs exposed to warfarin. Phenytoin is known to cause severe toxicity in PMs. A new polymorphism was discovered in CYP2C8, which metabolizes Taxol (paclitaxel). Genetic testing is available for all known CYP2C variant alleles.

abstract: Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals who are at greater risk with certain medications. Routine adoption of pharmacogenetic tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at preventing or reducing the incidence of ADRs. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms related to pharmacogenetic testing, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were scored independently by two reviewers. Articles deemed to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstracts and reviewed for full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met the inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58: 01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before clopidogrel treatment). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before 6-mercaptoputine, azathioprine and cisplatin therapy), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (to inform genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before methotrexate treatment) and factor Vpri Leiden testing. oral contraception). Testing for A1555G before prescribing aminoglycosides is ineffective. Our systematic review found strong evidence for the efficacy of genotyping before treatment with a number of conventional drugs. However, further analyzes and/or the availability of strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations for others.

abstract: During HIV infection and/or antiretroviral therapy (ART), monocytes and macrophages exhibit a wide range of dysfunctions that significantly contribute to HIV pathogenesis and therapy-related complications. However, the molecular components contributing to these dysfunctions remain elusive. Therefore, we used a parallel approach of genome-wide microarray analysis and focused gene expression profiling on monocytes from patients at different stages of HIV infection and/or ART to further characterize these dysfunctions. Processes involved in apoptosis, cell cycle, lipid metabolism, proteasome function, protein trafficking and transcriptional regulation were identified as areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection. Individual genes potentially contributing to this monocyte dysfunction included several novel factors. One of these is the adipocytokine NAMPT/visfatin, which we show can inhibit HIV infection early in its life cycle. About half of all genes identified were restored to control levels by ART, while the rest were persistently dysregulated. In addition, several candidate biomarkers (specifically CCL1 and CYP2C19) for the development of abacavir hypersensitivity reactions have been proposed. Previously described areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection were confirmed and new themes identified. In addition, individual genes associated with these dysfunctions and ART-related disorders were pinpointed. These genes provide a useful basis for further functional studies of the contribution of monocytes/macrophages to HIV pathogenesis. One such gene, NAMPT/visfatin, represents a possible new restriction factor for HIV.

abstract: Pharmacogenomic studies contribute to our understanding of interindividual differences in response to antiretroviral drugs. Genetic polymorphisms in major histocompatibility complex genes predict the likelihood of hypersensitivity reactions in subjects prescribed abacavir and possibly nevirapine. Recent studies have shown that polymorphisms in the CYP2B6 gene are associated with higher efavirenz plasma concentrations and increased central nervous system side effects of efavirenz. Polymorphisms in the MDR1 gene encoding the drug pump, P-glycoprotein, may predict nevirapine-associated hepatotoxicity and long-term virologic response to efavirenz. CYP2C19 polymorphism predicts nelfinavir plasma levels and possibly the risk of virological failure on this drug. European mitochondrial haplogroup can predict increased risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Expanding and refining knowledge of human genetics and associations with antiretroviral drug response may ultimately allow individualization of genotype-based therapy. This article summarizes a presentation by David Haas, MD, David W., at the International AIDS Society-USA International Course in Atlanta in March 2005. Haas presentation on HIV therapeutics and pharmacogenomics.

abstract: Several long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) are natural ligands of the non-secretory peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma (PPARG), which, together with its lipogenic target genes, is upregulated in the lactating cow mammary gland. Thus, PPARG may represent an important control point for bovine milk fat synthesis. We tested the expression of the lipogenic gene network by quantitative PCR of 19 genes in bovine epithelial cells cultured 16:0, 18:0, cis-9 18:1, trans-10 18:1, trans-10, cis-12 18: 2 [ t10c12 conjugated linoleic acid (CLA)], 20:5, ethanol (control) and the PPARG agonist rosiglitazone (ROSI). Triplicate cultures were maintained for 12 h in 50 muM ROSI or 100 muM LCFA. Relative to control, the overall 16:0 and 18:0 responses included significantly higher expression of INSIG1 (+298%, +92%), AGPAT6 (+137%, +169%), FABP3 (+755%, +338%). and FABP4 (+171%, 157%). This was coupled with greater intracellular lipid droplet formation and mRNA for ACSS2, LPIN1, SCD, and SREBF2 in response to 16:0 and greater DGAT1 and THRSP in response to 18:0. Trans-10 18:1 and t10c12 CLA reduced FASN (-60%, -31%), SCD (-100%, -357%) and SREBF1 (-49%, -189%) expression. In addition, t10c12 CLA decreased the expression of ACSS2, FABP3, INSIG1, SREBF2, and THRSP. SREBF1 expression was lower in cis-9 18:1 (-140%) and 20:5 (-125%) compared to control. The latter LCFA also reduced the expression of SCD, SREBF2 and LPL. No effect of LCFA or ROSI on PPARG was observed, but ROSI upregulated ACACA, FASN, LPIN1, AGPAT6, DGAT1, SREBF1, SREBF2, and INSIG1 expression (+39% to +269%). Thus, these genes are putative PPARG target genes in bovine cells. This is the first report showing a direct effect of trans-10 on lipogenic gene expression in 18:1 bovine mammary cells. Coordinated upregulation of lipogenic gene networks in response to ROSI and saturated LCFA suggests support for PPARG activation in the regulation of bovine milk fat synthesis.

abstract: In adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and macrophages, nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ (PPAR-γ) signaling is a determinant of insulin sensitivity, and this receptor mediates the insulin-sensitizing effects of thiazolidinediones (TZDs). Since PPAR-γ is also expressed in neurons, we generated mice with a neuron-specific Pparg knockout (Pparg brain knockout (BKO)) to determine whether neuronal PPAR-γ signaling contributes to weight gain or insulin sensitivity. When fed a high-fat diet (HFD), Pparg-BKO mice had reduced food intake and increased energy expenditure compared with Pparg(f/f) mice, resulting in reduced weight gain. Pparg-BKO mice also responded better to leptin administration than Pparg(f/f) mice. When treated with the TZD rosiglitazone, Pparg-BKO mice were resistant to rosiglitazone-induced hyperphagia and weight gain and experienced only marginal improvements in glucose metabolism compared with rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice. Hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp studies showed that the rosiglitazone-induced increase in hepatic insulin sensitivity during HFD feeding was completely abrogated in Pparg-BKO mice, consistent with the failure of rosiglitazone to improve hepatic insulin receptor signaling. We conclude that HFD-induced weight gain is partially dependent on the effects of neuronal PPAR-γ signaling to limit thermogenesis and increase food intake. Neuronal PPAR-γ signaling is also required for the hepatic insulin-sensitizing effects of TZDs.

abstract: The nuclear hormone receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR gamma) is an important regulator of lipid and glucose homeostasis and cellular differentiation. Studies in multiple cell types in vitro and in vivo have shown that activation of PPAR gamma can reduce cell proliferation. We show here that activation of PPAR gamma is sufficient to reduce the proliferation of cultured insulinoma cell lines. We created a model with mice in which PPARG gene expression in beta cells was eliminated (beta gamma KO mice) and these mice had significant islet hyperplasia on a chow diet. Interestingly, the normal expansion of beta-cell mass that occurs in control mice in response to a high-fat diet is markedly blunted in these animals. Despite this change in beta cell mass, no effect on glucose homeostasis was observed in beta gamma KO mice. Furthermore, while thiazolidinediones enhanced insulin secretion from cultured wild-type islets, administration of rosiglitazone to insulin-resistant control and beta gamma KO mice showed that PPAR gamma in beta cells is not required for the antidiabetic activity of these compounds. These data demonstrate a critical physiological role for PPAR gamma function in beta-cell proliferation and also indicate that the mechanisms controlling beta-cell hyperplasia in obesity are distinct from those regulating basal cell mass in the islet.

This distinction is vital for drug-gene interaction studies as it explores the complexity of therapeutic effects beyond the primary target. abstract: Nocturnin (NOC) is a circadian-regulated protein related to the yeast family of transcription factors involved in the cellular response to nutrient status. In mammals, NOC functions as a deadenylase but lacks a transcriptional activation domain. It is highly expressed in bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs), hepatocytes and adipocytes. In BMSCs exposed to the PPAR-gamma (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma) agonist rosiglitazone, Noc expression increased 30-fold. Previously, we reported that Noc(-/-) mice had lower body temperatures, were protected from diet-induced obesity, and importantly showed absence of Pparg circadian rhythmicity on a high-fat diet. Noc(-/-) mice have reduced bone marrow adiposity and high bone mass, consistent with its role in influencing the distribution of BMSCs. In the same vein, NOC overexpression enhances adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells but negatively regulates osteogenesis in MC3T3-E1 cells. NOC and a mutant form lacking deadenylase activity bind to PPAR-gamma and markedly enhance PPAR-gamma transcriptional activity. Both WT and mutant NOC promote nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma. Importantly, NOC-mediated nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma is blocked by a short peptide fragment of NOC that inhibits its physical interaction with PPAR-gamma. The inhibitory effect of this NOC-peptide was partially reversed by rosiglitazone, indicating that the effect of NOC on PPAR-gamma nuclear translocation may be independent of ligand-mediated PPAR-gamma activation. In summary, Noc plays a unique role in regulating mesenchymal stem cell lineage distribution by modulating PPAR-gamma activity via nuclear translocation. These data illustrate a unique mechanism by which a nutrient-responsive gene influences BMSC differentiation, adipogenesis, and ultimately body composition.

It especially emphasizes how NOC-induced modifications in PPARG activity influence mesenchymal stem-cell lineage allocation, which is critical for metabolic processes and disease conditions linked to PPARG functions.  4. **Implications of PPARG Activity Modulation**: The ability of NOC, and by extension, Rosiglitazone (through its effect on Noc), to facilitate the nuclear translocation of PPARG and enhance its transcriptional activity, is pivotal. abstract: In this study, we attempted to test the hypothesis that genetic factors may influence the antidepressant response to fluoxetine. The study focused on seven candidate genes in the serotonergic pathway involved in serotonin synthesis, transport, recognition and degradation. Our clinical sample consisted of 96 subjects with unilateral major depression treated with fluoxetine, with response variables assessed after a 12-week study. Patient data were also collected to investigate the pattern of drug response. Using a high-throughput single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping platform and capillary electrophoresis, we screened patients for 110 SNPs and four repeat polymorphisms located in seven candidate genes (HTR1A, HTR2A, HTR2C, MAOA, SLC6A4, TPH2, and TPH1). Statistical tests performed included single-locus and haplotype association tests and linkage disequilibrium (LD) estimation. Little evidence of population stratification was observed using a genomic control procedure with 20 random SNPs in the sample. Our most intriguing results included three SNPs in the TPH1 gene and one SNP in the SLC6A4 gene showing significant single-locus association when response to fluoxetine was compared to non-response (P=0.02-0.04). All odds ratios indicate an increased risk of non-response to fluoxetine. In the comparison of non-specific and non-responders with specific response, three SNPs in the TPH2 gene (P=0.02-0.04) were positively associated and one SNP in the HTR2A gene (P=0.02) was negatively associated. When comparing the specific response with the non-specific response, we found significant negative associations for three SNPs in the HTR2A gene (P=0.001-0.03) and two SNPs in the MAOA gene (P=0.03-0.05). We observed variable, albeit strong, LD within each gene and a surprisingly low number of putative haplotypes arising from tagged SNPs. Significant haplotype associations were found for all genes except HTR1A and HTR2C. Although these data should be interpreted with caution due to the small sample size, these results implicate TPH1 and SLC6A4 in the general response and HTR2A, TPH2, and MAOA in the specificity of the response to fluoxetine. Interestingly, we observed that the less frequent alleles of many SNP markers were associated with non-response and non-specific phenotypes.

By focusing on genes linked to serotonin's synthesis, transport, recognition, and degradation, the study inherently explores the mechanistic pathways through which Fluoxetine might exert its effects.  2. **Significant Genetic Associations**: The abstract reports significant associations between specific single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the SLC6A4 gene and the response to Fluoxetine treatment in subjects with unipolar major depression. Such genetic associations strengthen the hypothesis as they suggest that variations within the SLC6A4 gene could influence the efficacy or the response profile of the drug.  3. **Methodological Rigor**: Through the use of high-throughput SNP genotyping and subsequent statistical analyses (including single-locus and haplotype association tests), the study robustly tests the hypothesis, lending validity to the observed associations. This detailed genetic analysis is crucial in establishing a credible link between the drug and the gene.  4. **Clinical Relevance**: The outcome of the study has significant clinical implications, suggesting that genetic markers in SLC6A4 could potentially be used to predict patient response to Fluoxetine. This can lead to more personalized medication strategies in the treatment of depression, optimizing therapeutic outcomes.  5. **Context within Serotonergic Pathway**: Given that SLC6A4 (commonly related to the serotonin transporter 5-HTT) is pivotal in the reuptake of serotonin, its direct relationship with the mechanism of action of Fluoxetine underscores the relevance of studying this gene in the context of treatment responsiveness.  In summary, the abstract directly addresses and presents findings that support the hypothesis of an interaction between Fluoxetine and the gene SLC6A4. This is achieved through the specific focus on genetic variations linked to drug response, thereby affirming the gene-drug interaction and justifying the relevance score of 1.

abstract: The serotonin transporter is a molecular target of many antidepressants, and the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein is associated with response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). We sought to test the hypothesis that SLC6A4 is associated with SSRI response by repeat sequencing of this gene in subjects with major depression. All exons, portions of all introns, and the promoter region containing a polymorphic repeat polymorphism (HTTLPR) previously associated with SSRI response were sequenced for 96 subjects, and variants were tested for association with response to fluoxetine treatment. We screened 712 kilobases of sequence and found 27 SLC6A4 variants, 21 of which had not been previously described. Seventeen were observed per chromosome, including three of the five exonic variants. One polymorphism (rs25531), just upstream of HTTLPR, showed an association with treatment response, and biochemical experiments showed that this polymorphism altered the binding of nuclear extracts to the transcription factor consensus activator protein 2, which is believed to be a critical factor in the regulation of neural gene expression in mammals. These results support an association between response to SSRIs and deoxyribonucleic acid variation at the serotonin transporter locus. We also identified a potentially important functional variant that contributes to this association and a possible biological mechanism that may mediate its effect.
cot: The abstract is highly relevant and hence rated as 1 for evaluating the hypothesis that there exists an interaction between the drug Fluoxetine and the gene SLC6A4. Here is a detailed explanation supporting this classification:  1. **Direct Examination of SLC6A4:** The study explicitly investigates the gene SLC6A4, which encodes the serotonin transporter, a known molecular target of antidepressants including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as Fluoxetine. This direct link between the gene and the drug is fundamental to evaluating the hypothesis.  2. **Focus on SSRI Response:** The primary goal of the research is to assess the association between genetic variants within SLC6A4 and response to SSRI treatment, particularly using Fluoxetine. By exploring this association, the study aims to understand how different genetic makeups can affect the efficacy of Fluoxetine, contributing directly to the hypothesis in question.  3. **Variant Identification and Functional Assessment:** The study not only identifies multiple variants within the SLC6A4 gene but also tests these variants for their association with treatment response to Fluoxetine. This deepens the understanding of how SLC6A4 variants can impact drug action, which is central to confirming the hypothesis.  5. **Genetic and Pharmacological Relevance:** By combining genetic analysis (resequencing of SLC6A4) and pharmacological outcomes (response to Fluoxetine), the study provides a comprehensive approach to investigate the gene-drug interaction, thereby making a significant contribution towards validating the proposed hypothesis.  Overall, the abstract delivers substantial evidence and detailed insights into how variations in the SLC6A4 gene influence the therapeutic effects of Fluoxetine, supporting the stated hypothesis about the interaction between the drug and the gene.

abstract: Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by recurrent and intrusive thoughts that are distressing (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors or mental acts that the person feels compelled to perform (compulsions). OCD has a partly genetic basis. Strong serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) drugs (clomipramine (Anafranil), fluvoxamine (Luvox), fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and paroxetine (Paxil)) are used to treat OCD, which act on the serotonin transporter protein. Uniquely effective. A polymorphism in the promoter region of the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein has recently been shown to affect protein expression and to be associated with measures of anxiety and depression and autism (using a family-controlled transmission disequilibrium test (TDT) design). Therefore, SLC6A4 has strong a priori support for potentially influencing risk in OCD: the protein it encodes is a drug target; Polymorphism in a gene affects function; and that polymorphisms have been shown to be associated with behavioral phenotypes. We used TDT with a trio set of 34 European-American families, 30 from unrelated and four from extended pedigrees, to test for linkage disequilibrium between OCD and alleles at the SLC6A4 promoter polymorphic locus. Of the 35 heterozygous parents, 24 transmitted the 'l' SLC6A4 allele and 11 transmitted the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 4.83; P < 0.03). Considering only the 13 SRI drug non-responders, there were 13 heterozygous parents, 10 of whom transmitted the 'l' allele and three the 's' allele (chi 2 TDT = 3.77; P < 0.052). These data provide preliminary support for an association and linkage disequilibrium between the SLC6A4 'l' allele and OCD.
cot: The abstract is highly relevant for evaluating the hypothesis that there exists an interaction between the drug Fluoxetine and the gene SLC6A4. The reasons for this relevance include:  1. **Focus on SLC6A4 and Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SRIs):** The abstract specifically mentions that potent serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRI), including Fluoxetine (Prozac), are used for the treatment of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). This provides a direct link to the drug in question, Fluoxetine.  2. **Genetic Basis of OCD and the Role of SLC6A4:** The abstract discusses the genetic foundation of OCD and highlights the gene SLC6A4, which encodes the serotonin transporter protein targeted by SRIs. This establishes SLC6A4 as a critical gene in the pathway affected by Fluoxetine.  3. **Polymorphism in SLC6A4 Affecting Drug Efficacy:** It further elaborates on a polymorphism in the promoter region of SLC6A4, affecting protein expression. This polymorphism is associated with behavioral phenotypes and potentially modulates the efficacy of SRIs like Fluoxetine, reinforcing the hypothesis of a pharmacogenomic interaction.  4. **Empirical Data Supporting SLC6A4-Fluoxetine Interaction:** The use of the Transmission Disequilibrium Test (TDT) in a family study design to test the linkage disequilibrium between OCD and alleles at the SLC6A4 promoter polymorphic locus provides empirical evidence. The findings that certain alleles (‘l’) are more likely to be transmitted in the context of OCD, especially among SRI drug (including Fluoxetine) nonresponders, underscores a potential genetic interaction influencing drug response.  5. **Statistical Significance and Clinical Implications:** The statistical data presented (chi-square values and P-values) support the association and linkage disequilibrium, suggesting a clinically relevant genetic interaction that might influence treatment outcomes in patients using Fluoxetine.  Together, these points ensure that the abstract is not only relevant but also critical in evaluating the interaction between Fluoxetine and the gene SLC6A4. This interaction is pivotal for understanding treatment responses and could contribute to more personalized medicine approaches in managing OCD.

abstract: Recent key findings from studies of SLC6A4 and its related protein, the serotonin (5-HT) transporter (SERT) in humans, rodents, and nonhuman primates indicate that combinations of the SLC6A4 noncoding 5', 3' UTRs, and intronic regions by coding variants that together act, can alter 5HT transport 40-fold in vitro. In vivo, SLC6A4 variants in humans and other species cause marked physiological changes, despite the attenuation of neurodevelopmental adaptations of 5-HT receptors, plus compensatory changes in 5-HT synthesis and metabolism. Polymorphisms in SLC6A4 are associated with differences in emotional, endocrine, and personality traits, as well as with many diseases. These genes, in combination with gene×gene (G×G) and gene×environment (G×E) interactions, however, remain incompletely understood, and some association findings remain controversial. Given its primary importance in the regulation and function of the entire serotonergic system (as evidenced by the effects of SERT-mediated reuptake inhibition such as fluoxetine in humans and genetically engineered alterations in mice and rats), SLC6A4 and SERT are likely to remain areas of high interest in our field's efforts to better understand and treat 5-HT related disorders.
cot: The abstract discusses the SLC6A4 gene and its product, the serotonin transporter (SERT), focusing on their roles and variability due to genetic differences, and how these contribute to physiological and behavioral traits. It also touches on the impact of SERT reuptake inhibition by serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SRIs) such as fluoxetine (a commonly known SRI). Here are key points that determine the relevance of this abstract to the proposed hypothesis that there exists an interaction between the drug fluoxetine and the gene SLC6A4:  1. **Direct Reference to Fluoxetine and SLC6A4**: The abstract explicitly mentions fluoxetine, showing its role in SERT-mediated reuptake inhibition. Given that SERT is the product of the SLC6A4 gene, there is a direct connection between fluoxetine and its pharmacological effect on a mechanism influenced by this gene.  2. **Significance of SERT (product of SLC6A4) in Fluoxetine Action**: Mention of how the inhibition of SERT reuptake by fluoxetine impacts the serotonergic system signifies a direct biochemical pathway involving SLC6A4 and the drug fluoxetine. This is key because the serotonergic system's regulation, facilitated by SLC6A4, is directly targeted by fluoxetine.  3. **Discussion on Regulatory Mechanisms**: The abstract discusses the broader regulatory implications of SLC6A4 in serotonergic system functioning. abstract: A hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir is strongly associated with the presence of the HLA-B*5701 allele. This study was designed to prospectively determine the efficacy of HLA-B*5701 screening in preventing hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir. This double-blind, prospective, randomized study involved 1,956 patients from 19 countries who were infected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 and who had not previously received abacavir. We randomized patients to prospective HLA-B*5701 screening, excluding HLA-B*5701-positive patients from abacavir treatment (prospective screening group), or a standard-of-care approach to using abacavir without prospective. HLA-B*5701 screening (control group). All patients who started abacavir were followed for 6 weeks. To immunologically confirm and enhance the specificity of the clinical diagnosis of a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir, we performed an epicutaneous patch test using abacavir. The prevalence of HLA-B*5701 was 5.6% (109 of 1956 patients). Of the patients receiving abacavir, 72% were male, 84% were white, and 18% had not received prior antiretroviral therapy. Screening eliminated immunologically confirmed hypersensitivity reactions (0% in the prospective screening group v. 2.7% in the control group, P<0.001), with a negative predictive value of 100% and a positive predictive value of 47.9%. A hypersensitivity reaction was clinically diagnosed in 93 patients, with a significantly lower incidence in the prospective screening group (3.4%) than in the control group (7.8%) (P<0.001). HLA-B*5701 screening reduced the risk of hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir. In predominantly white populations, as in this study, 94% of patients do not carry the HLA-B*5701 allele and are at low risk for a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. Our results show that a pharmacogenetic test can be used to rule out drug-specific toxic effects. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00340080.)

abstract: The use of abacavir, a potent HIV-1 nucleoside analog-reverse-transcriptase inhibitor, is complicated by life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome in approximately 5% of cases. Genetic factors that influence the immune response to abacavir may result in susceptibility. We aimed to find associations between MHC alleles and abacavir hypersensitivity in HIV-1-positive individuals treated with abacavir. MHC region typing was performed in the first 200 participants exposed to abacavir in the Western Australian HIV Cohort Study. Definite abacavir hypersensitivity was identified in 18 cases and excluded in 167 individuals exposed to the drug for more than six weeks (abacavir tolerant). 15 people developed some symptoms but did not meet the criteria for abacavir hypersensitivity. p values ​​were corrected for multiple HLA allele comparisons (p(c)) by multiplying the raw p value by the estimated number of HLA alleles present at the examined loci. HLA-B*5701 was present in 14 of 18 (78%) abacavir-sensitive patients and four (2%) of 167 abacavir-tolerant patients (odds ratio 117 [95% CI 29-481], p(c )<0.0001), while The combination of HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 was found in 13 (72%) hypersensitive and five (3%) tolerant patients (73 [20-268], p(c)<0.0001). HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 were present in combination in 13 (72%) hypersensitive patients and in none of the tolerant patients (822 [43-15 675], p(c)<0.0001). Other MHC markers were also present on the 57.1 pedigree haplotype to which the above three markers belong, confirming the existence of haplotype-specific linkage disequilibrium and mapping potential susceptibility loci to the region bounded by C4A6 and HLA-C. In the entire abacavir exposure cohort (n=200), the presence of HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 had a positive predictive value for hypersensitivity of 100% and a negative predictive value of 97%. Genetic susceptibility to abacavir hypersensitivity is carried on the ancestral haplotype 57.1. In our population, withholding abacavir in patients with HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 should reduce the prevalence of hypersensitivity from 9% to 2.5% without inappropriate rejection of abacavir in any patient.

abstract: Hypersensitivity to abacavir affects approximately 4% of patients receiving the drug for HIV-1 infection. We performed a retrospective, case-control study to identify multiple markers in the vicinity of HLA-B associated with hypersensitivity reactions. HLA-B57 was present in 39 (46%) of 84 patients and 4 (4%) of 113 controls (p<0 small midpoint0001). However, due to the low numbers of women and other ethnic groups, these findings apply mainly to white men. The lower sensitivity of HLA-B57 for predicting hypersensitivity to abacavir in this study compared to a previous report highlights that the predictive values ​​of the markers vary by population. Clinical monitoring and management of hypersensitivity reactions in patients receiving abacavir should remain unchanged.

abstract: Human leukocyte antigens (HLA) are highly polymorphic proteins that initiate immunity by presenting pathogen-derived peptides to T-cells. HLA polymorphism mostly reflects the antigen-binding cleft, thereby diversifying the repertoire of self-developed and pathogen-derived peptide antigens selected by different HLA allotypes. An increasing number of immunologically based drug reactions, including abacavir hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) and carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), are associated with specific HLA alleles. However, little is known about the mechanisms underlying these associations, including AHS, the prototypical HLA-associated drug reaction, which occurs exclusively in individuals with the common histocompatibility allele HLA-B*57:01 and a relative risk of more than 1000 (refs 6, 7 ). We show that intact abacavir binds non-covalently to HLA-B*57:01, lies at the bottom of the antigen-binding cleft and accesses the F-pocket, where the carboxy-terminal tryptophan typically anchors HLA-B-binding peptides. *57:01. Abacavir binds HLA-B*57:01 with exquisite specificity, altering the shape and chemistry of the antigen-binding cleft, thereby altering the repertoire of endogenous peptides capable of binding HLA-B*57:01. In this way, abacavir directs the selection of new endogenous peptides, leading to a noticeable change in the "immunological self". The resulting peptide-centric “altered self” activates abacavir-specific T-cells, leading to the activation of polyclonal CD8 T-cells and a systemic response manifesting as AHS. We also show that carbamazepine, a widely used antiepileptic drug associated with hypersensitivity reactions in HLA-B*15:02 individuals, binds to this allotype and produces changes in the repertoire of self-peptides presented. Our findings both highlight the importance of HLA polymorphisms in the evolution of pharmacogenomics and provide a general mechanism for some of the growing number of HLA-related hypersensitivity cases involving small molecule drugs.
