abstract: Advances in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, especially with regard to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, require regular updating of concepts and management. An expert panel of the European Leukemia Network reviewed previous and new studies to update the recommendations made in 2009. We recommend imatinib, nilotinib or dasatinib as initial treatment. Response is assessed by standardized real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction and/or cytogenetics at 3, 6, and 12 months. BCR-ABL1 transcript levels ≤10% at 3 months, <1% at 6 months, and ≤0.1% at 12 months onwards define optimal response, while >10% at 6 months and >1% at 12 months define failure, mandating treatment change. Similarly, a partial cytogenetic response (PCyR) at 3 months and a complete cytogenetic response (CCyR) from 6 months onward define an optimal response, with CyR (Philadelphia chromosome-positive [Ph+] > 95%) at 3 months less than PCyR at 6 months. months and less than CCyR beyond 12 months defines failure. Between optimal and failure is an intermediate warning zone that requires more frequent monitoring. Similar definitions are given for response to second-line therapy. Specific recommendations are given for patients in accelerated and blast phase and for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Optimal responders should continue therapy indefinitely with careful monitoring, or may be enrolled in controlled trials of treatment discontinuation once a deep molecular response is achieved.

abstract: Although the role of hedgehog (Hh) signaling in embryonic patterning is well established, its functions in adult tissue renewal and maintenance remain unclear, and the relationship of these functions to cancer development has not been established. Here we show that loss of Smoothened (Smo), an essential component of the Hh pathway, inhibits hematopoietic stem cell renewal and reduces induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) by the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Loss of Smo leads to depletion of CML stem cells—the cells that propagate leukemia—and constitutively active Smo increases the number of CML stem cells and accelerates the disease. As a possible mechanism of Smo action, we show that the cell fate determinant Numb, which downregulates CML stem cells, is increased in the absence of Smo activity. Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of Hh signaling inhibits not only the proliferation of CML induced by wild-type BCR-ABL1, but also the growth of imatinib-resistant murine and human CML. These data indicate that Hh pathway activity is required for the maintenance of normal and neoplastic stem cells in the hematopoietic system and raise the possibility that drug resistance and disease relapse associated with imatinib treatment of CML may be avoided by targeting this essential pathway for stem cell maintenance.

abstract: There is considerable variability in the level of molecular responses achieved with imatinib therapy in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These differences may be due to variable therapy adherence. Eighty-seven patients with chronic-phase CML treated with imatinib 400 mg/day for a median of 59.7 months (range, 25 to 104 months) who achieved a complete cytogenetic response were followed for 3 months for compliance using microelectronic monitoring. device. Adherence was correlated with molecular response levels. Other factors that may influence the result are also analyzed. The median adherence rate was 98% (range, 24% - 104%). Twenty-three patients (26.4%) had adherence <or= 90%; In 12 of these patients (14%), adherence was <or= 80%. There was a strong correlation between the adherence rate (<or= 90% or > 90%) and the 6-year probability of a 3-log reduction (also known as major molecular response [MMR]) in BCR-ABL1 transcripts (28.4%). v 94.5%; P < .001) as well as complete molecular response (CMR; 0% v 43.8%; P = .002). Multivariate analysis revealed adherence (relative risk [RR], 11.7; P = .001) and human molecular organic cation transporter-1 (RR, 1.79; P = .038) expression as the only independent predictors of MMR. Adherence was the only independent predictor of CMR. No molecular responses were observed when adherence was < or = 80% (P < .001). Patients whose imatinib doses were increased had poor adherence (86.4%). In the latter population, adherence was the only independent predictor of failure to achieve MMR (RR, 17.66; P = .006). In CML patients treated with imatinib for several years, poor adherence may be the main reason for failure to obtain adequate molecular responses.

abstract: Imatinib, a selective BCR-ABL1 kinase inhibitor, improves prognosis in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). We performed efficacy and safety analyzes based on more than 10 years of follow-up in CML patients treated with imatinib as initial therapy. In this open-label, multicenter study with a crossover design, we randomly assigned patients with newly diagnosed CML in chronic phase to receive either imatinib or interferon alfa plus cytarabine. Long-term analyzes included overall survival, response to treatment, and serious adverse events. Median follow-up was 10.9 years. Given the high crossover rate among patients randomized to interferon alfa plus cytarabine (65.6%) and the short duration of therapy before crossover in these patients (median, 0.8 years), the current analyzes focused on patients randomized to imatinib. Among patients in the imatinib group, the overall survival rate at 10 years was 83.3%. Approximately half (48.3%) of patients randomized to imatinib completed study treatment with imatinib, and 82.8% had a complete cytogenetic response. Serious side effects that the researchers considered to be related to imatinib were rare and most often occurred during the first year of treatment. A nearly 11-year follow-up showed that the efficacy of imatinib was maintained over time and that long-term imatinib administration was not associated with unacceptable cumulative or late toxic effects. (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals; IRIS ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00006343 and NCT00333840 .).

abstract: The HER2 gene, which codes for the growth factor receptor HER2, is amplified and HER2 is overexpressed in 25 to 30 percent of breast cancers, making the tumor more aggressive. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We randomized 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) anthracycline therapy were treated with doxorubicin (or epirubicin in 36 women) and either cyclophosphamide (138 women) or trastuzumab (143 women) alone. Patients previously receiving adjuvant anthracycline were treated with paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel with trastuzumab (92 women). The addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with longer time to disease progression (median, 7.4 vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001), higher objective response rate (50 percent vs. 32 percent, P<0.001), longer duration of response (median, 9.1 vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), lower mortality at 1 year (22 percent vs. 33 percent, P=0.008), longer survival (median survival, 25.1 vs. 20.3 months; P=0.01), and a 20 percent reduction in the risk of death. The most important adverse event was New York Heart Association class III or IV cardiac dysfunction, which occurred in 27 percent of the group receiving anthracycline, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab; 8 percent of the group received anthracycline and cyclophosphamide alone; 13 percent of the paclitaxel and trastuzumab group; and 1 percent of the group given paclitaxel alone. Although cardiotoxicity was potentially severe and, in some cases, life-threatening, symptoms generally improved with standard medical management. Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy in HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer.

abstract: Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), has been investigated in combination with chemotherapy for the first-line treatment of HER2-positive gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. ToGA (trastuzumab for gastric cancer) was an open-label, international, phase 3, randomized controlled trial conducted at 122 centers in 24 countries. Patients with gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer were eligible for inclusion if their tumors demonstrated HER2 protein overexpression by immunohistochemistry or gene amplification by fluorescence in-situ hybridization. Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive a chemotherapy regimen consisting of capecitabine plus cisplatin or fluorouracil plus cisplatin given every 3 weeks for six cycles or chemotherapy plus intravenous trastuzumab. Allocation was by block randomization, stratified by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, chemotherapy regimen, disease severity, primary cancer location, and disease measurement implemented by a central interactive voice recognition system. The primary endpoint was overall survival in all randomized patients who received study medication at least once. This trial is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01041404. 594 patients were randomly assigned to study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n=298; chemotherapy alone, n=296), of whom 584 were included in the primary analysis (n=294; n=290). Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11–25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9–25) in the chemotherapy alone group. Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12–16) among patients assigned to trastuzumab plus chemotherapy compared with 11.1 months (10–13) among those assigned to chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio 0.74; 95% CI 0 .60-0.91 p=; 0.0046). The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] vs chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] vs 134 [46%]), and neutropenia (157 . [53%] vs. 165 [57%]). The incidence of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs 18 [6%]) did not differ between groups. Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy may be considered a new standard option for patients with HER2-positive gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. F Hoffmann-La Roche.

abstract: We present the combined results of two studies that compared adjuvant chemotherapy with or without concomitant trastuzumab in women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. The National Breast and Bowel Surgical Adjuvant Project study B-31 compared doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel every 3 weeks (group 1) with the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab starting with the first dose of paclitaxel (group 2). The North Central Cancer Treatment Group study N9831 compared three regimens: doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by weekly paclitaxel (group A), the same regimen followed by 52 weeks of trastuzumab followed by paclitaxel (group B), and the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab starting. with paclitaxel (group C) at the same time. The studies were modified to include a pooled analysis comparing groups 1 and A (the control group) with groups 2 and C (the trastuzumab group). Group B was excluded because trastuzumab was not given with paclitaxel. As of March 15, 2005, there were 394 events (recurrence, second primary cancer, or death before recurrence), leading to the first planned interim analysis. Of these, 133 were in the trastuzumab group and 261 in the control group (hazard ratio, 0.48; P<0.0001). This result crossed the early stop line. The absolute difference in disease-free survival between the trastuzumab group and the control group was 12 percent at three years. Trastuzumab therapy was associated with a 33 percent reduction in the risk of death (P=0.015). The three-year cumulative incidence of class III or IV congestive heart failure or death from cardiac causes in the trastuzumab arm was 4.1 percent in trial B-31 and 2.9 percent in trial N9831. Trastuzumab plus paclitaxel after doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide improves outcomes in women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov numbers, NCT00004067 and NCT00005970.)

abstract: Trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody against HER2, has clinical activity in advanced breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We investigated its efficacy and safety after excision of early-stage breast cancer and completion of chemotherapy. This international, multicenter, randomized trial compared one or two years of trastuzumab given every three weeks with observation in patients with HER2-positive and node-negative or node-positive breast cancer who had completed locoregional therapy and at least four cycles of neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy. Data were available for 1,694 women randomly assigned to two years of trastuzumab treatment, 1,694 women assigned to one year of trastuzumab, and 1,693 women assigned to observation. We report here only the results of trastuzumab treatment at one year or follow-up. At the first planned interim analysis (median follow-up of one year), there were 347 events (breast cancer recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, second non-breast malignancy, or death): 127 events in the trastuzumab group and 220 in the observation group. The unadjusted hazard ratio for an event in the trastuzumab group compared with the observation group was 0.54 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.67; P<0.0001 by log-rank test, cutoff for interim analysis), representing an absolute benefit in disease-free survival at two years by 8.4 percentage points. Overall survival was not significantly different between the two groups (29 deaths with trastuzumab and 37 with observation). Severe cardiotoxicity occurred in 0.5 percent of women treated with trastuzumab. One-year treatment with trastuzumab after adjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves disease-free survival in women with HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00045032.)

abstract: The clinical success of selective kinase inhibitors such as imatinib and erlotinib as therapeutic agents for several human cancers has led to significant interest in the further development and clinical testing of such inhibitors for a wide range of malignancies. While much of this effort has focused on receptor tyrosine kinases, including EGFR, HER2, the PDGF receptor, c-KIT, and MET, inhibitors of serine/threonine kinases are also beginning to emerge in the discovery pipelines. Among these kinases, the RAF and MEK kinases have received considerable attention, mainly due to the relatively high frequency of activating mutations in RAS (about 20% of all human cancers), an upstream activator of the well-established RAF-MEK-ERK signaling cascade. , as well as frequent activating mutations in BRAF kinase (about 7% of all human cancers). Here, we summarize the current state of development of kinase inhibitors targeting this signaling pathway, several of which are already showing favorable toxicity profiles as well as promising activity in early phase clinical trials.

abstract: Targeted therapy with compounds that inhibit a specific target molecule represents a new perspective in cancer treatment. Unlike conventional chemotherapy, which affects all dividing cells, produces toxic effects and damages normal tissues, targeted drugs allow for a more specific targeting of cell subpopulations directly involved in tumor progression. Molecules that control cell proliferation and death, such as receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) for growth factors, are the best targets for this type of therapeutic approach. Two classes of compounds targeting RTKs are currently used in clinical practice: monoclonal antibodies and tyrosine kinase inhibitors. The era of targeted therapy began with the approval of trastuzumab, a HER2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer, and imatinib, a small tyrosine kinase inhibitor that targets BCR-Abl, in chronic myeloid leukemia. Despite initial enthusiasm for the efficacy of these treatments, clinicians soon faced the problem of relapse, as almost invariably cancer patients developed drug resistance, often due to activation of alternative RTKs pathways. In this sense, the rationale behind drug targeting changes radically. In the past, major efforts have focused on developing highly specific inhibitors that target individual RTKs. Now, there is general agreement that molecules that interfere with multiple RTKs simultaneously may be more effective than single-target agents. With the recent FDA approval of Sorafenib and Sunitinib—targeting VEGFR, PDGFR, FLT-3, and c-Kit—a different scenario is emerging, with a new generation of anticancer drugs that can inhibit more than one pathway. , will probably play the main role.

abstract: The emerging field of personalized medicine is playing an increasingly important role in cancer prevention, diagnosis, prognosis, and therapy. Its importance in clinical management is demonstrated by the recent introduction of various individualized, molecularly targeted therapies with increased efficacy and/or reduced toxicity into routine clinical practice. The identification of cancer susceptibility genes, such as the BRCA genes in breast cancer, enables screening programs to identify patients at risk of developing cancer and helps them make decisions about individual risk-modifying behaviors. Personalized medicine is also playing an increasingly important role in cancer treatment. It is becoming increasingly clear that there are molecularly distinct subtypes of different common cancers, with different therapeutic approaches required for each subtype, such as the use of monoclonal antibodies (trastuzumab and cetuximab) in HER2-positive breast cancer and wild-type KRAS colorectal cancer. cancer Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib, gefitinib, erlotinib and crizotinib) in chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors and non-small cell lung cancer and intracellular agents (vemurafenib and olaparib) in metastatic and malignant breast cancer, melanoma. The efficacy of various targeted therapies in such diverse tumors suggests that we are entering an era where treatment decisions will be based on the tumor's molecular pathology profile or "signature" rather than on tumor tissue type or anatomic site of origin, improving patient prognosis and quality of life. of life. This mini-review focuses on the role of personalized medicine in cancer prevention and treatment, as well as its future direction in oncology.

abstract: The strong clinical activity of imatinib and trastuzumab in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and breast cancer has shown that blocking pathogenic tyrosine kinases can alter the natural history of human tumors. On the other hand, EGF receptor inhibitors have shown overall modest activity. The contrast in the development of these agents implies that both molecular target dependence and patient selection are necessary for a successful outcome of this process. We will dissect the lessons learned from the development of Abl, c-Kit, HER2/neu (erbB2), and EGFR inhibitors, highlight successes and limitations in the field, and suggest new approaches for the clinical development of tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy.

abstract: Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, the two main types of chronic inflammatory bowel disease, are multifactorial conditions of unknown etiology. A locus for susceptibility to Crohn's disease has been mapped to chromosome 16. Here, we used a positional cloning strategy based on linkage analysis followed by linkage disequilibrium mapping to identify three independent associations with Crohn's disease: a frameshift variant and two missense variants. NOD2, which encodes a member of the Apaf-1/Ced-4 superfamily of apoptosis regulators, is expressed in monocytes. These NOD2 variants alter the structure or surrounding region of the protein or the leucine-rich repeat domain. NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kB; This activating function is regulated by a carboxy-terminal leucine-rich repeat domain that has an inhibitory role and also acts as an intracellular receptor for components of microbial pathogens. These observations suggest that the NOD2 gene product confers susceptibility to Crohn's disease by altering the recognition of these components and/or by overactivating NF-kB in monocytes, thus supporting a molecular model of the pathogenic mechanism of Crohn's disease that is now available further. investigated.

abstract: Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract believed to be caused by exposure to environmental factors in a genetically predisposed host. The location of a gene in the pericentromeric region of chromosome 16, IBD1, that contributes to susceptibility to Crohn's disease has been established by multiple linkage studies, but the specific gene(s) has not been identified. NOD2, a gene that encodes a protein with homology to plant disease resistance gene products, is located on chromosome 16 in a linkage peak (rev. 7). Here we show, using a transmission disequilibrium test and a case-control analysis, that a cytosine insertion frameshift mutation, 3020insC, predicted to encode the NOD2 protein, is associated with Crohn's disease. Wild-type NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kappaB, making it responsive to bacterial lipopolysaccharides; However, this induction was deficient in mutant NOD2. These results implicate NOD2 susceptibility to Crohn's disease and suggest a link between the innate immune response to bacterial components and disease development.

abstract: Nod2 activates the NF-kappaB pathway after intracellular stimulation by bacterial products. Recently, mutations in Nod2 have been associated with Crohn's disease, suggesting a role for bacteria-host interactions in the etiology of this disorder. We show here that Nod2 is a general peptidoglycan sensor by recognizing muramyl dipeptide (MDP), a minimal bioactive peptidoglycan motif common to all bacteria. Moreover, the 3020insC frameshift mutation, the most frequent Nod2 variant associated with Crohn's disease patients, completely impairs Nod2-dependent detection of peptidoglycan and MDP. Together, these results have implications for understanding the development of Crohn's disease. Furthermore, the characterization of Nod2 as the first pathogen-recognition molecule that detects MDP will help unravel the well-known biological activities of this immunomodulatory compound.

abstract: Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs), Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis are chronic inflammatory disorders of the gastrointestinal tract. Recently, tremendous progress has been made in understanding the pathogenesis of these diseases. Studies in patients and mouse models have shown that Crohn's disease is caused by the production of interleukin-12 (IL-12) and interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), and ulcerative colitis is believed to be caused by the production of IL. -13. A second area of ​​progress is identifying the specific genetic abnormalities responsible for the disease. The most important finding is the identification of mutations in the gene encoding the NOD2 (nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 2) protein in a subset of patients with Crohn's disease. Here we discuss these recent findings and the implications for therapy.

This direct reference to genetic abnormalities in NOD2 in relation to Crohn's disease directly supports the hypothesis of an interaction between the disease and this specific gene.  3. **Link to Disease Mechanisms**: By identifying mutations in the NOD2 gene among patients, the abstract underscores a genetic basis for the manifestation and perhaps the severity or progression of Crohn's disease. abstract: CARD15/NOD2 mutations are associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). CD and GVHD are thought to be related to dysfunction of Peyer's patches (PP) and isolated lymphoid follicles (LFs). Using a novel Card15/Nod2 (KO) knockout mouse model, we analyzed the effect of the gene in these lymphoid formations along with the development of experimental colitis. At weeks 4, 12, and 52, the number of PPs and LFs was higher in KO mice, while no difference was observed at birth. At weeks 4 and 12, the size and cellular composition of PPs were analyzed by flow cytometry and immunohistochemistry. PPs of KO mice were larger with an increased proportion of M cells and CD4(+) T-cells. KO mice were also characterized by higher concentrations of TNFalpha, IFNgamma, IL12 and IL4 as measured by ELISA. In contrast, small differences were observed in PP-free ileum and spleen of KO mice. Using chamber experiments, we found that this PP phenotype is associated with both paracellular permeability and yeast/bacterial translocation. Finally, KO mice were more susceptible to TNBS-induced colitis. Card15/Nod2 deficiency results in abnormal development and function of PPs, characterized by an exaggerated immune response and increased permeability. These observations provide a comprehensive link between the molecular defect and human CARD15/NOD2-associated disorders: CD and GVHD.

abstract: GATA3 is a transcription factor that regulates T cell production of cytokines. We investigated the role of GATA3 in the development of colitis in mice. We performed quantitative polymerase chain reaction and immunofluorescence analyzes of colonic tissues from patients with Crohn's disease (n = 61) or ulcerative colitis (UC, n = 74) or without inflammatory bowel disease (n = 22) to measure GATA3 levels. . Colitis was induced by administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid to control mice, mice with T-specific deletion of GATA3, and mice with deletion of tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) 1 and TNFR2 (TNFR double knockouts). ); Some mice were given GATA3-specific DNAzyme (hgd40) or control DNAzyme by intrarectal administration or systemic injections of antibodies to TNF before or during the sensitization and challenge phase of colitis induction. Colon tissues were collected and immunofluorescence and histochemical analyzes were performed. Lamina propria mononuclear cells and T cells were isolated and analyzed by flow cytometry or cytokine analysis. Colonic distribution of labeled DNAzyme and inflammation were monitored by in vivo imaging (endoscopy) in mice. GATA3 messenger RNA levels were higher in colon tissues from patients with UC but not ileal Crohn's disease than in control tissues; GATA3 levels correlate with levels of inflammatory cytokines (interleukin [IL] 9, IL17A, IL6, IL5, IL4, IL13, and TNF). We observed increased expression of GATA3 by lamina propria T cells from mice with colitis compared with controls. Mice with a T-specific deletion of GATA3 did not develop colitis, and their colon tissues did not produce inflammatory cytokines (IL6, IL9, or IL13). DNAzyme hgd40 inhibited GATA3 messenger RNA expression by unstimulated and stimulated T cells and was distributed in the inflamed colon of mice with colitis. Colon tissues from mice given hgd40 had reduced GATA3 messenger RNA expression compared to mice given control DNAzyme. Mice given hgd40 did not develop colitis after administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid; Lamina propria cells from these mice expressed lower levels of IL6, IL9, and IL13 than cells from control DNAzyme-treated mice. Mini-endoscopic images showed that hgd40 and anti-TNF reduced colonic inflammation over 3 days; hgd40 reduces colitis in TNFR double knockout mice. GATA3 levels are increased in patients with UC and correlate with inflammatory cytokine production in mice and humans. A DNAzyme that inhibits GATA3 expression reduces colitis in mice independently of TNF and reduces cytokine levels in the colon. This DNAzyme could be developed to treat patients with UC.

abstract: Geographic and ethnic variations in the incidence of ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease suggest that environmental factors influence disease risk. Prevention of parasitic worms (helminths) through improved hygiene may be one of the factors leading to increased disease prevalence. Helminths alter the host's mucosal and systemic immunity. Animals exposed to helminths are protected from experimental colitis and other immunological diseases, and helminthic colonization can be used to treat ongoing disease in mice and humans. Helminths induce mucosal T cells to produce Th2 and regulatory cytokines. Helminth-induced mucosal IL4, TGFbeta and IL10 are likely part of the protective process. Helminths affect innate immunity pathways such as TLR4 expression and function. Worms also induce different regulatory T-cell subsets in the gut that limit the growth and function of effector T-cells. These effects of once-present helminths may protect humans from immune-mediated diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.

abstract: About 70 loci have been associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD), particularly in the innate immunity, autophagy, and pathogen recognition pathways. Phenotype-genotype associations are inconsistent. CD susceptibility polymorphisms ATG16L1 rs2241880, ICAM1 rs5498, IL4 rs2070874, IL17F rs763780, IRGM rs13361189, ITLN1 rs2274910, LRR374910, LRR 0 were genotyped in a Portuguese population of 511 patients 26 controls) and assessed for association with CD clinical features. There is a significant association of CD with single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in ATG16L1 (odds ratio [OR] 1.36 [1.15-1.60], P = 2.7 × 10(-6) for allele G), IRGM (OR 1.56 [1.21). -1.93], P = 3.9 × 10(-4) for C allele) and ITLN1 (OR 1.55 [1.28-1.88], P = 4.9 × 10(-4) for C allele ). This SNP was associated with ileal location (OR, 1.49, 1.52, and 1.70, respectively), ileocolonic location (OR, 1.31, 1.57, and 1.68, respectively), and upper digestive tract involvement (OR, 1.96 and 1.95 for ATGIRGM and ATG16L1, respectively. ). The risk genotype GG in ATG16L1 was associated with patients responding to steroids (OR 1.89), responding to immunosuppressants (OR 1.77) and biological therapy (OR 1.89). SNPs in ITLN1 and IRGM are both associated with positive response to biologic therapy. The risk of ileal, ileocolonic, and upper digestive tract location increases with the number of risk alleles (OR for the three alleles, 7.10, 3.54, and 12.07, respectively); The OR for positive response to biologic therapy is 3.66. A multilocus approach using autophagy-related genes provides insight into CD phenotype-genotype associations and genetic markers to predict therapeutic responses.

abstract: Schizophrenia is a very hereditary disease. Genetic risk is caused by a large number of alleles, including common alleles of small effect, which can be detected by genome-wide association studies. Here we report a multilevel genome-wide association study of schizophrenia with up to 36,989 cases and 113,075 controls. We identify 128 independent associations involving 108 conservatively defined loci that meet genome-wide significance, 83 of which have not been previously reported. Associations were enriched between genes expressed in the brain, providing biological plausibility to the findings. Many findings have the potential to provide entirely new insights into etiology, but associations with DRD2 and several genes involved in glutamatergic neurotransmission highlight molecules of known and potential therapeutic relevance to schizophrenia and are consistent with leading pathophysiological hypotheses. Independent of genes expressed in the brain, associations were enriched among genes expressed in tissues with important roles in immunity, supporting the speculated link between the immune system and schizophrenia.

abstract: In an attempt to identify potential genetic risk factors for schizophrenia, research groups around the world have published more than 1,000 genetic association studies, with largely inconsistent results. To facilitate the interpretation of these findings, we created a regularly updated online database of all published genetic association studies in schizophrenia ("SzGene"). For all polymorphisms for which genotype data were available in at least four independent case-control samples, we systematically performed a random-effects meta-analysis using allelic contrasts. A meta-analysis of 118 showed a total of 24 genetic variants in 16 different genes (APOE, COMT, DAO, DRD1, DRD2, DRD4, DTNBP1, GABRB2, GRIN2B, HP, IL1B, MTHFR, PLXNA2, SLC534) and nominally significant effects with mean summary odds ratios of approximately 1.23. . Seven of these options have not previously been meta-analysed. According to recently proposed criteria for evaluating cumulative evidence in genetic association studies, four significant results can be characterized as showing “strong” epidemiologic reliability. Our project is the first comprehensive online resource for systematically synthesizing and qualitative evidence from genetic association studies in schizophrenia. As such, it may serve as a model for wild synopses of genetic associations in other common and genetically complex disorders.

abstract: Although nucleotide sequence changes are known to affect protein composition and structure, functional changes caused by nucleotide substitutions cannot always be inferred from simple DNA sequence analysis. Because a strong synonymous codon usage bias in the human DRD2 gene, suggesting selection at synonymous positions, was revealed by the relative independence of G+C content of third codon positions from isochore G+C frequencies, we decided to investigate functional effects. Of the six known naturally occurring synonymous changes (C132T, G423A, T765C, C939T, C957T, and G1101A) in human DRD2. We report here that some synonymous mutations in human DRD2 have functional effects and suggest a novel genetic mechanism. 957T, rather than being “silent,” altered predicted mRNA folding, reduced mRNA stability and translation, and dramatically reversed dopamine-induced regulation of DRD2 expression. 1101A showed no effect by itself, but abrogated the aforementioned effects of 957T in the compound clone 957T/1101A, demonstrating that combinations of synonymous mutations can have functional consequences markedly different from each isolated mutation. C957T was found to be a linkage disequilibrium in a European-American population with -141C Ins/Del and TaqI 'A' variants associated with schizophrenia and alcoholism, respectively. These results question some assumptions about synonymous variation in molecular population genetics and gene mapping studies of complex inherited diseases and indicate that synonymous variation may have effects of potential pathophysiological and pharmacogenetic significance.

abstract: - The A1 allele of the Taq I polymorphism of the dopamine D2 receptor (DRD2) gene has previously been reported in 69% of alcoholics compared to 20% of controls. Other studies have found no significant difference in the prevalence of the A1 allele in alcoholics and controls, and there is no evidence that the DRD2 gene is associated with alcoholism. We hypothesized that these seemingly contradictory results may be because the increased prevalence of the A1 allele may not be specific to alcoholism. Thus, we investigated other disorders that are often associated with alcoholism or disorders that are thought to be associated with defects in dopaminergic neurotransmission. -- A case comparison study. To minimize the effect of racial differences in gene frequencies, the study was limited to non-Hispanic whites. --Ambulatory and hospitalized patients. -- Among all known controls (n = 314), 77 (24.5%) carried the A1 allele. Of the 69 controls known not to be alcoholics, 10 (14.5%) carried the A1 allele. The prevalence of A1 allele was significantly increased in patients with Tourette syndrome (44.9%, n = 147), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (46.2%, n = 104), autism (54.5%, n = 33), alcoholism (42.3%). , n = 104) and post-traumatic stress disorder (45.7%, n = 35). After adjustment for multiple comparisons (significance required P less than .0009), all remained significant except PTSD. The prevalence of the A1 allele was not significantly increased in patients with depression, panic attacks, Parkinson's disease, or obesity. The prevalence of the A1 allele in drug addicts and schizophrenia was significant only when compared to non-alcoholic controls, and no adjustment was made for multiple comparisons. --These results suggest that the A1 allele of the DRD2 gene is associated with a number of behavioral disorders in which it may act as a modifier gene rather than as a primary etiological agent.

abstract: Velo-cardio-facial syndrome (VCFS), a syndrome characterized by an increased incidence of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, is associated with small interstitial deletions on chromosome 22q11. We assessed 50 adults with VCFS using a structured clinical interview (Clinical Assessment Schedule in Neuropsychiatry or Psychiatric Assessment Schedule for Adults with Developmental Disabilities if IQ < 50) for DSM-IV diagnosis. The schizophrenia phenotype in individuals with VCFS and schizophrenia was compared to a matched series of individuals with schizophrenia and without VCFS (n = 12). The King Schizotypy Questionnaire was administered to individuals with VCFS (n = 41), their first-degree relatives (n = 68), and a series of unrelated normal controls (n = 316). All individuals with VCFS deleted for the N25 probe (n = 48) were genotyped for a genetic polymorphism in the COMT gene that causes variations in enzyme activity. Fifteen people (30%) with VCFS had a psychotic disorder, with 24% (n = 12) meeting DSM-IV criteria for schizophrenia. In addition, 6 (12%) had severe depression without psychotic features. Individuals with schizophrenia had fewer negative symptoms and a relatively later age of onset than those with schizophrenia and without VCFS. We found no evidence that possession of a low-activity COMT allele was associated with schizophrenia in our sample of patients with VCFS. The high prevalence of schizophrenia in this group suggests that chromosome 22q11 may contain a gene or genes relevant to the etiology of schizophrenia in the general population.

abstract: It has been common for psychiatric research, including the search for predisposing genes, to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder as distinctly different illnesses. This represents Emil Kraepelin's traditional dichotomous classification of the so-called "functional" psychoses and forms the basis of modern diagnostic practice. However, findings from many areas of psychiatric research do not fit this model well. In particular, a pattern of findings from genetic studies shows increasing evidence of overlap in genetic susceptibility across traditional classification categories—including association findings for DAOA(G72), DTNBP1 (dysbindin), COMT, BDNF, DISC1, and NRG1. Findings suggest the possibility of a relatively specific relationship between genotype and psychopathology. For example, DISC1 and NRG1 may predispose to a form of illness with mixed features of schizophrenia and mania. Elucidation of the genotype-phenotype relationship is in its infancy, but the current findings highlight the need for psychiatric research to consider alternative approaches to classification and conceptualization rather than continuing to rely on the traditional Kraepelinian dichotomy. As psychosis susceptibility genes are identified and characterized over the next few years, this will greatly impact our understanding of the pathophysiology of the disease and lead to changes in classification and clinical practice in psychiatry.

abstract: The variability of phenotypic presentations and the lack of genetic associations in mental illness remain a major challenge in molecular psychiatry. Recently, it has become increasingly clear that altered promoter DNA methylation may play a critical role in mediating differential gene regulation and facilitating short-term adaptation in response to the environment. Here, we report differential membrane-bound catechol-O-methyltransferase (MB-COMT) activity due to altered promoter methylation and explore the nature of the contribution of the COMT Val158Met polymorphism as a risk factor for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder with 115 analyses. Subsequent brain samples from the frontal lobe. These studies are the first to show that MB-COMT promoter DNA is frequently hypomethylated in patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder compared to controls (methylation rate: 26 and 29 vs. 60%; P=0.004 and 0.008, respectively), particularly in the left frontal lobes (Methylation rate: 29 and 30 vs. 81%; P=0.003 and 0.002, respectively). Quantitative gene expression analysis showed a corresponding increase in MB-COMT transcript levels in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder patients compared to controls (P=0.02) with an accompanying inverse correlation between MB-COMT and DRD1 expression. In addition, there was a trend for enrichment of the Val allele of the COMT Val158Met polymorphism in patients with MB-COMT hypomethylation. These findings suggest that MB-COMT overexpression due to promoter hypomethylation and/or a hyperactive allele of COMT may increase dopamine degradation in the frontal lobe, providing a molecular basis for the common symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

abstract: We used a translational convergent functional genomics (CFG) approach to identify and prioritize genes implicated in schizophrenia by integrating genome-wide association study data at the gene level with other genetic and gene expression studies in humans and animal models. Using these multiple scores and pathway analysis, we identify top genes (DISC1, TCF4, MBP, MOBP, NCAM1, NRCAM, NDUFV2, RAB18, as well as ADCYAP1, BDNF, CNR1, COMT, DRD2, DTNBP1, GRIAB1, GD1, HTR2A, NRG1, RELN, SNAP-25, TNIK), brain development, myelination, cell adhesion, glutamate receptor signaling, G-protein-coupled receptor signaling, and cAMP-mediated signaling as keys to pathophysiology and as targets for therapeutic intervention. Overall, the data are consistent with a disrupted connectivity model of schizophrenia resulting from neurodevelopmental environmental stress exposure in the context of genetic vulnerability. Furthermore, we show how the best candidate genes identified by CFG can be used to generate a genetic risk prediction score (GRPS) to aid in the diagnosis of schizophrenia, with predictive power in independent cohorts. The GRPS also differentiates the classic age of schizophrenia from early and late disease. We also show in three independent cohorts, two European Americans and one African American, increasing overlap, repetition, and consistency from single-nucleotide polymorphisms to genes, then genes prioritized by CFG, and finally at the level of biological pathways and mechanisms. Finally, we compared our top candidate genes for schizophrenia from this analysis with top candidate genes for bipolar disorder and anxiety disorders from our previous CFG analyses, as well as from the autism and Alzheimer's domains. Overall, our work is reshaping the genomic and biological landscape of schizophrenia, providing a better understanding of the disease, diagnosis, and therapeutics. It also exhibits significant genetic overlap with other major psychiatric disorder domains, suggesting a need for improved nosology.

abstract: Refinement of neuronal connections during development is regulated by environmental interactions. Some refinement occurs through changes in gene expression and/or epigenetic gene-specific DNA methylation status. DNA methylation occurs by the transfer of a methyl group from S-adenosyl methionine to a cytosine residue in the dinucleotide sequence CpG. While common CpG sequences in the genome are usually heavily methylated, those found in CpG islands in the promoter regions of genes are less methylated. In most cases, the level of DNA methylation correlates with the degree of gene inactivation. Other known epigenetic mechanisms include histone deacetylation and chromatin remodeling, RNA silencing, RNA modification, and DNA remodeling. Exposure memory, expressed as epigenetic DNA modifications, allows for genome plasticity and short-term adaptation of each generation to the environment. Environmental factors that affect DNA methylation include diet, proteins, drugs, and hormones. Induced changes in methylation can alter the gene's response to subsequent hormonal stimulation. Gene-specific DNA methylation status can be maintained during transmission through mitosis and meiosis. A growing body of data implicates a role for DNA methylation in multifactorial psychiatric disorders. For example, treatment with L-methionine may exacerbate psychosis; And valproate, a drug that produces hypomethylated DNA, reduces such symptoms. Hypermethylation of the RELN gene promoter region correlates with reduced gene expression. The protein Reelin of this gene, essential for neuronal migration and synaptogenesis, is reduced in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, indicating hypermethylation of the promoter region of these disorders. Some evidence implicates DRD2 and HTR2A gene promoter methylation in schizophrenia and mood disorders. DNA methylation normally increases with age, although hypomethylation of the promoter region of the amyloid A4 precursor gene during aging may play a role in Alzheimer's disease. More research is needed to determine the role of methylomics and other epigenetic phenomena in the nervous system.

abstract: No specific gene has been identified for any major psychiatric disorder, including schizophrenia, despite strong evidence supporting a genetic basis for this complex and devastating disorder. There are several possible reasons for this failure, ranging from poor study design to genetic mechanisms with low statistical power, such as polygenic inheritance, epigenetic interactions, and pleiotropy. Most research designs currently in use are inadequate to detect these mechanisms. However, to date, genetic studies have suggested the causes and potential therapies for psychiatric disorders. There is growing evidence to suggest that understanding the genetic etiology of psychiatric illnesses, including schizophrenia, will be more successful with integrative approaches that consider both genetic and epigenetic factors. For example, several genes, including dopamine receptors (DRD2, DRD3, and DRD4), serotonin receptor 2A (HTR2A), and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), have been implicated in the etiology of schizophrenia and related disorders in meta-analyses and large, multicenter studies. There is also growing evidence for a role for DRD1, NMDA receptor genes (GRIN1, GRIN2A, GRIN2B), brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), and the dopamine transporter (SLC6A3) in both schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Recent studies have shown that epigenetic modification of Relin (RELN), BDNF and DRD2 promoters leads to clinical psychiatric conditions. Pharmacological therapy of psychiatric disorders is likely to be more effective once the molecular pathogenesis is understood. For example, hypoactive alleles of DRD2 and hyperactive alleles of COMT, which reduce dopamine in the synaptic cleft, are associated with schizophrenia. It is likely that insufficient dopaminergic transmission in the frontal lobe plays a role in the development of negative symptoms associated with this disorder. Antipsychotic therapy with partial dopamine D2 receptor agonist effects may be a plausible alternative to existing therapies and may be effective in reducing symptoms in psychotic individuals. It is also possible that therapy using dopamine D1/D2 receptor agonists or COMT inhibitors may be beneficial for patients with negative symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The complex etiology of schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders warrants consideration of both genetic and epigenetic systems and careful design of experiments to elucidate the genetic mechanisms responsible for these disorders and the benefit of existing and new therapies.

abstract: ZNF804a was identified by a genome-wide association study (GWAS), in which a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP rs1344706) in ZNF804a reached genome-wide statistical significance for association with a combined diagnosis of schizophrenia (SZ) and bipolar disorder. Although the molecular function of ZNF804a is unknown, the amino acid sequence likely contains a C2H2-type zinc finger domain and suggests that ZNF804a plays a role in DNA binding and transcription. Here, we demonstrate that ZNF804a directly contributes to transcriptional control by regulating the expression of several SZ-associated genes and directly interacts with chromatin proximal to the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, two genes that we found to be regulated by ZNF804a. Using immunochemistry, we determined that ZNF804a is localized in the nucleus of rat neural progenitor cells in culture and in vivo. We show that expression of ZNF804a results in a significant increase in the transcript levels of PRSS16 and COMT compared to GFP transfected controls and a statistically significant decrease in the transcript levels of PDE4B and DRD2. Furthermore, we show using a chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay that both epitope-tagged and endogenous ZNF804a interact directly with the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, suggesting direct transcriptional regulation of ZNF804a on the expression of these genes. These results are the first to demonstrate that ZNF804a regulates the transcription levels of four SZ-associated genes and binds to chromatin proximal to the promoters of two SZ genes. These results suggest a model where ZNF804a can modulate the transcriptional network of SZ-associated genes.

abstract: More than 70 mutations in two structural genes for type I procollagen (COL1A1 and COL1A2) have been found in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, an inherited disease in children characterized by the fragility of bones and other tissues rich in type I collagen. Mutations include deletions, insertions, RNA splicing mutations, and single-base substitutions that convert a glycine codon to an amino acid codon with a bulkier side chain. With few exceptions, the most severe disease phenotypes are mainly explained by the synthesis of structurally defective pro-alpha chains of type I procollagen, which either interfere with the folding of the triple helix or self-assembly into collagen fibrils. The results highlight how the lightning folding of the collagen triple helix and the self-assembly of collagen fibrils depend on the principle of nucleation, in which several subunits form a core and then the core multiplies to form a larger structure. Precisely defined architecture. The principle of nuclear growth is a highly efficient mechanism for the assembly of large structures, but biological systems that rely heavily on nuclear growth are highly vulnerable to mutations that lead to the synthesis of structurally abnormal but partially functional subunits. Recently, several mutations in three other collagen genes (COL2A1, COL3A1, and COL4A5) have been found in patients with genetic diseases involving these collagen-rich tissues. Most probands have rare genetic diseases, but some appear to have phenotypes that are difficult to distinguish from more common disorders such as osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, and aortic aneurysm. Therefore, the results suggest that mutations in procollagen genes may cause a wide range of both rare and common human diseases.

abstract: Immunosuppressants are critical in preventing adverse immune reactions associated with allogeneic organ transplantation, but they often cause adverse effects in a number of biological systems, including the skeletal system. Calcineurin inhibitors FK506 and cyclosporine A inhibit nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) and cause severe immunosuppression. Among the NFAT proteins, NFATc1 is critical for the differentiation of bone-resorbing osteoclasts. Here, we show that administration of FK506 results in decreased bone mass despite blockade of osteoclast differentiation. This reduction is due to a severe impairment of bone formation, suggesting that NFAT transcription factors also play an important role in the transcriptional program of osteoblasts. In fact, bone formation was inhibited in Nfatc1- and Nfatc2-deficient cells as well as FK506-treated osteoblasts. Overexpression of NFATc1 stimulates the Osterix-dependent activation of the Col1a1 (encoding type I collagen) promoter but not the Runx2-dependent activation of the Bglap1 (encoding osteocalcin) promoter. NFAT and Osterix form a complex that binds to DNA, and this interaction is important for the transcriptional activity of Osterix. Thus, NFAT and Osterix jointly control osteoblastic bone formation. These results may provide important information for the management of post-transplant osteoporosis, as well as a new strategy to promote bone regeneration in osteopenic disease.

abstract: Osteoporosis is a common disease with a strong genetic component. We previously described a polymorphic Sp1 binding site in the COL1A1 gene associated with osteoporosis in several populations. Here, we investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying this association. A meta-analysis showed a significant association between COL1A1 "s" alleles and bone mineral density (BMD), body mass index (BMI) and osteoporotic fractures. The association with fracture was stronger than expected based on the observed differences in BMD and BMI, suggesting an additive effect on bone strength. Gel shift assays showed increased binding of the "s" allele to Sp1 protein, and primary RNA transcripts derived from the "s" allele were approximately threefold more abundant than "S" allele-derived transcripts in "Ss" heterozygotes. Collagen derived from osteoblasts cultured from "Ss" heterozygotes had an increased ratio of alpha 1(I) protein to alpha 2(I) and was accompanied by an increased ratio of COL1A1 mRNA compared to COL1A2. Finally, the yield strength of bone obtained from “Ss” individuals was reduced compared to bone obtained from “SS” subjects. We conclude that the COL1A1 Sp1 polymorphism is a functional genetic variant that predisposes to osteoporosis through complex mechanisms involving changes in bone mass and bone quality.

abstract: Type I collagen is the most abundant and ubiquitous of the collagen family of proteins. It is a heterotrimer comprising two alpha1(I) chains and one alpha2(I) chain encoded by the unlinked loci COL1A1 and COL1A2, respectively. Mutations at these loci mainly cause the connective tissue disorders osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome types VIIA and VIIB. Two cases of osteoporosis and one case of Marfan syndrome also result from mutations at these loci. Mutation data are available on the World Wide Web at http://www.le.ac.uk/depts/ge/collagen/collagen.html

abstract: Celiac disease is a genetically determined chronic inflammatory bowel disease caused by an environmental factor, gluten. Patients with this disease may have predominantly non-gastrointestinal symptoms, and as a result patients are referred to a variety of medical practitioners. Epidemiological studies have shown that celiac disease is very common and affects one in 250 people. The disease is associated with osteoporosis, infertility, autoimmune diseases, and malignancies, especially lymphomas. The mechanism of the intestinal immune response is not fully understood but involves an HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 restricted T-cell immune response in the lamina propria as well as an immune response in the intestinal epithelium. An important component of the disease is the intraepithelial lymphocyte, which may be clonally expanded in refractory sprue and enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. Studying the mechanism of the immune response in celiac disease may provide insight into the mechanism of inflammatory and autoimmune responses and lead to innovations in treatment.

abstract: A few years ago, celiac disease (CD) was considered a rare food intolerance confined to childhood and characterized by severe malabsorption and small intestinal mucosa. Currently, CD is considered an autoimmune disorder common in the general population (affecting 1 in 100 people), occurring at any age and with many possible presentations. CD is difficult to identify because it can begin not only with diarrhea and weight loss, but also with atypical gastrointestinal (constipation and recurrent abdominal pain) and extra-intestinal symptoms (anemia, elevated transaminases, osteoporosis, recurrent miscarriages, aphthous stomatitis, and associated autoimmune diseases, disorders), or may be completely asymptomatic. Over the past 20 years, the diagnostic accuracy of serology for CD has gradually increased with the development of highly reliable tests such as the detection of IgA tissue transglutaminase and antiendomysial and IgG antideamidated gliadin peptide antibodies. The routine use of antibody markers has allowed researchers to detect a very large number of "borderline" cases characterized by positive serology and mild intestinal damage or normal small bowel architecture that could be classified as potential CD. Therefore, it is clear that "old celiac disease" with squamous mucosa is only part of the spectrum of CD. It is possible that serology can identify CD at an early stage, before the appearance of severe intestinal damage. In cases with positive serology but mild or absent intestinal lesions, detection of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 can help confirm or exclude the diagnosis of gluten sensitivity.

abstract: Celiac disease is a lifelong intolerance to the gluten found in wheat, barley and rye, and some patients are also sensitive to oats. The disease is genetically determined, 10% of first-degree relatives are affected and 75% of monozygotic twins are concordant. 95% of patients with celiac disease are human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 positive. Characteristically, the jejunal mucosa is damaged by a T-cell autoimmune response, probably triggered by a 33-mer peptide fragment of A2 gliadin, and patients with this disorder have elevated levels of anti-endomysium and tissue transglutaminase antibodies. their blood. Celiac disease is the most commonly diagnosed food intolerance and, with the advent of a simple blood test to detect cases, the prevalence rate is about 1:100. Classically, the condition presents with malabsorption and failure in infancy, but this picture has now been overtaken by a much more common presentation in adults, usually with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue and anemia, bowel habit disturbances, or low impact bone fractures. Small bowel biopsy is essential for diagnosis and shows a characteristic flat appearance with crypt hypoplasia and epithelial lymphocyte infiltration. Diet is the key to management, and a gluten-free diet effectively treats the condition. However, this commitment is ongoing and many supermarket aisles are effectively closed to people with celiac disease. Compliance can be monitored by measuring antibodies in the blood, which return to negative after 6-9 months. Patients with mild symptoms who are accidentally diagnosed with celiac disease often wonder if they need to follow a diet. The current advice is that following the diet is necessary to avoid long-term complications, which are mainly osteoporosis and lymphoma of the small intestine. However, the risk of these complications is significantly reduced in patients who follow a gluten-free diet.

abstract: Public concern about gluten has led to widespread demand for gluten-free foods, but celiac disease remains significantly underdiagnosed and some confusion remains regarding optimal diagnostic practice. Small bowel histology is the gold standard for diagnosis. High-quality commercial enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for transglutaminase immunoglobulin A and deamidated gliadin immunoglobulin A and G are sensitive screening tools, but nearly 10% of celiacs are seronegative and serologic testing is unreliable in very young people already following a gluten-reduced diet and using immunosuppressive medications. HLA DQA and DQB genotyping to demonstrate the absence of HLA DQ2 and DQ8 coding alleles virtually excludes celiac disease. Confirmation of histological remission reduces the risk of further complications such as osteoporosis and cancer. Serological remission monitoring is unreliable. Because gluten is an exogenous antigen and readily accessible to the small intestine, the immunopathogenesis of celiac disease is better understood than other strongly major histocompatibility complex class II-associated diseases, such as type 1 diabetes. Therapeutic targets have been identified and drugs are under development to supplement or even replace a gluten-free diet. With greater awareness and non-dietary therapies, the diagnosis and treatment of celiac disease will become increasingly popular in medical practice.

abstract: To investigate the role of IL-4 in allergic asthma, we developed a model of allergen-induced airway inflammation. Repeated daily exposure of actively immunized C57BL/6 mice to aerosolized ovalbumin (OVA) induced peribronchial inflammation and increased eosinophils and lymphocytes in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid. IL-4 deficient (IL4-/-) mice treated in the same manner had substantially fewer eosinophils in BAL and significantly less peribronchial inflammation compared with wild-type mice. In this model, mast cell-deficient (W/Wv) mice developed a similar degree of BAL eosinophilia and peribronchial inflammation as wild-type mice, demonstrating that mast cells are not required for the induction of chronic airway inflammation. In contrast, BAL eosinophilia and airway inflammation were absent in OVA-treated MHC class II-deficient (B6.Aa-/-) mice, which lack mature CD4+ T lymphocytes. In conclusion, these results indicate that IL-4 is a central mediator of allergic airway inflammation that regulates antigen-induced eosinophil recruitment to the airways by a T cell-dependent mechanism.

This details a mechanistic pathway in which IL-4 facilitates the recruitment of eosinophils into the airways, a critical inflammatory process in asthma — all regulated via a T cell-dependent mechanism.  4. **Comparison with Other Genetic Models**: By incorporating comparisons with other genetic models such as mast cell and MHC Class II deficient mice, the study encompasses a broader perspective, confirming the specific involvement of IL-4 and T cells over other components like mast cells in this model of asthma.  5. **Implications for Targeted Therapies**: Understanding the role of IL-4 in asthma can direct future therapeutic strategies focusing on IL-4 as a target for managing or treating asthma. abstract: IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 are thought to be central to the allergic response in asthma. Previous work suggested that the major source of these cytokines was CD4(+) T(H)2 cells. However, recent studies have shown that other innate production of type 2 cytokines may be just as important. Nuocytes are a novel population of IL-13-producing innate cells critical for protective immunity during Nippostrongylus brasiliensis infection. With this in mind, we investigated the potential presence and functional importance of nuocytes in experimental allergic asthma. We generated Il4(+/eGFP)Il13(+/tomato) double reporter mice to study cytokine-producing cells in allergic inflammation. We transduced innate IL-13-producing cells to investigate their role in airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR). We show that allergen-induced nuocytes infiltrate the lung and are the major innate source of IL-13. CD4(+) T cells in the lung almost exclusively express IL-13, and IL-4-producing T cells are restricted to the draining lymph nodes. IL-13-producing nuocytes in BAL fluid induced by intranasal administration of IL-25 or IL-33. Strikingly, adoptive transfer of wild-type nuocytes, but not Il13(-/-) nuocytes into Il13(-/-) mice, which are normally resistant to IL-25-induced AHR, restored airway resistance and lung cell infiltration. These findings identify nuocytes as a novel cell type in allergic lung inflammation and an innate source of IL-13 that can directly induce AHR in the absence of IL-13-producing CD4(+) T cells. These data highlight nuocytes as an important new issue in the development of future allergic asthma therapies.

abstract: Asthma is a common respiratory disease characterized by variable airway obstruction caused by acute and chronic inflammation of the bronchi; Associated phenotypes include bronchial hyperresponsiveness (BHR), elevated serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels, and positive skin tests to common allergens. Binding of interleukin-13 (IL13) or interleukin-4 (IL4) to the IL4 receptor (IL4R) triggers the initial response to polarize Th2 lymphocytes. Both IL13 and IL4 are produced by Th2 cells and can induce B-cell isotype switching to produce IgE following allergen exposure. These cytokines also share a common receptor component, IL4R alpha. We investigated five IL4RA single-nucleotide polymorphisms in a population of Dutch families diagnosed through probands with asthma. Treating probands and their spouses as an unrelated sample, we observed significant associations of atopy and asthma-related phenotypes with IL4RA polymorphisms, including S478P, and serum total IgE levels (P=.0007). A significant gene-gene interaction was detected between S478P in IL4RA and the -1111 promoter variation in IL13 previously shown to be associated with BHR (P=.003). Individuals with risk genotypes for both genes had a nearly fivefold greater risk of developing asthma than individuals with nonrisk genotypes for either gene (P=.0004). These data suggest that variations in IL4RA contribute to elevated serum total IgE levels and that the interaction between IL4RA and IL13 significantly increases an individual's susceptibility to asthma.

abstract: A 3-gene signature of periostin, chloride channel accessory 1 (CLCA1), and serpin β2 (SERPINB2) in airway epithelial brushes is used to classify asthma into TH2-high and TH2-low endotypes. Little is known about the utility of sputum gene profiling as a molecular phenotyping method. We sought to determine whether gene profiling in sputum cells can identify T(H)2-high and T(H)2-low asthma subtypes. In induced sputum cells from 37 asthmatic patients and 15 healthy control subjects, PCR was used to profile IL-13 activation epithelial cell signature gene expression (periostin, CLCA1 and SERPINB2), TH2 genes (IL4, IL5 and IL13). ) and other genes associated with airway TH2 inflammation. Gene expression levels of CLCA1 and periostin, but not SerpinB2, were significantly higher than normal in sputum cells from asthmatic subjects. The expression levels of IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13 were also significantly increased in asthmatic patients and were highly correlated among individual subjects. Combining the expression levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 into a single quantitative metric ("T(H)2 gene mean"), 26 of 37 asthmatic patients (70%) had T(H)2-high asthma, which It was characterized by more severe measures of asthma and increased blood and sputum eosinophilia. Mean TH2 gene values ​​were stable when baseline values ​​were very high or very low, but fluctuated above or below the T(H)2-high value when baseline values ​​were intermediate. IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 transcripts are readily detected in sputum cells of asthmatic patients, and their expression levels can be used to classify asthma into T(H)2-high and T(H)2-low endotypes. .

abstract: Chitin is an essential structural polysaccharide of fungal pathogens and parasites, but its role in human immune responses is largely unknown. After cellulose, it is the second most common polysaccharide in nature, and its derivatives are widely used today for medical and industrial purposes. We analyzed the immunological properties of purified chitin particles derived from the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans, which induced the selective secretion of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. We identified NOD2, TLR9, and mannose receptors as essential fungal chitin recognition receptors for the induction of this response. Chitin reduces LPS-induced inflammation in vivo and thus may contribute to the immune response after defeating the pathogen. Fungal chitin also induced eosinophilia in vivo, confirming its ability to induce asthma. Polymorphisms in the identified chitin receptors, NOD2 and TLR9, predispose individuals to inflammatory states and decreased expression of chitinase and chitinase-like binding proteins, whose activity is essential for in vitro generation of IL-10-inducing fungal chitin particles, have also been linked. Inflammatory conditions and asthma. Chitin recognition is therefore critical for immune homeostasis and likely plays an important role in infectious and allergic diseases.

This direct mention establishes a clear link between the gene NOD2 and the disease asthma.  2. **Biological Mechanism Elaborated**: The text describes the role of chitin in inducing immune responses, including the secretion of IL-10 and eosinophilia, which are relevant to the pathophysiology of asthma. NOD2, along with other receptors, is implicated in the recognition of chitin, suggesting its involvement in the pathways leading to asthma through immune response modulation.  3. **Role in Asthma Exacerbation**: It describes how chitin induces eosinophilia in vivo, a key feature often associated with asthma and allergic responses. abstract: Interactions with microbial pathogens are critical for the maturation of the immune system. Nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain protein 1 (NOD1) is a cytosolic receptor that senses a muropeptide found primarily in Gram-negative bacterial peptidoglycans. NOD1 is located on chromosome 7p14-p15, a region associated with atopy. Recently, a closely related NOD2 polymorphism has been associated with atopy-related traits. Within a large population-based cohort of German adults (n = 1417), a case-control population with atopic eczema (n = 454), and a large cohort of parent-offspring trios for atopic eczema (189 trios), we evaluated 11 NOD1 polymorphisms for association with atopic phenotypes. Methods Subjects were phenotyped by standardized questionnaires and interviews, skin examination, and serum IgE measurements. Genotyping was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry. Analyzes revealed a significant association of one NOD1 haplotype with atopic eczema in a population-based cohort ( P = .004) and a case-control population ( P = .003). Another NOD1 haplotype was associated with reduced total IgE ( P = .008). In addition, significant associations with serum total IgE levels were observed for polymorphisms rs2907748 ( P = .006), rs2907749 ( P = .012), and rs2075822 ( P = .018). This polymorphism was significantly associated with atopic eczema and asthma in family-based association analyzes (P = .001-.043). Seven polymorphisms showed significant transmission bias for total IgE levels ( P values ​​<.0001-.029). These data indicate that genetic variants in NOD1 are important determinants of atopy susceptibility.

abstract: Nucleotide-binding and oligomerization domain NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are highly conserved cytosolic pattern recognition receptors that perform critical functions in probing the intracellular environment for the presence of infection, pathogens, and metabolic disturbances. Sensing of these danger signals by NLRs leads to their oligomerization into large macromolecular scaffolds and the rapid deployment of efficient signaling cascades to restore homeostasis. Although some NLRs act by recruiting and activating inflammatory caspases, others induce inflammation through alternative pathways, including the nuclear factor-κB, mitogen-activated protein kinase, and regulatory factor pathways. The critical role of NLRs in development and physiology is demonstrated by their apparent impact on human diseases. Mutations in the genes encoding NLRP3 or NLRP12 cause hereditary periodic fever syndromes, while mutations in CARD15, which encodes NOD2, are associated with Crohn's disease or Blau syndrome. Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have identified a number of risk alleles involving NLR genes in diseases including allergic rhinitis, multiple sclerosis, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, multi-bacillary leprosy, vitiligo, early menopause, and osteoporosis. Loss of density in older women. Animal models have in some cases allowed the characterization of the underlying effective mechanisms. In this review, we highlight the functions of NLRs in health and disease and discuss how the characterization of their molecular mechanisms provides new insights into therapeutic strategies for the management of inflammatory pathologies.

abstract: In affluent, developed parts of the world, there is a steady and simultaneous increase in at least three groups of diseases: (1) allergies, (2) inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD; eg, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis), and (3) autoimmunity (eg, type 1 diabetes). and multiple sclerosis). Because the medical world is so fragmented, it took some time before the connection between this growth was noticed and understood. There is now evidence that the concomitant increase in these immunoregulatory diseases is due, at least in part, to a malfunction of regulatory T cells (Treg). This paper provides an overview of each of these areas of medicine (albeit allergic disorders) and concludes that the increasing failure of Treg is the result of reduced exposure to certain microorganisms that are "old friends". Because of their continuous existence throughout the evolution of mammals. These organisms, which include saprophytic mycobacteria, helminths, and lactobacilli, are recognized by the innate immune system as harmless and as an adjunct to Treg induction. Polymorphisms in components of the innate immune system, such as TLR2 and NOD2, appear to define population subgroups that will develop immunoregulatory disorders while living in a modern environment. A further role of the "old friends" and the Tregs they induce may be to maintain the levels of regulatory IL-10-secreting macrophages and antigen-presenting cells, which are reduced in asthma and Crohn's disease. These concepts lead to new therapies based on harmless organisms or their components. Phase I/II clinical trials have yielded some statistically significant results, and Phase II trials are ongoing.

abstract: The action of tissue transglutaminase (TGase) on specific protein-bound glutamine residues plays a critical role in many biological processes. Here we provide evidence for a novel role for this enzyme in the common, HLA-DQ2 (and DQ8) associated enteropathy, celiac disease (CD). Intestinal inflammation in CD is induced by exposure to dietary wheat gliadin and is associated with increased mucosal TGase activity. This enzyme has also been identified as a major target of CD-associated anti-endomysium autoantibodies and is known to accept gliadin as one of its several substrates. We investigated the possibility that TGase may be involved in the modulation of gliadin-specific T cell reactivity. This may provide a link between previous reports of a role for TGase in CD and the prevailing view of CD as a T-cell-mediated disorder. We found a specific effect of TGase on T cell recognition of gliadin. This effect was limited to gliadin-specific T cells isolated from intestinal CD lesions. We show that TGase mediates its effect through the orderly and specific deamidation of gliadin. This deamidation creates an epitope that effectively binds DQ2 and is recognized by intestinal T cells. The generation of epitopes by enzymatic modification is a novel mechanism that may be relevant to tolerance breakdown and the initiation of autoimmune disease.

abstract: Proteins in wheat, rye, and barley cause celiac disease, an autoimmune type of gastrointestinal disorder, in genetically susceptible people. Because the disease may be underdiagnosed, we estimated the prevalence of the disease and tested the hypothesis that serum autoantibody assays can be used to detect untreated celiac disease and that positive findings are associated with specific HLA haplotypes. Serum samples were collected from 3654 students (age range, 7 to 16 years) in 1994 and screened in 2001 for endomysial and tissue transglutaminase antibodies. HLA typing was also performed on stored blood samples. All antibody-positive subjects were asked to undergo a small bowel biopsy in 2001. None of the subjects received a clinical diagnosis of celiac disease as of 1994, but 10 who tested positive for both antibodies in serum obtained in 1994 received a diagnosis between 1994 and 2001. Of 36 other antibody-positive subjects who consented to biopsy in 2001, 27 had evidence of celiac disease on biopsy. Thus, the estimated biopsy-proven prevalence was 1 in 99 children. All but two antibody-positive subjects had the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotype. The prevalence of the combination of antibody positivity and the HLA haplotype associated with celiac disease was 1 in 67. Presence of serum tissue transglutaminase and endomysial autoantibodies predicts small intestinal abnormalities suggestive of celiac disease. There is a good correlation between autoantibody positivity and specific HLA haplotypes. We estimate the prevalence of celiac disease in Finnish schoolchildren to be at least 1 case in 99 children.

abstract: The vast majority of patients with wheat gluten protein intolerance due to celiac disease (CD) are human histocompatibility leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2(+), while the remaining few usually express HLA-DQ8. These two class II molecules are primarily responsible for the presentation of gluten peptides to gluten-specific T cells, which are found only in the intestines of CD patients but not in controls. Interestingly, tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-mediated deamidation of gliadin plays an important role in the recognition of this food antigen by intestinal T cells. Here, we used recombinant antigens to demonstrate that the intestinal T cell response to alpha-gliadin in adult CD is focused on two immunodominant, DQ2-restricted peptides overlapping a seven-residue fragment of gliadin. We show that tTG converts the glutamine residue in this fragment to glutamic acid and that this process is critical for T cell recognition. Gluten-specific T cell lines from 16 different adult patients all responded to either or both of these deamidated peptides, indicating that these epitopes are critical to disease pathology. Binding studies showed that deamidated peptides showed increased affinity for DQ2, a molecule known to preferentially bind peptides containing negatively charged residues. Interestingly, the modified glutamine is placed in different pockets of DQ2 for different epitopes. These results indicate modification of anchor residues leading to improved affinity for major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and altered conformation of the peptide-MHC complex may be a critical factor leading to T cell response to gliadin and oral gluten intolerance. CD.
