abstract: Despite the increased prescription of gluten-free diets in individuals with gastrointestinal symptoms who do not have celiac disease, there is minimal evidence that gluten is the cause. The aims of this study were to determine whether gluten ingestion can cause symptoms in non-celiac individuals and to investigate the mechanism. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled rechallenge study was conducted in patients with irritable bowel syndrome in whom celiac disease was excluded and who were symptomatically controlled on a gluten-free diet. Participants received gluten or a placebo in the form of two slices of bread plus one muffin per day on a gluten-free diet for up to 6 weeks. Symptoms were assessed using a visual analog scale and markers of intestinal inflammation, damage, and immune activation were monitored. A total of 34 patients (29-59 years, 4 males) completed the study per protocol. Overall, 56% had human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 and/or HLA-DQ8. Adherence to diet and supplementation was very high. Thirteen of 19 patients (68%) in the gluten group reported that symptoms were not adequately controlled compared with 6 of 15 (40%) on placebo (P=0.0001; generalized estimating equation). On a visual analog scale, patients significantly worsened at 1 week on gluten for overall symptoms (P=0.047), pain (P=0.016), bloating (P=0.031), satisfaction with stool consistency (P=0.024), and fatigue. (P=0.001). Antigliadin antibodies were not induced. There were no significant changes in faecal lactoferrin, celiac antibody levels, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, or intestinal permeability. There were no differences in any of the endpoints between individuals with and without DQ2/DQ8. "Non-celiac gluten intolerance" may exist, but no evidence for the mechanism has been elucidated.

abstract: HLA-DRB1, -DQA1 and -DQB1 genomic typing was performed in 50 patients with dermatitis herpetiformis and 290 healthy blood donors. Genes encoding the DQ (alpha 1*0501, beta 1*02) heterodimer were carried by 43 (86%) patients and 72 (25%) controls. Six of the remaining seven patients (12% of all patients) carried the genes encoding the DQ (alpha 1*03, beta 1*0302) heterodimer. These HLA associations are very similar to those observed in patients with celiac disease. Thus, we conclude that dermatitis herpetiformis and celiac disease are associated with the same HLA-DQ alpha beta heterodimers.

abstract: The role of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 heterodimer (DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201) in the presentation of gluten peptides in celiac disease (CD) effector T cells is well documented. Because HLA-DQ2 is transferred to DR3 haplotypes due to unequal linkage, such haplotypes are more common in patients with autoimmune disease. This study analyzed 35 North Indian children aged <15 years and diagnosed CD according to ESPGAN criteria, which included histopathological changes in duodenal biopsy, clinical response to gluten withdrawal, and presence of antiendomysial antibodies. HLA class I and class II alleles were determined by polymerase chain reaction sequence-specific primers, sequence-specific oligonucleotide probes, and reverse-strip molecular techniques. Statistically significant positive association of disease with HLA-DRB1*03 (94.2% vs. 22.1% in controls, chi(2) = 73.4, p = 7.54E-11) and negative association with DRB1*15 (chi(2) ) = 7.4 , p = 6.5E-03) and DRB1*13 alleles were observed. HLA-DQB1*0201 was observed in all 35 patients (100%), and DQ2 heterodimer alpha(0)beta(0) was observed in 97.1% of CD patients (31.4% in double dose, 65.7% in single dose). and revealed a significant deviation from healthy controls (chi(2) = 102.08, p = 7.56E-11). Further analysis revealed the involvement of multiple DR3+ve haplotypes with CD in Indians, of which A26-B8-DR3 was the most common DR3 haplotype in patients (34.28%, chi(2) = 40.57, p = 2.65E-10), followed by Ax-B21 -DR3 (11.4%) (chi(2) = 13.8, p = 2E-04) and classical Caucasian haplotype A1-B8-DR3 (5.7%). The first two haplotypes are characteristic of Asian Indians and are involved in the development of CD. We conclude that high-risk DR3 haplotypes, which play a critical role in the development of CD, are unique in Asian Indians. Detailed analysis of these haplotypes in Indian patients with autoimmune diseases may help to understand the influence of other intervening genes in the major histocompatibility complex.

abstract: From 1991 to 1998, we vaccinated 4835 newborns against hepatitis B virus (HBV) and observed their humoral response to the recombinant vaccine. In a sample of 184 of these infants, we studied the relationship between HLA class I and II genomic polymorphisms and the humoral response to the vaccine and the relationship between the response and immune-mediated diseases. A subset of 96 children also underwent HLA class III (C4A and C4B) typing. Four levels of humoral response have been identified, each with its own MHC restriction. Different HLA products appear to act as agonists (C4AQ0 and HLA-DQB1(*)02) or antagonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02 and HLA-DRB1(*)11, DQB1(*)0301) in humoral impairment. . Response to HBV vaccine. The group of responders was more characterized by the lack of "non-responsive" alleles than those with specific "response". Tolerance to HBV peptides may have clinical consequences, possibly for infants at genetic risk for immunopathologies. In fact, many poor responders carried two to four HLA-DQ alpha beta heterodimers that predispose to insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and celiac disease. Two true responders suffered from allergies and two slow responders had transient episodes of hyperglycemia.

abstract: The possibility that genetic susceptibility to celiac disease (CD) may be influenced by polymorphisms in tumor necrosis factor (TNF) genes has been repeatedly raised. To date, this has only been investigated in case-control studies, and the results have been conflicting. To avoid possible ethnic mismatch between patients and controls, we approached this problem by studying 71 celiac families, comparing parental haplotypes and CD control haplotypes (so-called AFBAC or affected family-based controls). We used DNA-based methods to screen for HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 alleles, TNFalpha promoter polymorphisms, and TNFa and b microsatellites. A guanine adenine polymorphism at position -308 of the promoter region of the TNFalpha gene was found to be associated with CD, as the TNF-308A allele appeared to be significantly increased in frequency in CD haplotypes, and this was independent of CD and linkage. DRB1*0301,DQA1*0501,DQB1*0201 alleles. Our results indicate that at least one gene other than the known association of CD with HLA class II has a susceptibility role in this disease. It must be either TNFalpha or another polymorphic gene at the telomeric end of the HLA class III region.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis is a common disease of the central nervous system, in which the interaction of inflammatory and neurodegenerative processes usually leads to periodic neurological disorders, followed by progressive accumulation of disability. Epidemiological studies have shown that genetic factors are primarily responsible for the substantially increased frequency of disease found in relatives of affected individuals, and systematic efforts to identify linkage in multiplex families have confirmed that major histocompatibility complex (MHC) variation is of greatest importance. Individual influence on risk. Modest genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have allowed the identification of more than 20 risk loci and have shown that multiple variants with modest individual effects have a key role in disease susceptibility. Much of the genetic architecture underlying disease susceptibility remains to be elucidated and is expected to require analysis with sample sizes larger than those currently available to individual research groups. In a collaborative GWAS comprising 9,772 cases of European origin collected by 23 research groups working in 15 different countries, we replicated almost all previously proposed associations and identified at least 29 new susceptibility loci. In the MHC, we clarified the identity of the HLA-DRB1 risk alleles and confirmed that variation in the HLA-A gene underlies an independent protective effect attributed to the class I region. Immunologically relevant genes are significantly overrepresented among those mapping near the identified loci and particularly implicate T-helper cell differentiation in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system in which a limited cellular immune response is observed. To determine whether similar T cell responses are antigen-specific, particularly to myelin basic protein (MBP), we analyzed T-cell receptor (TCR) gene expression directly from MS brain plaques using polymerase chain reaction. reverse transcribed messenger RNA and compared them to the TCR of previously described MBP-specific T cell clones from MS and a rat model of experimental allergic encephalomyelitis. The translocated V beta 5.2 gene was detected in the brains of all patients who were HLA DRB1*1501, DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401. V beta 5.2-D beta-J beta sequences in these MS brain plaques revealed five motifs. One common motif was identical to that described for the VDJ region of the V beta 5.2 T-cell clone. This clone was from an MS patient that was HLA DRB1*1501, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401 and was cytotoxic against targets containing the MBP peptide 89–106 (rev. 1). The deduced amino acid sequence of this VDJ rearrangement, Leu-Arg-Gly, has also been described in rat T cells cloned from experimental allergic encephalomyelitis lesions specific for MBP peptide 87-99 (Rev. 2). VDJ sequences specific for this MBP epitope account for the majority (40%) of TCR V beta 5.2 N(D)N rearrangements in MS lesions. The ability of rat T cells with this VDJ sequence to induce experimental allergic encephalomyelitis and the prevalence of such sequences in human demyelinating lesions suggests that T cells with this rearranged TCR may be critical in MS.

abstract: There is a striking latitudinal gradient in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis (MS), but exceptions in Mediterranean Europe and northern Scandinavia and some systematic reviews suggest that the gradient may be an artefact. The authors attempted to estimate the association between MS prevalence and latitude by metaregression. Studies were retrieved from online databases, reference mining, and author referral. Prevalence estimates were age-standardized for the 2009 European population. Analyzes were performed via random-effects meta-regression, weighted with inversion of within-study variance. The authors included 650 prevalence estimates from 321 peer-reviewed studies; 239 were age standardized and 159 provided sex-specific data. The authors found a significant positive association (change in prevalence with latitude) between age-standardized prevalence (1.04, p<0.001) and latitude, which decreased at higher latitudes. Adjusting for year of prevalence strengthened the association with latitude (2.60, p<0.001). The inverse gradient in the Italian region was modified by adjusting the distribution of the MS-associated HLA-DRB1 allele. Adjustment for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies did not significantly change the gradient in Europe. Adjustment for some potential sources of bias did not affect the observed associations. This, the most comprehensive review of MS prevalence to date, confirmed a statistically significant positive association between MS prevalence and global latitude. The exception of the gradient in the Italian region and northern Scandinavia is probably the result of genetic and behavioral-cultural variations. The presence of a positive gradient in Europe after adjustment for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies strongly supports a role for environmental factors that vary by latitude, with ultraviolet radiation (UVR)/vitamin D being the most prominent candidates.

abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex trait in which allelic variation in the MHC class II region exerts one of the strongest effects on genetic risk. Epidemiological data for MS provide strong evidence that environmental factors operate at the population level and influence the unusual geographic distribution of this disease. A growing body of evidence implicates sunlight or vitamin D as a major environmental factor in the etiology. We hypothesized that this environmental candidate may interact with hereditary factors and searched for the responsible regulatory elements in the MHC class II region. Sequence analysis localized one MHC vitamin D response element (VDRE) to the promoter region of HLA-DRB1. Sequencing of this promoter in more than 1000 chromosomes of HLA-DRB1 homozygotes showed absolute conservation of this putative VDRE across HLA-DRB1*15 haplotypes. In contrast, there was striking variability among MS-associated haplotypes. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays demonstrated specific recruitment of the vitamin D receptor to the VDRE in the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter, confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments using lymphoblastoid cells homozygous for HLA-DRB1*15. Transient transfection using a luciferase reporter assay demonstrated a functional role for this VDRE. B cells transiently transfected with the HLA-DRB1*15 gene promoter showed increased expression upon stimulation with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (P = 0.002), which was lost with both VDRE deletion and the homologous “VDRE” sequence found in non-MS Associated HLA-DRB1 haplotypes. Flow cytometric analysis showed a specific increase in cell surface expression of HLA-DRB1 by vitamin D supplementation only in HLA-DRB1*15 lymphoblastoid cells. This study further implicates vitamin D as a strong environmental candidate in MS by demonstrating a direct functional interaction with a major genetic susceptibility determinant locus. These findings support a link between key epidemiologic and genetic features of this disease, with major practical implications for disease mechanism and prevention studies.

In summary, the abstract effectively demonstrates a significant interaction between Multiple Sclerosis and the gene HLA-DRB1 through detailed genetic and environmental pathway analysis, confirming the hypothesis and justifying the relevance score of 1.

abstract: In the Western population, within the normal range of LDL cholesterol, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Thus, lowering LDL cholesterol in such populations may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely regardless of baseline cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40–80 years) with coronary artery disease, other occlusive arterial disease, or diabetes mellitus were randomized to simvastatin 40 mg daily (mean compliance: 85%) or matching placebo (mean off-study statin use: 17%. ). The analyzes are event-specific first-come, first-served and compare all simvastatin-allocated versus all placebo participants. This "intention-to-treat" comparison estimated the effect of approximately two-thirds (85% minus 17%) of taking statins during the planned 5-year treatment period resulting in a mean difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L. about two-thirds of the effect of actual use of simvastatin 40 mg per day). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subcategory analyses), with additional assessments of cancer and other major morbidities. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin-allocated vs 1,507 [14.7%] 10,267 placebo-allocated deaths; p=0.0003), with a highly significant 18% (SE 5) proportional reduction in coronary events. mortality (587 [5.7%] vs 707 [6.9%]; p=0.0005), marginally significant reduction in other vascular mortality (194 [1.9%] vs 230 [2.2%]; p=0.07) and non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality ( 547 [5.3%] vs 570 [5.6%]; p=0.4). There was a highly significant reduction of approximately one-quarter in the first event rate for non-fatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] vs 1212 [11.8%]; p<0.0001), non-fatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%] vs 585 [5.7%] ; p<0.0001) and for coronary or noncoronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a definite 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19–28) reduction in the event rate (2033 [19.8%] vs 2585 [25.2%] affected individuals; p < 0.0001). The reduction in major vascular events during the first year was not significant, but thereafter it was highly significant in each individual year. The proportional reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in each participant subcategory studied, including: those without a diagnosis of coronary artery disease, those with cerebrovascular disease, or those with peripheral artery disease, or those with diabetes; men and separate women; is less than 70 years old at the time of entry; And—most notably—even those who had LDL cholesterol below 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL) or total cholesterol below 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefit of simvastatin was additive to that of cardioprotective treatment. The annual excess risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or hospitalization for any other nonvascular cause. The addition of simvastatin to existing treatment safely provides significant additional benefit for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their baseline cholesterol concentration. Taking simvastatin 40 mg per day reduced the incidence of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for the discrepancy, the actual use of this regimen is likely to reduce these figures by about one-third. Therefore, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, 5 years of simvastatin would prevent approximately 70-100 of 1,000 people from experiencing at least one of these major vascular events (and longer-term treatment should provide further benefit). The size of the 5-year benefit mainly depends on such individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not just their blood lipid concentrations.

abstract: Although treatment of myocardial overload is effective in reducing death from the progression of heart failure, it is not known whether the progression of coronary artery disease will be delayed by lipid-lowering treatment. In the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study, 4444 patients with coronary heart disease without evidence of heart failure were randomized to placebo (n = 2223) or simvastatin 20-40 mg (n = 2221) and followed for more than 5 years. Among patients who received placebo, 228 (10.3%) were diagnosed with heart failure at follow-up compared with 184 (8.3%) patients who received simvastatin (P < .015). Mortality was 31.9% in the placebo group and 25.5% in the simvastatin group in patients who developed heart failure. This compares with 9.2 and 6.6%, respectively, in non-HF patients. There were 45 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the placebo group and 23 in the simvastatin group (NS). Patients who developed heart failure were more likely to have recurrent myocardial infarction and have a history of diabetes, peripheral artery disease, and hypertension than patients who did not develop congestive heart failure. Long-term prophylaxis with simvastatin reduces the incidence of heart failure in a cohort of patients with coronary heart disease without prior evidence of congestive heart failure.

abstract: Essential hypertension is a common human disease believed to result from the interaction of multiple genetic and environmental determinants. In genetic studies of two large panels of hypertensive siblings from widely separated geographic areas, we obtained a genetic association between the angiotensinogen gene (AGT) and hypertension, demonstrated an association of AGT molecular variants with the disease, and found significant differences in plasma concentrations. Angiotensinogen among hypertensive subjects with different AGT genotypes. The confirmation and replication provided by these results support the interpretation that molecular variants of AGT represent heritable predispositions to essential hypertension in humans.

This indicates a genetic connection between AGT and hypertension, thereby supporting the hypothesis.  3. **Molecular Variants and Disease Association**: It is mentioned that molecular variants of AGT are associated with hypertension. This is a crucial point as it highlights specific variations within the AGT gene that correlate with the disease's presence, providing a genetic mechanistic insight into how AGT may influence hypertension.  4. **Physiological Evidence through Plasma Angiotensinogen Levels**: The study also found significant differences in plasma angiotensinogen levels among hypertensive subjects with differing AGT genotypes. This physiological data provides additional support for the role of AGT in modulating blood pressure, which is a key aspect of hypertension.  5. **Confirmation and Replication**: The replication and confirmation of results across different studies, as mentioned in the abstract, enhance the reliability of the findings regarding AGT's role in hypertension. abstract: Variants in the human angiotensinogen gene have been associated with increased circulating angiotensinogen levels and essential hypertension in some studies. To test for direct causality between genotypes at the angiotensinogen locus and blood pressure, we studied mice carrying zero, one, two, three, or four functional copies of the murine wild-type angiotensinogen gene (Agt) at its normal chromosomal location. Plasma angiotensinogen levels increase progressively, although not linearly, from zero-copy animals to 145% of normal in four-copy animals. Mice of all genotypes are normal at birth, but most null copy animals die before weaning. The kidneys of null-copy animals show pathological changes in adulthood, but the kidneys are normal in other genotypes. One adult, copy-zero male tested was fertile. Blood pressure in single- to quadruple-copy animals shows a significant and nearly linear increase of about 8 mmHg per gene copy, even though their normal compensatory mechanisms are intact. These results establish a direct causal relationship between Agt genotypes and blood pressure.

This directly links the gene AGT to the physiological condition of hypertension, establishing a clear relevance to the hypothesis.  2. **Experimental Approach Using Gene Copies**: The study utilized a genetic approach by manipulating the number of functional copies of the murine AGT gene in mice. By varying the gene dosage (from zero to four copies), the study could directly observe the impact of these variations on blood pressure levels, which are integral to understanding hypertension.  3. **Observation of Physiological Effects**: The results indicated that plasma angiotensinogen levels and blood pressures increased progressively with an increasing number of AGT gene copies. Mice with zero copies showed severe health issues and mortality, while increases in gene copies correlated with heightened blood pressure, providing strong evidence of a causal relationship.  4. **Confirmation of the Causal Relationship**: The experiments unequivocally established a direct causal link between the number of AGT gene copies and the changes in blood pressure — a key factor in diagnosing and studying hypertension.  5. **Relevance to Human Health**: Although the experiments were conducted on mice, the implications extend to human health, as the human angiotensinogen gene shares functional similarities with its murine counterpart. This not only supports the hypothesis but also enriches our understanding of how genetic variations in the AGT gene can influence blood pressure and hypertension risk.

abstract: To summarize the incidence of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) and associations between CIN incidence and risk factors in patients undergoing intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) with low or iso-osmolar iodinated contrast medium. This review was performed in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items in the Prisma for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines. We searched MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane databases from 2002 to November 2012. Two reviewers included papers and extracted data. Pooled data were analyzed using a fixed- or random-effects approach, depending on the heterogeneity defined as the I(2) index. 42 articles with 18,790 patients (mean age 61.5 years (range: 38-83 years)) were included. The mean baseline eGFR was 59.8 mL/min and ranged from 4 to 256 mL/min. 45.0% of all patients had estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) <60 ml/min, 55.2% had hypertension; 20.2% had diabetes mellitus (DM) and 6.5% had congestive heart failure (CHF). The overall pooled CIN incidence, defined as SCr increase ≥ 25% or ≥ 0.5 mg/dL, was 4.96% (95%CI: 3.79–6.47). Data analysis showed an association between CIN and the presence of renal failure, DM, malignancy, age > 65 years and use of NSAIDs with an odds ratio of 1.73 (95%CI: 1.06-2.82), 1.87. (95%CI: 1.55-2.26), 1.79 (95%CI: 1.03-3.11), 1.95 (95%CI: 1.02-3.70) and 2.32 (95%CI: 1.04-5.19), respectively hypertension, anemia and CF did not were associated (p=0.13, p=0.38, p=0.40). The mean incidence of CIN after intravenous iodinated CECT was low and was associated with renal failure, diabetes, presence of malignancy, older age, and use of NSAIDs.

abstract: The high affinity of cell-free hemoglobin (CFH) for nitric oxide (NO) may limit the use of CFH as an oxygenated blood substitute because it scavenges NO, causing vasoconstriction and hypertension. However, the extent to which changes in perivascular levels of NO after intravascular administration of hemoglobin (Hb) with different molecular dimensions correlate with vasoconstrictive responses in the microcirculation is unknown. The aim of the study was to determine the vasoconstrictive effects after (1) bolus infusion of alpha-cross-linked Hb; (2) polymerized cattle Hb; or (3) polyethylene glycol-decorated Hb (PEG-Hb), by measuring in vivo microvascular diameter, blood flow, perivascular NO concentration, and systemic hemodynamic parameters. All CFHs induced a decrease in perivascular NO levels that was not associated with microvascular responses. PEG-Hb (the largest molecular size) maintained blood flow, while the others caused vasoconstriction and decreased perfusion. All solutions increased mean blood pressure due to vasoconstriction and blood volume expansion, except PEG-Hb, which increased blood pressure due to blood volume expansion and maintenance of cardiac output. In conclusion, perivascular reduction of NO is similar for all Hb solutions because NO binding affinities are similar; However, the effect on vascular resistance is related to the type of molecular modification, molecular size, and affinity for oxygen.

This term refers to hemoglobin that is not contained within red blood cells and is being considered for its properties and effects when used as a blood replacement fluid. This is distinctly different from the gene Complement Factor H, which is a regulator of the complement cascade involved in the immune response and has the common abbreviation CFH.  2. **Focus on Vasoactive Effects of Hemoglobins**: The study investigates how various forms of modified hemoglobin influence vasoconstriction and blood flow in the context of their potential use as blood substitutes. The research focuses purely on the pharmacodynamic effects of cell-free hemoglobin variants in a controlled experimental setup. abstract: In some families, a predisposition to colorectal cancer is linked to markers on chromosome 2. Molecular characteristics of "familial" cancers were compared with sporadic colon cancers. Neither familial nor sporadic cancers showed loss of heterozygosity for chromosome 2 markers, and mutation rates in KRAS, P53, and APC were similar in the two groups of tumors. However, most familial cancers had widespread changes in short DNA repeat sequences, indicating that multiple replication errors occurred during tumor development. Thirteen percent of sporadic cancers had identical abnormalities, and these tumors shared biological features with familial cases. These data suggest a mechanism of familial tumorigenesis that differs from that mediated by classical tumor suppressor genes.

APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) is a well-known tumor suppressor gene that is critical in the development and maintenance of colorectal cancer, particularly through its role in the Wnt signaling pathway, which is pivotal for cell cycle regulation and cellular adhesion.  2. **Similar Mutational Incidence in Familial and Sporadic Cases**: The study finds that mutations in the APC gene occur at comparable rates in familial colorectal cancers (those that may run in families due to genetic predispositions) and sporadic (random and non-hereditary) cases. This suggests a general relevance of APC mutations across different types of colorectal cancer scenarios.  3. **Context of Study with Other Genes**: By studying APC in conjunction with other genes like KRAS and P53, the research provides a broader genetic landscape of colorectal cancer. This comparison helps illustrate the unique or converging paths of tumorigenesis influenced by these critical genes, including APC.  4. **Mechanistic Insights**: Although the abstract indicates that familial types of colorectal cancers exhibit widespread alterations in DNA sequences suggesting numerous replication errors, the comparable incidence of APC mutations in familial and sporadic cancers highlights the gene's role beyond just familial cases. This is directly relevant to assessing how changes in the APC gene interact with the pathophysiology of the disease. abstract: We have previously established long-term culture conditions in which individual crypts or stem cells derived from the mouse small intestine are expanded for long periods of time. Expanding crypts undergo multiple crypt fission events, simultaneously generating villus-like epithelial domains containing all differentiated cell types. We adapted culture conditions to grow similar epithelial organoids from mouse colon and human small intestine and colon. Based on the mouse small intestine culture system, we optimized mouse and human colon culture systems. Adding Wnt3A to a combination of growth factors applied to mouse colon crypts allowed them to expand indefinitely. Addition of nicotinamide, along with a small molecule inhibitor of Alk and a p38 inhibitor, was required for long-term culture of human small intestine and colon tissues. The culture system also allowed the growth of mouse Apc-deficient adenomas, human colorectal cancer cells, and human metaplastic epithelia from regions of Barrett's esophagus. We have developed technology that can be used to study infected, inflamed or cancerous tissues from the human gastrointestinal tract. These tools may have applications in regenerative biology through ex vivo expansion of the intestinal epithelium. Studies of these cultures indicate that there is no inherent limit to the replicative potential (or Hayflick limit) of adult stem cells ex vivo.

abstract: Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the most common malignancy of the digestive system. The aim of this study was to identify gene signatures in CRC and reveal their potential mechanisms. Gene expression profiles of GSE21815 were downloaded from the GEO database. The GSE21815 dataset contained 141 samples, including 132 CRC and 9 normal colon epithelium. Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genome Pathway (KEGG) enrichment analyzes were performed, and a protein-protein interaction network of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) was constructed with Cytoscape software. In total, 3500 DEGs were identified in CRC, including 1370 up-regulated genes and 2130 down-regulated genes. The results of GO analysis showed that the up-regulated DEGs were significantly enriched in biological processes (BP), including cell cycle, cell division, and cell proliferation; Downregulated DEGs were significantly enriched in biological processes, including immune response, intracellular signaling cascade, and defense response. KEGG pathway analysis showed that up-regulated DEGs were enriched in cell cycle and DNA replication, and down-regulated DEGs were enriched in drug metabolism, xenobiotic metabolism by cytochrome P450, and retinol metabolism pathways. The top 10 hub genes, GNG2, AGT, SAA1, ADCY5, LPAR1, NMU, IL8, CXCL12, GNAI1, and CCR2 were identified from the PPI network, and the subnetworks showed that these genes were involved in important pathways, including the G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway, gastrin -CREB signaling pathway with PKC and MAPK and extracellular matrix organization. In conclusion, the present study showed that the identified DEGs and hub genes contribute to our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the development of CRC and can be used as molecular targets and diagnostic biomarkers for CRC treatment.

abstract: The aim of this study was to identify K-ras mutations as a marker for isolated tumor cells in liver, lymph node and bone marrow samples from patients with colorectal cancer. PCR-RFLP analysis was used for their detection, the sensitivity of which exceeds routine histopathology by at least 1 order of magnitude. In addition, the ratio of mutated to wild-type alleles was determined by the internal standard. 74 of 199 patients (37.5%) were found to have K-ras-positive tumors. Of these, 60 (81%) were mutated in codon 12 and 14 (19%) in codon 13 (P < 0.001). In addition, 14 organs were found to be K-ras positive, of which 13 were from 12 patients with K-ras-positive tumors (16%) and 1 from a patient with K-ras-negative tumors (0.8%). Eight patients showed liver damage and 6 showed lymph node involvement. Notably, none of the bone marrow samples were found to be K-ras positive (P < 0.017 vs. liver involvement). DNA sequence analysis of the tumor showed that GGT (Gly) was changed to GAT (Asp; 35%), GTT (Val; 32%), AGT (Ser; 13%), GCT (Ala; 10%), TGT (Cys; 8%) and CGT (Arg; 2%) for codon 12, and GAC (Asp) as the only type of codon 13 mutation. In colorectal carcinoma, the ratio of K-ras mutation to wild-type alleles ranged from 4. orders of magnitude (10(0)-10(-4), median: 10(-2)) and was associated with both residual tumor burden (R1/2; P = 0.028) and distant metastases (M1; P = 0.057). These results show that the detection of K-ras mutated alleles by PCR-RFLP in colorectal carcinoma patients can help to identify isolated tumor cells. High ratios of K-ras alleles were associated with some negative prognostic parameters (R,M). Consistent with its function as a primary filter for colorectal carcinoma cells, the liver was more frequently stained with K-ras-positive cells than the bone marrow.

abstract: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of blindness in the elderly. We report a genome-wide screen for AMD-associated polymorphisms in 96 cases and 50 controls. Among 116,204 genotyped single-nucleotide polymorphisms, an intronic and common variant of the complement factor H gene (CFH) was strongly associated with AMD (nominal P value <10(-7)). In individuals homozygous for the risk allele, the probability of AMD increases 7.4-fold (95% confidence interval 2.9 to 19). Repeat screening revealed a polymorphism in linkage disequilibrium with the risk allele representing a tyrosine-histidine change at amino acid 402. This polymorphism is in the region of CFH that binds heparin and C-reactive protein. The CFH gene is located on chromosome 1 in a region repeatedly associated with AMD in family-based studies.

abstract: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the most common cause of irreversible blindness in the elderly in developed countries. Our previous studies implicated complement activation in drusin formation, a hallmark lesion of AMD. Here we show that factor H (HF1), a major inhibitor of the alternative complement pathway, accumulates in drusen and is synthesized by the retinal pigment epithelium. Because previous linkage analyzes identified chromosome 1q25-32 containing the factor H gene (HF1/CFH) as an AMD susceptibility locus, we analyzed HF1 for genetic variation in two independent cohorts consisting of approximately 900 AMD cases and 400 matched controls. We found associations of eight common HF1 SNPs with AMD; Two common nonsense variants show highly significant associations (I62V, chi2 = 26.1 and P = 3.2 x 10(-7) and Y402H, chi2 = 54.4 and P = 1.6 x 10(-13)). Haplotype analysis reveals that multiple HF1 variants confer increased or decreased risk of AMD. One common risk haplotype is present at a frequency of 50% in AMD cases and 29% in controls [odds ratio (OR) = 2.46, 95% confidence interval (1.95–3.11)]. Homozygotes for this haplotype accounted for 24% of cases and 8% of controls [OR = 3.51, 95% confidence interval (2.13-5.78)]. Several protective haplotypes (OR = 0.44-0.55) were also identified, further implicating HF1 function in the pathogenetic mechanisms underlying AMD. We propose that genetic variation in regulators of the alternative complement pathway, when combined with a precipitating event such as infection, underlies much of AMD in the human population.

abstract: To investigate the possible protective effect of the dietary antioxidant quercetin on retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell dysfunction and cellular senescence that occurs in age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The major flavonoid quercetin was studied on RPE cells in vitro. Cultured human RPE cells were incubated with different concentrations of quercetin for 24 h. Cells were then treated with 150 to 300 μM hydrogen peroxide for 2 h. Mitochondrial function was measured using the MTT assay and cell viability by live-dead staining assay. Intracellular glutathione levels were determined using a glutathione assay kit. Apoptosis was quantified by caspase-3 assay, and cellular senescence was quantified by beta-galactosidase staining. The expression of senescence-associated transmembrane protein caveolin-1 was investigated by Northern and Western blot analysis. Treatment with hydrogen peroxide caused a significant decrease in mitochondrial function (52%) and cell viability (71%), whereas preincubation with 50 μM quercetin reduced this decrease in a dose-dependent manner. Quercetin treatment did not show any detectable effect on intracellular glutathione levels at any concentration of quercetin used. Hydrogen peroxide-induced caspase-3 activation was reduced by 50 μM quercetin, 1.9- to 1.4-fold, compared with untreated controls (P < 0.001). Hydrogen peroxide caused a large (>90%) dose-dependent increase in beta-galactosidase-positive cells, whereas in untreated controls only single cells expressed this enzyme (<5%). This increase in cellular senescence was significantly reduced by quercetin in a dose-dependent manner. The highest attenuation was achieved at 50 μM quercetin. Quercetin induced a significant dose-dependent decrease in caveolin-1 mRNA 48 h after hydrogen peroxide treatment. After 96 hours of incubation, caveolin-1 protein levels also decreased. Data show that quercetin can protect RPE cells from oxidative damage and cell senescence in a dose-dependent manner in vitro. The authors hypothesize that this increase in antioxidant capacity—among other mechanisms, such as intracellular redox status—is also mediated by inhibition of caveolin-1 upregulation. Downregulation of caveolin-1 may be important for the retinal pigment epithelium to prevent apoptotic cell death in response to cellular stress, a condition implicated in the early pathogenesis of AMD. Therefore, the authors believe that the use of antioxidant dietary flavonoids, such as quercetin, is a promising approach in the prevention of early AMD.

abstract: Study of the effects of subtoxic levels of hydrogen peroxide (H(2)O(2)) on the expression and release of interleukin-6 by retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells and study of the relevant signaling pathways. Cultured human RPE cells were stimulated with different subtoxic concentrations of H(2)O(2) for different time periods. Conditioned medium and cells were collected. IL-6 in medium and IL-6 mRNA in harvested cells were measured using IL-6 enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit and reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction, respectively. of nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-κB) in nuclear extracts and phosphorylated p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), and c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNK) in and without cultured cells. H(2)O(2) was measured by NF-κB and MAPK enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kits. Inhibitors of p38 (SB203580), ERK (UO1026), JNK (SP600125), and NF-κB (BAY11-7082) were added to the cultures before H(2)O(2) addition to test their effects (.) H(2)O(2) subtoxic levels (100 μM and less) increased IL-6 mRNA levels and IL-6 protein secretion by cultured human RPE cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner. This was accompanied by an increase in NF-κB in nuclear extracts and phosphorylated p38 MAPK, ERK, and JNK in cell lysates, particularly p38 and NF-κB. NF-κB inhibitor reduced H(2)O(2)-induced expression of IL-6. A p38 inhibitor, but not an ERK or JNK inhibitor, completely abrogated H(2)O(2)-induced IL-6 expression by RPE cells. The p38 inhibitor also abolished the increase in NF-κB in nuclear extracts from H(2)O(2)-treated cells. H(2)O(2) stimulated the production of IL-6, a key factor in the modulation of immune responses, inflammatory processes and the development of autoimmune diseases, which has recently been shown to increase age-related macular degeneration. (and so on). This may be the molecular link between oxidative stress and inflammatory/autoimmune responses in AMD and may be a new target for AMD treatment.

abstract: Holoproencephaly (HPE) is a common developmental defect of the forebrain and often the midface in humans with both genetic and environmental causes. HPE has a prevalence of 1:250 during embryogenesis and 1:16,000 in neonates and involves incomplete development and septation of midline structures in the central nervous system (CNS) with a wide range of clinical severity. Alobar HPE, the most severe form, usually incompatible with postnatal life, involves complete failure of the forebrain to divide into right and left hemispheres and features facial abnormalities including cyclopia, a primitive nasal structure (proboscis), and/or a midfacial cleft. . At the mild end of the spectrum, findings may include microcephaly, mild hypotelorism, a single maxillary central incisor, and other malformations (Fig. 1). This phenotypic variation also occurs between affected members of the same family. The underlying molecular basis of HPE is unknown, although teratogens, nonrandom chromosomal abnormalities, and familial forms with autosomal dominant and recessive inheritance have been described. HPE3 on chromosome 7q36 is one of at least four different loci implicated in HPE. Here, we report the identification of human Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) as HPE3—the first known gene to cause HPE. Analyzing 30 autosomal dominant HPE (ADHPE) families, we found five families harboring different heterozygous SHH mutations. Two of these mutations predict premature termination of the SHH protein, while the others alter the highly conserved alpha-helix-1 motif or the vicinity of the signal cleavage site.

abstract: The steroid alkaloid cyclopamine produces cyclopia and holoproencephaly when administered to gastrulation-stage amniotic embryos. Cyclopamine-induced malformation in chick embryos is associated with disruption of dorsoventral formation of the neural tube and somites. Cell types normally induced by SH in the ventral neural tube are either absent or aberrant in the ventral midline after cyclopamine treatment, whereas dorsal cell types normally repressed by SH appear ventrally. In cyclopamine-treated embryos, somites show Pax7 expression throughout, indicating failure of sclerotome induction. Cyclopamine at concentrations of 20-100 nM blocks the response of neural plate explants to recombinant Shh-N in a dose-dependent manner. Similar concentrations did not affect the post-translational modification of Shh by cholesterol in transfected COS-1 cells. Comparison of the effects of cyclopamine with the holoproencephaly-causing cholesterol synthesis inhibitor AY-9944 shows that cyclopamine does not cause malformations by interfering with cholesterol metabolism. Although AY-9944 does not terminate Shh signaling in ovo, it blocks the response to Shh-N in explants cultured without an exogenous cholesterol source. As predicted by current models of cholesterol metabolism regulation, the response to shh-N in AY-9944-treated explants is restored by exogenous cholesterol supply. However, exogenous cholesterol did not restore Shh signaling in cyclopamine-treated explants. These findings suggest that cyclopamine-induced teratogenesis is due to a more direct antagonism of Shh signal transduction.

abstract: Plasma vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) levels are significantly elevated in patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer (HRPC) compared to patients with localized disease and are associated with disease progression in patients with other cancers. Therefore, we measured VEGF levels in plasma prospectively collected from patients enrolled in the Cancer and Leukemia Group B 9480, an intergroup study of suramin in patients with HRPC, to determine whether these levels had prognostic value. Pretreatment plasma was collected from patients with HRPC enrolled in Cancer and Leukemia Group B 9480. In a subset of samples representing the entire cohort, plasma VEGF levels were determined in duplicate using a Quantiglo chemiluminescent ELISA kit (R&D Systems, Minneapolis, MN). Statistical analyzes were performed to determine the correlation between pretreatment plasma VEGF levels and overall survival time. The proportional hazards model was used to estimate the prognostic value of different cut points in multivariate models. Plasma VEGF levels in this population ranged from 4-885 pg/ml, with a median level of 83 pg/ml. As a continuous variable, plasma VEGF levels inversely correlated with survival time (P = 0.002). Using different exploratory cut points, plasma VEGF levels appeared to correlate with survival. In multivariate models in which other prognostic factors (serum prostate-specific antigen, alkaline phosphatase, evidence of measurable disease, and hemoglobin) were included, plasma VEGF levels were significant at various time points tested. Although these data are exploratory and require confirmation in an independent data set, they suggest that VEGF may have clinical relevance in patients with HRPC.

abstract: To understand the role of MALAT-1 in prostate cancer, we evaluated its expression in prostate cancer tissues and cell lines. We also studied the therapeutic effects of MALAT-1 silencing on castration-resistant prostate cancer cells in vitro and in vivo. Quantitative reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction was used to detect MALAT-1 expression in prostate cancer tissues and cell lines. siRNA against MALAT-1 was generated and the effect of silencing was examined by quantitative reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction. The biological effects of MALAT-1 siRNA on cells were examined by studying cell proliferation using cell counting kits and cell colony assays, as well as cell migration by in vitro scratch assay, cell invasion by Transwell® invasion assay, and cell cycle by flow cytometry. We next investigated the effect of therapeutic siRNA targeting MALAT-1 on castration-resistant prostate cancer in vivo. MALAT-1 is upregulated in human prostate cancer tissues and cell lines. Higher MALAT-1 expression is associated with higher Gleason score, prostate-specific antigen, tumor stage, and castration-resistant prostate cancer. MALAT-1 depletion by siRNA inhibited prostate cancer cell growth, invasion, and migration and induced cell cycle arrest in G0/G1 phases of castration-resistant prostate cancer. Importantly, tumor delivery of therapeutic siRNA targeting MALAT-1 resulted in delayed tumor growth and reduced prostate cancer xenografts in castrated male nude mice, with concomitant prolongation of tumor-bearing mice survival. MALAT-1 may be required to maintain prostate tumorigenesis and is involved in prostate cancer progression. Thus, MALAT-1 may be a potential therapeutic target for castration-resistant prostate cancer.

abstract: Prostate cancer is the most common solid tumor in men and shares the hallmark of all cancers with elevated, non-homeostatic cell proliferation. Here, we tested the hypothesis that the SONIC HEDGEHOG (SHH)-GLI signaling pathway is involved in prostate cancer. We report the expression of components of the SHH-GLI pathway in adult human prostate cancer, with often enhanced levels in tumors compared with normal prostate epithelium. Blockade of the pathway with cyclopamine or anti-SHH antibodies inhibits proliferation of GLI1+/PSA+ prostate tumor primary cultures. Conversely, SHH can enhance tumor cell proliferation, suggesting that autocrine signaling may often maintain tumor growth. Furthermore, blockade of the pathway in three metastatic prostate cancer cell lines with cyclopamine or GLI1 RNA interference resulted in inhibition of cell proliferation, indicating the activation of the cell-autonomous pathway at different levels and demonstrating the important role of GLI1 in human cells. Our data demonstrate the dependence of prostate cancer on SHH-GLI function and suggest a novel therapeutic approach.

abstract: During fetal prostate development, sonic hedgehog (Shh) expression by the urogenital sinus epithelium activates Gli-1 expression in the surrounding mesenchyme and promotes proliferation in the nascent duct. Shh signaling is down-regulated at the end of prostate duct development. However, studies of adult prostate tissues reveal significant levels of Shh signaling in normal, hyperplastic, and malignant prostate tissue. In cancer samples, Shh expression is localized to the tumor epithelium, while Gli-1 expression is localized to the tumor stroma. The close correlation between Shh and Gli-1 expression levels suggests active signaling between tissue layers. To determine whether Shh-Gli-1 signaling may be functionally important for tumor growth and progression, we performed experiments with an LNCaP xenograft tumor model and demonstrated that: 1). Shh expressed by LNCaP tumor cells activates Gli-1 expression in the tumor stroma, 2). Genetically engineered Shh overexpression in LNCaP cells leads to increased tumor stromal Gli-1 expression and 3). Shh overexpression dramatically accelerates tumor growth. These data suggest that Hedgehog signaling from prostate cancer cells to the stroma can induce the expression of paracrine signals that promote tumor growth.

abstract: Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) plays an important role in host defense and tumor growth control. Therefore, anti-TNF antibody therapy may increase the risk of serious infections and malignancies. To assess the extent to which anti-TNF antibody therapy may increase the risk of serious infections and malignancies in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, we performed a meta-analysis to derive estimates of rare adverse events occurring in randomized trials of anti-TNF therapy. A systematic literature review of EMBASE, MEDLINE, the Cochrane Library, and electronic abstracts of scientific meetings was conducted through December 2005. 2 licensed anti-TNF antibodies. We included randomized, placebo-controlled trials of 2 licensed anti-TNF antibodies (infliximab and adalimumab) used for 12 weeks or longer in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Nine trials met our inclusion criteria, including 3493 patients who received anti-TNF antibody treatment and 1512 patients who received placebo. Data on study characteristics to assess study quality and intention-to-treat data on serious infections and malignancies were extracted. Published information from the trials was supplemented by direct contact between principal investigators and industry sponsors. We calculated the pooled odds ratio (Mantel-Haenszel methods with discontinuity adjustment designed for sparse data) for malignancy and serious infections (infection requiring antimicrobial therapy and/or hospitalization) in anti-TNF-treated patients compared with placebo patients. We evaluated the effect for high and low doses separately. The pooled odds ratio for malignancy was 3.3 (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.2–9.1) and for serious infection was 2.0 (95% CI, 1.3–3.1). Malignancies were significantly more common in patients treated with higher doses than in patients receiving lower doses of anti-TNF antibodies. For patients treated with anti-TNF antibodies in the included studies, the required number to harm was 154 (95% CI, 91-500) for 1 additional malignancy during the 6- to 12-month treatment period. The required number of harms for serious infections was 59 (95% CI, 39-125) between 3 and 12 months of treatment. There is evidence of an increased risk of serious infections and a dose-dependent increased risk of malignancy in patients with rheumatoid arthritis treated with anti-TNF antibody therapy. A formal meta-analysis of data from randomized controlled trials with data on rare adverse events serves as a basis for assessing adverse drug effects.

abstract: Recent insights into rheumatoid arthritis (RA) have prompted an update of the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) RA management recommendations. A large international task force based its decisions on evidence from 3 systematic literature reviews, developed 4 guiding principles and 12 recommendations (vs. 3 and 14, respectively, in 2013). Recommendations apply to conventional synthetic (cs) disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) (methotrexate (MTX), leflunomide, sulfasalazine); Glucocorticoids (GC); Biologic (b) DMARDs (tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegoli, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab), abatacept, rituximab, tocilizumab, sarilumab and sirukumab (targeted DM) ) DMARDs (Janus k Naza ( Jak) inhibitors tofacitinib, baricitinib). Monotherapy, combination therapy, treatment strategies (treatment-to-target), and targets of sustained clinical remission (as defined by American College of Rheumatology (ACR)-EULAR logical or index criteria) or low disease activity are discussed. Cost aspects were considered. As a first strategy, the task force recommends MTX (rapid escalation to 25 mg/week) plus short-term GC, with a goal of >50% improvement at 3 and goal at 6 months. If this fails, stratification is recommended. Without unfavorable prognostic markers, switching to or adding another csDMARD (plus short-term GC) is recommended. In the presence of unfavorable prognostic markers (autoantibodies, high disease activity, early erosion, failure of 2 csDMARDs), any bDMARD (current practice) or Jak-inhibitor should be added to the csDMARD. If this fails, any other bDMARD or tsDMARD is recommended. If the patient is in sustained remission, bDMARDs may be tapered. For each recommendation, the level of evidence and agreement of the working group are provided, both of which are generally very high. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national rheumatology societies, hospital officials, social care agencies, and regulators about the latest EULAR consensus on the management of RA aimed at achieving the best outcomes with current therapies.

abstract: Statins, 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase inhibitors approved for lowering cholesterol, may also be useful in treating inflammatory diseases. Atorvastatin (Lipitor) was tested in chronic and relapsing experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis, a CD4(+) Th1-mediated central nervous system (CNS) demyelinating disease model in multiple sclerosis. Here we show that oral atorvastatin prevents or reverses chronic and relapsing paralysis. Atorvastatin induced STAT6 phosphorylation and secretion of Th2 cytokines (interleukin (IL)-4, IL-5, and IL-10) and transforming growth factor (TGF)-beta. Conversely, STAT4 phosphorylation was inhibited and the secretion of Th1 cytokines (IL-2, IL-12, interferon (IFN)-gamma, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha) was inhibited. Atorvastatin promotes the differentiation of Th0 cells into Th2 cells. Upon adoptive transfer, these Th2 cells protected recipient mice from EAE induction. Atorvastatin decreases central nervous system infiltration and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II expression. Treatment of microglia inhibited IFN-gamma-inducible transcription at multiple MHC class II transactivator (CIITA) promoters and inhibited class II upregulation. Atorvastatin inhibits IFN-gamma-induced expression of CD40, CD80 and CD86 costimulatory molecules. l-Mevalonate, a product of HMG-CoA reductase, modified the effect of atorvastatin on antigen-presenting cells (APC) and T cells. Treatment of APC or T cells with atorvastatin inhibited antigen-specific T-cell activation. Thus, atorvastatin has pleiotropic immunomodulatory effects involving both APC and T-cells. Statins may be useful in multiple sclerosis and other Th1-mediated autoimmune diseases.

abstract: Cardiovascular mortality, mainly due to rupture of unstable atherosclerotic plaques, is reduced by 3-hydroxy-methyl-glutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase inhibitors. Inflammatory cells that are attracted to vascular damage by chemokines are involved in the process of plaque breakdown. In cultured vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMC) and U937 mononuclear cells, we studied the effect of atorvastatin (ATV) on nuclear factor kappaB (NF-kappaB) activity, which is an inducer of mRNA expression of chemokines such as interferon-inducible protein 10 (IP-10) and monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (MCP-1). Angiotensin II (Ang II) and tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha) increased NF-kappaB activity in VSMC (2- and 5-fold, respectively). Preincubation of cells with 10(-7) mol/L ATP reduced this activation (44 and 53%). Inhibition was reversed by mevalonate, farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP) and geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP), but not by other isoprenoids. Coinciding with the activation of NF-kappaB in VSMC, there was a decrease in cytoplasmic IkappaB levels, which was restored by pretreatment with Atv. Ang II and TNF-alpha induced IP-10 (1.5 and 3.4-fold) and MCP-1 (2.4 and 4-fold) expression in VSMC. ATV reduced this overexpression by approximately 38 and 35% (IP-10) and 54 and 39% (MCP-1), respectively. Our results strongly suggest that Atv, by inhibiting NF-kappaB activity and chemokine gene expression, can reduce inflammation in atherosclerotic lesions and play a role in lesion stabilization.

abstract: ACE2, the first known human homolog of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), was identified by 5' sequencing of a human heart failure ventricular cDNA library. ACE2 has an apparent signal peptide, a single metalloprotease active site, and a transmembrane domain. The catalytic domains of ACE2 and ACE metalloprotease are 42% identical, and comparison of genomic structures indicates that the two genes arose by duplication. Unlike the more ubiquitous ACE, ACE2 transcripts are found only in heart, kidney, and 23 human tissue samples. Immunohistochemistry shows ACE2 protein predominantly in the endothelium of coronary and renal vessels and in the renal tubular epithelium. Active ACE2 enzyme is released from transfected cells by cleavage of the N-terminal to the transmembrane domain. Recombinant ACE2 hydrolyzes the carboxy-terminal leucine of angiotensin I to form angiotensin 1-9, which is converted to the angiotensin peptide ACE in vitro and by cardiomyocytes in culture. ACE2 can also degrade des-Arg bradykinin and neurotensin, but not bradykinin or 15 other vasoactive and hormonal peptides tested. ACE2 is not inhibited by lisinopril or captopril. The organ- and cell-specific expression of ACE2 and its unique cleavage of key vasoactive peptides indicate an important role of ACE2 in the local renin-angiotensin system of the heart and kidney. The full text of this article is available at http://www. circusaha.org.

abstract: A novel human zinc metalloprotease with significant homology to human angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) (40% identity and 61% similarity) has been identified. This metalloprotease (angiotensin-converting enzyme homolog (ACEH)) contains a single HEXXH zinc-binding domain and retains other critical residues characteristic of the ACE family. The predicted protein sequence consists of 805 amino acids, including a potential 17-amino acid N-terminal signal peptide sequence and a putative C-terminal membrane anchor. Expression in Chinese hamster ovary cells of a soluble, truncated form of ACEH lacking the transmembrane and cytosolic domains produces a glycoprotein of 120 kDa that can cleave angiotensin I and angiotensin II, but not bradykinin or Hip-His-Leu. During the hydrolysis of angiotensins, ACEH functions only as a carboxypeptidase. ACEH activity is inhibited by EDTA but not by classical ACE inhibitors such as captopril, lisinopril or enalaprilat. Identification of the genomic sequence of ACEH revealed that the ACEH gene contains 18 exons, several of which have significant size similarity to the first 17 exons of human ACE. The gene maps to the chromosomal location Xp22. Northern blot analysis showed that the ACEH mRNA transcript is approximately 3.4 kilobase pairs and is most highly expressed in the testis, kidney, and heart. This is the first report of a mammalian homologue of ACE and has implications for our understanding of cardiovascular and renal function.

abstract: Atrial fibrillation is a common but potentially preventable complication after coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. To assess the nature and outcomes of atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery and to develop a comprehensive risk index to better identify patients at risk for atrial fibrillation. Prospective follow-up of 4657 patients undergoing CABG surgery between November 1996 and June 2000 at 70 centers in 17 countries selected using a systematic sampling technique. From a derivation cohort of 3093 patients, associations between predictor variables and postoperative atrial fibrillation were identified to develop a risk model that was evaluated in a validation cohort of 1564 patients. New atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery. A total of 1503 patients (32.3%) developed atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery. Postoperative atrial fibrillation was associated with greater subsequent resource utilization as well as cognitive changes, renal dysfunction, and infection. Among patients in the derivation cohort, risk factors associated with atrial fibrillation were advanced age (odds ratio [OR] per 10-year increase, 1.75; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.59-1.93); history of atrial fibrillation (OR, 2.11; 95% CI, 1.57–2.85) or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (OR, 1.43; 95% CI, 1.09–1.87); valve surgery (OR, 1.74; 95% CI, 1.31-2.32); and postoperative discontinuation of a beta-blocker (OR, 1.91; 95% CI, 1.52-2.40) or an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (OR 1.69; 95% CI, 1.38-2.08). Conversely, a reduced risk was associated with beta-blockers (OR, 0.32; 95% CI, 0.22-0.46), ACE inhibitors (OR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.48-0.79), potassium supplementation (OR, 0.53); 95% CI, 0.42-0.68) and NSAIDs (OR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.40-0.60). The resulting multivariable risk index had adequate discriminatory power under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve of 0.77 in the validation sample. Forty-three percent (640/1503) of patients with atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery experienced more than 1 episode of atrial fibrillation. Predictors of recurrent atrial fibrillation included older age, history of congestive heart failure, left ventricular hypertrophy, aortic atherosclerosis, bicaval venous cannulation, discontinuation of ACE inhibitor or beta-blocker therapy, and use of amiodarone or digoxin. ). Patients with recurrent atrial fibrillation had longer hospital stays and experienced greater infectious, renal, and neurological complications than patients with a single episode. We developed and validated models that predict the occurrence of atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery based on the analysis of a large multicenter international cohort. Our findings suggest that treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and/or NSAIDs may provide protection. Atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery is associated with significant complications.

abstract: Carvedilol improved the symptomatic status of patients with moderate to severe heart failure in single-center studies, but its clinical effects were not evaluated in large, multicenter studies. We enrolled 278 patients with moderate to severe heart failure (6-minute walk distance, 150 to 450 m) and left ventricular ejection fraction < or = 0.35 in 31 centers. After an open-label, run-in period, each patient was randomly assigned (double-blind) to placebo (n = 145) or carvedilol (n = 133; target dose, 25 to 50 mg daily) for 6 months, while background therapy with digoxin, diuretics, and It remained unchanged with ACE inhibitors. Compared with placebo, patients in the carvedilol group had a greater rate of symptom improvement and a lower risk of clinical deterioration as assessed by changes in NYHA functional class (P = .014) or patient-rated global assessment of progress. (P = .002) or by a physician (P < .001). In addition, treatment with carvedilol was associated with a significant increase in ejection fraction (P < .001) and a significant reduction in the combined risk of morbidity and mortality (P = .029). In contrast, carvedilol therapy had little effect on indirect measures of patient benefit, including changes in exercise tolerance or quality of life scores. The effects of the drug were similar in patients with ischemic heart disease or idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy as a cause of heart failure. These findings indicate that, in addition to its beneficial effects on survival, carvedilol provides significant clinical benefit in patients with moderate to severe heart failure treated with digoxin, diuretics, and ACE inhibitors.

abstract: The advent of targeted therapy for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has highlighted the importance of characterizing pathways to identify novel molecular targets for treatment. We evaluated mTOR signaling in human HCC as well as the antitumor effect of dual-level blockade of the mTOR pathway. The mTOR pathway was evaluated using integrated data from mutation analysis (direct sequencing), DNA copy number changes (SNP-array), messenger RNA levels (quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and gene expression microarray) and protein activation (immunostaining) 351 Human sample [HCC (n = 314) and non-cancerous tissue (n = 37)]. The effects of dual blockade of mTOR signaling using a rapamycin analog (everolimus) and an epidermal/vascular endothelial growth factor receptor inhibitor (AEE788) were evaluated in liver cancer cell lines and a xenograft model. Aberrant mTOR signaling (p-RPS6) was present in half of the cases, associated with activation of the insulin-like growth factor pathway, upregulation of epidermal growth factor, and PTEN dysregulation. PTEN and PI3KCA-B mutations were rare events. Chromosomal gain in RICTOR (25% of patients) and positive p-RPS6 staining are associated with relapse. RICTOR-specific siRNA knockdown reduced tumor cell viability in vitro. Blockade of mTOR signaling with everolimus in vitro and in a xenograft model slowed tumor growth and increased survival. This effect was enhanced in vivo after epidermal growth factor blockade. MTOR signaling has a critical role in the pathogenesis of HCC, with evidence for a role for RICTOR in hepato-oncogenesis. MTOR blockade with everolimus is effective in vivo. These findings form the basis for targeting the mTOR pathway in HCC in clinical trials.

abstract: The conserved serine/threonine kinase mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin), a downstream effector of the PI3K/AKT pathway, forms two distinct multiprotein complexes: mTORC1 and mTORC2. mTORC1 is sensitive to rapamycin, activates S6K1 and 4EBP1, which are involved in mRNA translation. It is activated by various stimuli such as growth factors, nutrients, energy and stress signals and essential signaling pathways such as PI3K, MAPK and AMPK to control cell growth, proliferation and survival. mTORC2 is considered resistant to rapamycin and is generally insensitive to nutrient and energy signals. It activates PKC-α and AKT and regulates the actin cytoskeleton. Deregulation of multiple elements of the mTOR pathway (PI3K amplification/mutation, PTEN loss of function, AKT overexpression, and S6K1, 4EBP1, and eIF4E overexpression) has been observed in many cancer types, particularly in melanoma, where alterations in key components. The mTOR pathway was reported to have a significant effect on tumor progression. Therefore, mTOR is an attractive therapeutic target, and mTOR inhibitors, including the rapamycin analogs deforolimus, everolimus, and temsirolimus, are in clinical trials for the treatment of many cancers, alone or in combination with inhibitors of other pathways. Importantly, temsirolimus and everolimus were recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of renal cell carcinoma, PNET, and giant cell astrocytoma. Small molecules that inhibit mTOR kinase activity and dual PI3K-mTOR inhibitors are also in development. In this review, we aim to explore relevant research, molecular mechanisms of signaling, including upstream activation and downstream effectors, and the role of mTOR in cancer, mainly melanoma.

PTEN acts as a tumor suppressor gene by negatively regulating the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway, primarily through its lipid phosphatase activity, which opposes PI3K action.  3. **Deregulation of the mTOR Pathway in Cancer**: The abstract discusses how alterations in the mTOR pathway components, including PTEN loss of function, can significantly affect tumor progression. abstract: CellMiner (http://discover.nci.nih.gov/cellminer) and CellMinerCDB (https://discover.nci.nih.gov/cellminercdb/) are web-based applications for mining publicly available genomic, molecular, and pharmacological databases. . Human Cancer Cell Lines including NCI-60, Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia, Drug Susceptibility Genomics in Cancer, Cancer Therapeutic Response Portal, NCI/DTP Small Cell Lung Cancer, and NCI Almanac Cell Line Kit. Here we present our RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) data for NCI-60 and their access and integration with other databases. Correlation with transcript microarray expression levels of identical genes and identical cell lines in CellMinerCDB demonstrates the high quality of these new RNA-seq data. We provide composite and isoform transcript expression data and demonstrate the diversity of isoform composition for individual cancers and pharmacologically relevant genes, including HRAS, PTEN, EGFR, RAD51, ALKBH2, BRCA1, ERBB2, TP53, FGFR2, and CTNND1. We identify cell-specific differences in overall levels of isoforms and show their association with the expression of RNA processing and splicing genes, as well as changes resulting from cancer and pharmacological gene sets. Gene-drug pairs related by pathways or functions show specific correlations relative to isoforms with composite gene expression, including ALKBH2-benzaldehyde, AKT3-vandetanib, BCR-imatinib, CDK1 and 20-palbociclib, CASP1-imexon- and FGF3. Loss of MUC1 20 amino acid variable number tandem repeats, used to elicit an immune response, and the presence of AR-V4 and -V7 isoforms of the androgen receptor in all NCI-60-derived tissues confirm translational relevance. In summary, we report RNA-seq data in our CellMiner and CellMinerCDB web applications, allowing them to be explored for both research and translational purposes. Significance: The current study provides RNA-sequencing data for NCI-60 cell lines available through both CellMiner and CellMinerCDB and represents an important pharmacogenomics resource for the field.

abstract: There is no effective therapy for patients with advanced medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Vandetanib, a single oral inhibitor of RET kinase, vascular endothelial growth factor receptor, and epidermal growth factor receptor signaling, previously demonstrated antitumor activity in a phase II trial in patients with advanced hereditary MTC. Patients with advanced MTC were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive vandetanib 300 mg/day or placebo. Patients with objective disease progression could choose to receive open-label vandetanib. The primary endpoint was progression-free survival (PFS), determined by independent Central Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) assessments. Between December 2006 and November 2007, 331 patients (median age, 52 years; 90% sporadic; 95% metastatic) were randomly assigned to receive vandetanib (231) or placebo (100). At data cutoff (July 2009; median follow-up, 24 months), 37% of patients had progressed and 15% had died. The study met its primary objective of prolonging PFS with vandetanib versus placebo (hazard ratio [HR], 0.46; 95% CI, 0.31 to 0.69; P < .001). Statistically significant advantages of vandetanib were also observed in objective response rate (P < .001), disease control rate (P = .001), and biochemical response (P < .001). The overall survival data were insignificant at data cutoff (HR, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.48 to 1.65). Final survival analysis will be performed when 50% of patients have died. Common adverse events (of any grade) were more common with vandetanib compared with placebo, including diarrhea (56% v 26%), rash (45% v 11%), nausea (33% v 16%), hypertension (32% v 5 ). %) and headache (26% v 9%). Vandetanib demonstrated therapeutic efficacy in a phase III trial in patients with advanced MTC (ClinicalTrials.gov NCT00410761).

abstract: We identified in-frame fusion transcripts of KIF5B (kinesin family 5B gene) and RET oncogene present in 1-2% of lung adenocarcinomas (LADCs) from Japan and the United States using whole transcriptome sequencing. The KIF5B-RET fusion causes aberrant activation of the RET kinase and is considered a novel driver mutation of LADC, as it dissociates from mutations or fusions in EGFR, KRAS, HER2, and ALK, and the RET tyrosine kinase inhibitor, vandeprestanib, anchorage-independent growth activity induced by fusion in NIH3T3 cells.

abstract: The ABCG2 c.421C>single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was determined in 660 healthy Finnish volunteers, 32 of whom participated in a pharmacokinetic crossover study involving 20 mg of atorvastatin and rosuvastatin. The allele frequency of the c.421A variant was 9.5% (95% confidence interval 8.1–11.3%). Subjects with the c.421AA genotype (n = 4) had a 72% greater mean area under the plasma atorvastatin concentration-time curve from time 0 to infinity (AUC(0-infinity)) than individuals with the c.421CC genotype (n = 16; in subjects with the c.421AA genotype, rosuvastatin AUC(0-infinity) was 100% greater than that of c.421CA (n = 12) and 144% greater than in those with the c.421CC genotype. Individuals with the c.421AA genotype showed a peak plasma concentration of rosuvastatin that was 108% higher than in the c.421CA genotype group and 131% higher than in the c.421CC genotype group (P < or = 0.01).Atorvastatin transport was increased in MDCKII-ABCG2 cells compared to apical vector control cells (transport ratio 1.9 +/- 0.1 vs. 1.1 +/- 0.1).These results indicate that the ABCG2 polymorphism strongly affects the pharmacokinetics of atorvastatin and, more importantly, the pharmacokinetics of rosuvastatin—potentially affecting the efficacy and toxicity of statin therapy.

abstract: A barrier to statin therapy is myopathy associated with systemic drug exposure. Our aim was to investigate the relationship between clinical and pharmacogenetic variables and statin concentrations in patients. In total, 299 patients receiving atorvastatin or rosuvastatin were prospectively referred to an outpatient referral center. The contribution of clinical variables and transporter gene polymorphisms to statin concentrations was assessed using multiple linear regression. We observed a 45-fold variation in statin concentrations among patients receiving the same dose. After adjusting for sex, age, body mass index, ethnicity, dose, and time since last dose, SLCO1B1 c.521T>C (P<0.001) and ABCG2 c.421C>A (P<0.01) were significant for rosuvastatin concentrations (adjusted R (2)=0.56 for the final model). Atorvastatin concentration was associated with SLCO1B1 c.388A>G (P<0.01) and c.521T>C (P<0.05) and 4β-hydroxycholesterol, a marker of CYP3A activity (adjusted R(2)=0.47). A second cohort of 579 patients from primary and specialty care databases was retrospectively genotyped. In this cohort, genotypes associated with statin concentrations were not differentially distributed between dosing groups, meaning that providers had not yet optimized the risk-benefit ratio for each patient. Almost 50% of patients routinely receiving the highest doses were predicted to have statin concentrations above the 90th percentile. Interindividual variability in statin exposure among patients is associated with uptake and efflux transporter polymorphisms. An algorithm incorporating genomic and clinical variables to prevent high levels of atorvastatin and rosuvastatin is described; Further research will determine whether this approach reduces the incidence of statin myopathy.

Instead, it mentions the association of ABCG2 polymorphisms with rosuvastatin concentration, but not with atorvastatin concentration. Since the hypothesis focuses on an interaction between atorvastatin and the ABCG2 gene, and this specific interaction is not directly addressed in the abstract, the relevance to the hypothesis is questionable.
