abstract: The organic cation transporter OCT1 (SLC22A1) mediates hepatic uptake and metabolism of the active tramadol metabolite (+)O-desmethyltramadol. In this study, the influence of OCT1 genetic polymorphism on tramadol pharmacokinetics and analgesic efficacy in patients recovering from surgery was analyzed in addition to CYP2D6 genotype. Postoperative patients receiving tramadol with patient-controlled analgesia were enrolled. Genotypes carrying 0, 1, or 2 active OCT1 alleles were determined, as were CYP2D6 genotypes. The primary endpoint was 24-hour postoperative tramadol consumption in patients with 0 versus at least 1 active OCT1 allele. A secondary endpoint was the OCT1-dependent plasma concentration (areas under the concentration-time curves) of the active tramadol metabolite (+)O-desmethyltramadol. Of the 205 patients, 19, 82, and 104 carried 0, 1, and 2 active OCT1 alleles, respectively. Cumulative tramadol consumption for patient-controlled analgesia was lowest in patients with 0 active OCT1 alleles compared with the group of patients with 1 or 2 active alleles (343 ± 235 vs 484 ± 276 mg; P = 0.03). Multiple regression revealed that the number of active OCT1 alleles (P = 0.014), CYP2D6 (P = 0.001), pain scores (P < 0.001), and the extent of surgery (0.034) had a significant effect on tramadol consumption. The plasma areas under the (+)O-desmethyltramadol concentration-time curves were 111.8 (95% confidence interval: 63.4–160.1), 80.2 (65.1–95.3), and 64.5 (51.9–77.2) h·ng·mL in the subjects. 0, 1, or 2 active OCT1 alleles (P = 0.03). Loss of OCT1 function resulted in decreased tramadol uptake and increased plasma concentrations of (+)O-desmethyltramadol in patients recovering from surgery. Therefore, OCT1 analysis alongside CYP2D6 genotype may improve genotype-dependent dose recommendations for tramadol.

abstract: The rate of cocaine entry into the brain is a critical factor influencing neuronal plasticity and the development of cocaine dependence. Until now, passive diffusion was thought to be the unique mechanism by which cocaine crosses the blood-brain barrier. We re-evaluated the mechanisms of cocaine transport across the blood-brain barrier using a human cerebral capillary endothelial cell line (hCMEC/D3) and mouse carotid perfusion. Both in vivo and in vitro cocaine transport studies have demonstrated the coexistence of a carrier-mediated process with passive diffusion. At pharmacological exposure levels, passive diffusion of cocaine accounted for only 22.5% of total cocaine influx in mice and 5.9% in hCMEC/D3 cells, whereas the rate of carrier-mediated influx was 3.4 times its rate of passive diffusion in vivo. Functional identification of this carrier-mediated transporter demonstrated the involvement of a proton antiporter that shared the properties of the previously characterized clonidine and nicotine transporters. Functional characterization suggests that the solute transporters (SLC) Oct (Slc22a1-3), Mate (Slc47a1) and Octn (Slc22a4-5) are not involved in cocaine transport in vivo and in vitro. Diphenhydramine, heroin, tramadol, cocaethylene, and norcocaine strongly inhibit the transport of cocaine, unlike benzoylecgonine. Transstimulation studies showed that diphenhydramine, nicotine, 3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine (ecstasy), and the cathinone compound 3,4-methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) were also cocaine transporter substrates. Cocaine transport across the BBB involves a proton-antiporter flux that is quantitatively much more important than its passive diffusion. Molecular identification and characterization of this transporter will provide new tools to understand its role in addiction mechanisms.

abstract: Transporters in the blood-brain barrier (BRB), as well as in the blood-brain barrier (BBB), regulate the distribution of compounds in the neural parenchyma. However, the expression of BRB transporters and their quantitative effects in vivo are still poorly understood. Clonidine and diphenhydramine are novel BBB drug/proton antiporter substrates. We assessed their transport to the BRB by in situ carotid perfusion in wild-type or knockout Oct1-3 (Slc22a1-3) mice. At pharmacological exposure levels, carrier-mediated BRB influx was 2- and 12-fold greater than the passive diffusion rates of clonidine and diphenhydramine, respectively. Functional identification demonstrated the involvement of a high-capacity potassium- and sodium-independent proton antiporter that shared characteristics of the previously characterized BBB transporter of clonidine, diphenhydramine, and cocaine. Functional characterization suggests that SLC transporters Oct1-3, Mate1 (Slc47a1) and Octn1-2 (Slc22a4-5) are not involved. Melanin/retinal toxic drugs such as antimalarials (amodiaquine, quinine), quinidine, and tricyclic antidepressants (imipramine) acted as inhibitors of this proton antiporter. The endogenous indole derivative tryptamine inhibits the transporter, unlike 5-HT (serotonin), dopamine, or L-DOPA. [(3)H]-Clonidine trans-stimulation experiments on the BRB have shown that diphenhydramine, nicotine, oxycodone, naloxone, tramadol, 3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine (MDMA, ecstasy), heroin, methadone, and verapamil are common substrates. The proton antiporter is physiologically involved in the transport of clonidine and diphenhydramine and is quantitatively more important than their passive diffusion flux across the mouse BRB. The characteristics of this molecularly unidentified transporter highlight its importance in regulating drug delivery to the retina and suggest that it has the ability to process several drugs.

abstract: This study determined whether SLC22A1 [encoding organic cation transporter 1 (OCT1)] genotype, in addition to postmenstrual age (mean gestational plus postnatal age) and CYP2D6 genotype, could explain tramadol (M) pharmacokinetic variation in early infants. Fifty infants, median postmenstrual age 39.5 (interquartile range: 36.8–41.3) weeks, received i.v. M loading dose (2 mg/kg) followed by continuous infusion (5-8 mg·kg·24 h). Blood samples were taken between 4 and 24 hours after the start of M treatment, resulting in 230 observations. The concentrations of M and O-desmethyltramadol (M1) were measured by high-performance liquid chromatography. Linear mixed model analysis showed that SLC22A1/OCT1 genotype was independently associated with log-transformed M1/M ratio (P = 0.013), with carriers of <2 SLC22A1/OCT1 functional gene copies having a high M1/M ratio (225. 95% CI , 2.01–2.48) than infants with 2 functional gene copies (1.86; 95% CI, 1.66–2.06). The combined CYP2D6/SLC22A1 genotype was associated with a 57.8% higher M1/M ratio in carriers of ≥2 functional CYP2D6 gene copies and <2 functional SLC22A1/OCT1 gene copies compared to infants with <2 active CYP2P21A and CYP2D6 function. activity (P < 0.001). These findings highlight an additional role of SLC22A1/OCT1 genetics in neonatal M1 exposure. They also suggest that OCT1 is already active early after birth, which may influence the disposition of other OCT1 substrates in this population.

abstract: This study examined longitudinal trends in psychotropic medication prescribing in Australia from January 2000 to December 2011. Data for major classes of psychotropic medications (antidepressants, anxiolytics, sedatives, antipsychotics, mood stabilizers and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) were obtained from the Australian Department of Health and Aging's Substance Abuse Subcommittee. Results were expressed as defined daily doses/1000 population/day (DDDs/1000/day). Between 2000 and 2011, there was a 58.2% increase in psychotropic drug prescribing in Australia, driven by significant increases in antidepressants (95.3% increase in DDDs/1000/day), atypical antipsychotics (217.7% increase) and ADHD medications (72.9%). increase). Dispensing of anxiolytics remained largely unchanged, while sedatives and typical antipsychotics decreased by 26.4% and 61.2%, respectively. Dispensing of lithium remained static, while valproate and lamotrigine increased significantly. Antidepressants accounted for 66.9%/1000/day of total psychotropic DDDs in 2011, far more than anxiolytics (11.4%), antipsychotics (7.3%), mood stabilizers (5.8%), sedatives (5.5%), or ADHD medicines. 3.0%). Sertraline, olanzapine, valproate, and methylphenidate were the most commonly prescribed antidepressant, antipsychotic, mood stabilizer, and ADHD medications, respectively, while diazepam and temazepam were the most commonly prescribed anxiolytics and sedatives. The use of psychotropic drugs increased significantly in Australia between 2000 and 2011. Some potential concerns include: (1) benzodiazepines, especially alprazolam, despite their problematic effects; (2) the rapid increase in serotonin noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) use, given their more complex side effect profile compared to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs); and (3) a dramatic increase in prescriptions for antidepressants, despite questions about the efficacy of these drugs in mild to moderate depression. Finally, some limitations have been identified with the use of the DDDs/1000/day metric, which may bias estimates of the use of specific medications when the specified daily dose is higher or lower than the formulation most commonly dispensed in pharmacies.

abstract: We reviewed the available pediatric literature on second-generation antipsychotic medications to assess the available evidence for efficacy and safety. An English-language MEDLINE search (1974-2003) was conducted using the keywords - atypical antipsychotics, children and adolescents, toxicity, clozapine, risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine, ziprasidone, and aripiprazole. Additional efficacy and safety data were obtained from the drug manufacturers. We identified 176 reports, including 15 double-blind, controlled studies, 58 open-label studies, 18 retrospective chart reviews, and 85 case series/reports. The majority (43%) of these studies were on risperidone. Evidence suggests that second-generation antipsychotics are effective in the treatment of psychosis, bipolar disorders, pervasive developmental disorders, and Tourette's disorder, and are potentially useful in mental retardation, conduct disorder, and severe attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The most commonly reported side effects included cardiovascular effects, weight gain, sedation, sialorrhea, extrapyramidal signs, and hyperprolactinemia, although the relative frequency of these adverse effects varies between medications. Although the evidence base for pediatric use of second-generation antipsychotics is expanding, most available studies are anecdotal or short-term, open-label trials. Reports suggest that these compounds are effective for a variety of psychiatric disorders in children and adolescents, but additional double-blind, controlled studies are needed to determine definitive efficacy. Although these drugs appear to be well tolerated in short-term studies, long-term follow-up studies and ongoing clinical monitoring are necessary to confirm their safety in this age group.

abstract: The Movement Disorders Society (MDS) Working Group Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) Review for the Treatment of Parkinson's Disease (PD) was first published in 2002 and updated in 2005 to cover clinical trial data up to January 2004, with a focus on motor. Symptoms of PD. In this revised version, the MDS Working Group decided that it was necessary to extend the consideration to non-motor symptoms. The aim of this work was to update previous EBM reviews on the treatment of PD by focusing on non-motor symptoms. Level I (randomized controlled trial, RCT) reports of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions for non-motor symptoms of PD, published as full articles in English between January 2002 and December 2010, were reviewed. Inclusion and ranking criteria followed the original program outline and adhered to EBM methodology. For efficacy findings, treatments were assigned: effective, likely effective, unlikely effective, ineffective, or insufficient evidence. Safety data were cataloged and reviewed. Based on a combined assessment of efficacy and safety, clinical practice outcomes were determined using the following designations: clinically useful, possibly useful, investigational, unlikely to be useful, and not useful. Fifty-four new studies qualified for the efficacy review, and several other studies included safety issues. Updated and new efficacy findings were made for all indications. Effective treatments for the management of various non-motor symptoms include pramipexole for depressive symptoms, clozapine for psychosis, rivastigmine for dementia, and botulinum toxin A (BTX-A) and BTX-B, as well as glycopyrrolate for sialorrhea. The practical implications of these treatments, with the exception of glycopyrrolate, are that they are clinically useful. Since there is insufficient evidence for glycopyrrolate to treat sialorrhea for more than 1 week, it may be useful in practice. Medications believed to be effective in managing various non-motor symptoms include the tricyclic antidepressants nortriptyline and desipramine for depression or depressive symptoms, and macrogol for constipation. The practical implications of this treatment may be beneficial. For most other interventions, there is insufficient evidence to draw adequate conclusions about their effectiveness. These include the tricyclic antidepressant amitriptyline, all the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) discussed (paroxetine, citalopram, sertraline and fluoxetine), the newer antidepressants atomoxetine and nefazodone, pergolide, Ω-3 fatty acids (also magnetic stimulation for relapsing MS). ) to treat depression or depressive symptoms; Methylphenidate and Modafinil to treat fatigue; Amantadine for the treatment of pathological gambling; donepezil, galantamine and memantine for dementia; Quetiapine for the treatment of psychosis; fludrocortisone and domperidone for the treatment of orthostatic hypotension; sildenafil for erectile dysfunction, ipratropium bromide spray for sialorrhea; Levodopa/carbidopa controlled-release (CR), pergolide, eszopiclone, melatonin 3 to 5 mg, and melatonin 50 mg for insomnia and modafinil for excessive daytime sleepiness. Due to safety concerns, in practice, pergolide and nefazodone are not useful for the above indications. Because of safety concerns, olanzapine is not useful in the treatment of psychosis. As none of the studies were longer than 6 months, the recommendations given are for the short-term management of various non-motor symptoms. There were no RCTs that met the inclusion criteria for the treatment of anxiety disorders, apathy, medication-related impulse control disorders and related behaviors other than pathological gambling, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD), sweating, or urinary dysfunction. Therefore, there is insufficient evidence for the treatment of these indications. This EBM review of interventions for non-motor symptoms in PD updates the field, but as few RCTs are ongoing, a process of continuous updating is needed. Several interventions and guidelines still lack good-quality evidence, and these gaps provide opportunities for continued research. © 2011 Movement Disorder Society.

abstract: Antipsychotics are widely used in geriatric psychiatric disorders. A growing number of atypical antipsychotics are available, expanding clinical options but complicating decision making. Many questions about the use of antipsychotics in elderly patients remain unanswered in the available clinical literature. Therefore, we sought expert opinion on the use of antipsychotics in elderly patients (65 years and older) for recommendations regarding antipsychotic indications, selection of antipsychotics for various conditions (eg, delirium, dementia, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, psychotic mood disorders), and patients with comorbid conditions or History of adverse effects, dosing strategies, duration of treatment, and drug combinations. Based on the literature review, a 47-question survey with 1411 options was developed. About three-quarters of the options were rated using a modified version of RAND's 9-point scale for evaluating the appropriateness of medical decisions. For other options, experts were asked to write down answers. A survey was sent to 52 US experts in the treatment of older adults (38 geriatric psychiatrists, 14 geriatric internists/family physicians), of whom 48 (92%) completed. When analyzing responses to items rated on a 9-point scale, consensus was defined as a non-random distribution of scores with a chi-squared "goodness of fit" test. We assigned a categorical rank (first line/preferred, second line/alternative, third line/usually irrelevant) to each option based on a 95% confidence interval about the mean. Guidelines were then developed to indicate preferred treatment strategies for major clinical situations. The expert panel reached consensus on 78% of the options evaluated on a 9-point scale. Experts do not recommend the use of antipsychotics for panic disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, non-psychotic major depression, hypochondriasis, neuropathic pain, severe nausea, motion sickness or irritability, hostility, and sleep disturbances in the absence of an underlying psychiatric syndrome. However, antipsychotics were preferred for several other disorders. In case of delusional dementia, the first-line recommendation of experts is only an antipsychotic drug; They also consider adding a mood stabilizer. Risperidone (0.5–2.0 mg/day) was first-line followed by quetiapine (50–150 mg/day) and olanzapine (5.0–7.5 mg/day) as high second-line options. There was no first-line recommendation for agitated dementia without delusions; Only antipsychotics were highly second-line (first-line rated by 60% of experts). The first-line expert recommendation for late-onset schizophrenia was risperidone (1.25–3.5 mg/day). Quetiapine (100–300 mg/day), olanzapine (7.5–15 mg/day), and aripiprazole (15–30 mg/day) were high second-line. Antipsychotics were the only recommended treatment for elderly patients with delusional disorder. For agitated nonpsychotic major depression in the elderly patient, the first-line recommendation by experts was an antidepressant alone (77% first-line); Second-line options were an antidepressant plus an antipsychotic, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), an antidepressant plus a benzodiazepine, and an antidepressant plus a mood stabilizer. For non-psychotic major depression with severe anxiety, experts recommended only an antidepressant (79% first line) and also considered adding a benzodiazepine or mood stabilizer to the antidepressant. Support for adding an atypical antipsychotic to an antidepressant in an elderly patient at adequate doses for adequate duration was limited (36% after two failed trials of first-line antidepressants). Treatment of choice for geriatric psychotic major depression was an antipsychotic and an antidepressant (98% first line), with ECT the other first-line option (71% first line). For mild geriatric nonpsychotic mania, the first-line recommendation is a mood stabilizer alone; Experts also consider stopping the antidepressant if the patient is taking it. For severe non-psychotic mania, experts recommend using a mood stabilizer. Experts also consider stopping the antidepressant if the patient is taking it. In severe nonpsychotic mania, experts recommend a mood stabilizer plus an antipsychotic (57%; first line) or a mood stabilizer alone (48%; first line) and stopping any antidepressant the patient is taking. The treatment of choice for psychotic mania is a mood stabilizer plus an antipsychotic (98%; first line). Risperidone (1.25–3.0 mg/day) and olanzapine (5–15 mg/day) were first-line options in combination with a mood stabilizer for psychotic mania, with quetiapine (50–250 mg/day) as a high second-line option. If the patient has responded well, experts recommend the following treatment duration before attempting to taper and stop the antipsychotic: delirium, 1 week; agitated dementia, tapering over 3-6 months to determine the lowest effective maintenance dose; Schizophrenia, indefinite treatment at the lowest effective dose; delusional disorder, 6 months - indefinitely at the lowest effective dose; psychotic major depression, 6 months; and mania with psychosis, 3 months. For patients with diabetes, dyslipidemia, or obesity, experts avoid clozapine, olanzapine, and conventional antipsychotics (especially low- and medium-potency). Quetiapine is first-line for patients with Parkinson's disease. Clozapine, ziprasidone and conventional antipsychotics (especially low and medium potency) should be avoided in patients with QTc prolongation or congestive heart failure. For patients with cognitive impairment, constipation, diabetes, diabetic neuropathy, dyslipidemia, xerophthalmia, and xerostomia, experts prefer risperidone with quetiapine as second-line therapy. More than a quarter of experts considered these combinations contraindicated: clozapine + carbamazepine, ziprasidone + tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), and low-potency conventional antipsychotic + fluoxetine. When combining antidepressants and antipsychotics, experts would be more cautious about selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, which are stronger inhibitors of CYP 450 enzymes (ie, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine) and nefazodone, monoxidase, TCA inhibitors. Experts recommend additional monitoring when combining any antipsychotic with lithium, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, or valproate (except aripiprazole, risperidone, or high-potency conventional plus valproate) or with codeine, phenytoin, or tramadol. Experts have reached a high level of consensus on many key treatment questions. Within the framework of expert opinion and with the expectation that future research data will prevail, these guidelines provide direction for common clinical dilemmas in the use of antipsychotics in the elderly. Clinicians should be aware that no single guideline can address the complexities of the individual patient and that sound clinical judgment based on clinical experience should be used when applying these recommendations.

abstract: A complete polyglutamine domain expansion (polyQ≥34) in the polysome-associated protein ataxin-2 (ATXN2) is the cause of a multisystemic neurodegenerative disorder that commonly presents as spinocerebellar ataxia and is therefore known as SCA2. But rarely it can present as levodopa-sensitive parkinsonism or motor neuron disease. An intermediate expansion (27≤polyQ≤33) was reported to modify the risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). We now tested the reproducibility and specificity of this observation. In 559 independent ALS patients from Central Europe, the association of ATXN2 expansion (30≤polyQ≤35) with ALS was highly significant. A study of 1490 patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) showed an enrichment of the ATXN2 allele 27/28 in the subgroup with familial cases, but the overall risk of sporadic PD was unchanged. No association was found between polyQ expansions in ataxin-3 (ATXN3) and ALS risk. These data suggest a specific interaction between ATXN2 amplification and the causation of ALS, possibly through altered RNA processing as a common pathogenic factor.
cot: The given abstract provides information primarily about the relationship between polyglutamine (polyQ) expansions within the protein ataxin-2 (ATXN2) and its association with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), as well as Parkinson's disease (PD) to some extent. abstract: Common neurodegenerative diseases include Parkinson's disease (PD), Alzheimer's disease (AD), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), and Huntington's disease (HD). Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive and painless method for stimulating the human brain. Single-pulse and paired-pulse TMS paradigms are powerful techniques for studying the pathophysiological mechanisms of neurodegenerative diseases. Motor evoked potentials studied with single-pulse TMS are increased in PD, AD, and ALS, but decreased in HD. Changes in motor cortical excitability in neurodegenerative diseases may be related to functional deficits of cortical circuits or compensatory mechanisms. Short-term reduction or even absence of paired-pulse TMS-induced intracortical inhibition is common in neurodegenerative diseases, indicating functional disturbances in inhibitory cortical circuits. Reduced short-latency afferent inhibition in AD, PD, and HD may be related to cortical cholinergic deficits in these conditions. Cortical plasticity, tested by paired associative stimulation or theta burst stimulation, is impaired in PD, AD, and HD. Repetitive TMS (rTMS) refers to the use of trains of regularly repeating TMS pulses. High-frequency facilitatory rTMS can improve motor symptoms in PD patients, and low-frequency inhibitory stimulation is a potential treatment for levodopa-induced dyskinesia. rTMS delivered to both left and right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex improves memory in AD patients. Additional motor cortical stimulation at low frequency may be beneficial for HD patients. However, the effects of multiple sessions of rTMS treatment for neurodegenerative diseases need to be tested in future large, sham-controlled trials before they can be adopted into routine clinical practice.

abstract: The interpretation of clinical trials comparing different drug regimens in Parkinson's disease (PD) is complicated by the different dose intensities used: higher doses of levodopa and possibly other drugs provide better symptomatic control, but more late complications. To address this issue, conversion factors were calculated for antiparkinsonian drugs that yield a total daily equivalent dose (LED) of levodopa. LED evaluations vary, so we performed a systematic review of studies covering LEDs to provide standardized formulas. An electronic database and hand search of references identified 56 primary reports of LED evaluation. Data were extracted and mean and modal LEDs were calculated. This yielded a standardized LED for each drug, providing a useful tool for expressing the dose-intensity of different antiparkinsonian drug regimens in a single scale. Using these conversion formulas to report LEDs will improve reporting consistency and aid in the interpretation of clinical trials comparing different PD medications.

abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder characterized by a large number of motor and non-motor features that can affect function to a variable degree. This review describes the clinical features of PD with an emphasis on features that distinguish the disease from other Parkinsonian disorders. A MedLine search was conducted to identify studies evaluating clinical features of PD. Search terms included "Parkinson's disease," "diagnosis," and "signs and symptoms." Because there is no definitive test for the diagnosis of PD, the disease must be diagnosed based on clinical criteria. Rest tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and loss of postural reflexes are generally considered cardinal signs of PD. The presence and specific presentation of these features are used to differentiate PD from Parkinsonian disorders. Other clinical features include secondary motor symptoms (eg, hypomia, dysarthria, dysphagia, sialorrhea, micrographia, gait disturbance, festinations, freezing, dystonia, glabellar reflexes), non-motor symptoms (eg, autonomic dysfunction, cognitive/neurobehavioral disturbances, sleep disturbances. and sensory disturbances such as anosmia, paresthesia and pain). Absence of resting tremor, early onset of gait difficulty, postural instability, dementia, hallucinations, and the presence of dysautonomia, ophthalmoparesis, ataxia, and other atypical signs, with poor or no response to levodopa, suggest diagnoses other than PD. A thorough understanding of the wide spectrum of clinical manifestations of PD is essential for the correct diagnosis of the disease. Genetic mutations or variants, neuroimaging abnormalities, and other tests are potential biomarkers that may improve diagnosis and allow identification of individuals at risk.

abstract: To examine and compare the efficacy and safety of salmeterol xinafoate, a long-acting inhaled beta2-adrenergic agonist, inhaled ipratropium bromide and inhaled placebo in patients with COPD. A stratified, randomized, double-blind, double-dummy, placebo-controlled, parallel-group clinical trial. Multiple locations in clinics and university medical centers across the United States. Four hundred and eleven symptomatic patients with COPD with FEV1 < or = 65% predicted and clinically significant comorbidities. Comparison of inhaled salmeterol (42 mcg twice daily), inhaled ipratropium bromide (36 mcg four times daily), and inhaled placebo (2 inhalations four times daily) over 12 weeks. Salmeterol xinafoate was significantly (p < 0.0001) better than placebo and ipratropium in improving lung function at the recommended doses during the 12-week study. Both salmeterol and ipratropium reduced dyspnea associated with daily activity compared with placebo; This improvement was associated with the use of additional albuterol. Analysis of time to first COPD exacerbation showed that salmeterol was superior to placebo and ipratropium (p < 0.05). Adverse effects were similar among the three treatments. These collective data support the use of salmeterol as first-line bronchodilator therapy for the long-term treatment of airflow obstruction in patients with COPD.

abstract: Tiotropium, a once-daily anticholinergic, and salmeterol are two inhaled, long-acting bronchodilators from different pharmacological classes. The trial was designed to examine the efficacy and safety of both compounds across multiple outcome measures, including lung function, dyspnea, and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in patients with COPD. was a 6-month, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, double-dummy, parallel-group study of tiotropium, 18 mcg once daily by dry powder inhaler, compared with salmeterol, 50 mcg once daily by metered-dose inhaler. It is performed in patients with COPD. Efficacy was assessed by 12-hour monitoring of spirometry, transient dyspnea index (TDI), and St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ). A total of 623 patients participated (tiotropium, n=209; salmeterol, n=213; and placebo, n=201). The groups were similar in age (mean, 65 years), gender (75% male), and baseline FEV(1) (mean, 1.08 +/- 0.37 L; percent predicted, 40 +/- 12% [+/- SD ]). Compared with placebo treatment, mean morning FEV(1) after 6 months of therapy was significantly higher for the tiotropium group (0.14 L) than the salmeterol group (0.09 L; p < 0.01). The mean FEV(1) of tiotropium (0 to 12 h) was statistically superior to that of salmeterol (difference, 0.08 L; p < 0.001). Tiotropium improved TDI focal score by 1.02 U compared with placebo (p = 0.01), whereas there was no significant change in TDI focal score with salmeterol (0.24 U). Tiotropium was superior to salmeterol in improving TDI focal score (p < 0.05). At 6 months, the mean improvement in SGRQ total score from baseline was tiotropium, -5.14 U (p < 0.05 compared to placebo); Salmeterol, - 3.54 U (p = 0.4 vs placebo); and placebo, -2.43 U. A statistically higher proportion of patients receiving tiotropium achieved at least a 4-U change in SGRQ score compared to placebo. Both active agents reduced the need for rescue albuterol (p < 0.0001). Tiotropium once daily improves bronchodilation, dyspnea and the proportion of patients achieving significant changes in HRQoL compared to twice daily salmeterol in patients with COPD.

abstract: Atrial fibrillation is a common but potentially preventable complication after coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. To assess the nature and outcomes of atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery and to develop a comprehensive risk index to better identify patients at risk for atrial fibrillation. Prospective follow-up of 4657 patients undergoing CABG surgery between November 1996 and June 2000 at 70 centers in 17 countries selected using a systematic sampling technique. From a derivation cohort of 3093 patients, associations between predictor variables and postoperative atrial fibrillation were identified to develop a risk model that was evaluated in a validation cohort of 1564 patients. New atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery. A total of 1503 patients (32.3%) developed atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery. Postoperative atrial fibrillation was associated with greater subsequent resource utilization as well as cognitive changes, renal dysfunction, and infection. Among patients in the derivation cohort, risk factors associated with atrial fibrillation were advanced age (odds ratio [OR] per 10-year increase, 1.75; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.59-1.93); history of atrial fibrillation (OR, 2.11; 95% CI, 1.57–2.85) or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (OR, 1.43; 95% CI, 1.09–1.87); valve surgery (OR, 1.74; 95% CI, 1.31-2.32); and postoperative discontinuation of a beta-blocker (OR, 1.91; 95% CI, 1.52-2.40) or an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (OR 1.69; 95% CI, 1.38-2.08). Conversely, a reduced risk was associated with beta-blockers (OR, 0.32; 95% CI, 0.22-0.46), ACE inhibitors (OR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.48-0.79), potassium supplementation (OR, 0.53); 95% CI, 0.42-0.68) and NSAIDs (OR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.40-0.60). The resulting multivariable risk index had adequate discriminatory power under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve of 0.77 in the validation sample. Forty-three percent (640/1503) of patients with atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery experienced more than 1 episode of atrial fibrillation. Predictors of recurrent atrial fibrillation included older age, history of congestive heart failure, left ventricular hypertrophy, aortic atherosclerosis, bicaval venous cannulation, discontinuation of ACE inhibitor or beta-blocker therapy, and use of amiodarone or digoxin. ). Patients with recurrent atrial fibrillation had longer hospital stays and experienced greater infectious, renal, and neurological complications than patients with a single episode. We developed and validated models that predict the occurrence of atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery based on the analysis of a large multicenter international cohort. Our findings suggest that treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and/or NSAIDs may provide protection. Atrial fibrillation after CABG surgery is associated with significant complications.

abstract: Between January 1, 1986 and December 31, 1991, 4,507 adult patients underwent cardiac surgical procedures requiring cardiopulmonary bypass. Of these patients, 3,983 patients who did not undergo surgery for supraventricular tachycardia and who were in normal sinus rhythm form the preoperative study group for the present study. During the postoperative period, all patients were continuously monitored for the development of arrhythmia until discharge from the hospital. The rates of atrial arrhythmias requiring treatment during the most commonly performed operative procedures were as follows: coronary artery bypass grafting, 31.9%; coronary artery bypass grafting and mitral valve replacement, 63.6%; coronary artery bypass grafting and aortic valve replacement, 48.8%; and heart transplant, 11.1%. For all patients considered together, risk factors associated with the incidence of postoperative atrial arrhythmias (p < 0.05 by multivariate logistic regression) included increasing patient age, preoperative digoxin use, history of rheumatic heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and height. Aortic cross clamp time. Postoperative atrial fibrillation was associated with an increased incidence of postoperative stroke (3.3% vs. 1.4%; p < 0.0005), increased length of stay in the intensive care unit (5.7 vs. 3.4 days; p = 0.001), and in the postoperative nursing unit (10.9 vs. 10.9). 7.5 days; p = 0.0001), increased postoperative ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation (9.2% vs. 4.0%; p < 0.0005), and need for permanent pacemaker implantation (3.7% vs. 1.6%; p < 0.0005). These data provide the basis for targeting specific patient subgroups for prospective, randomized trials of therapeutic modalities designed to reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial arrhythmias.
